I do think that, in lots of ways going beyond just violence levels, we take for granted some of humanity's great achievements and how far we've come, and forget how bad things were at other times.I would read on anyway just to get the full skinny on his view even now I'm deeply unsure about it, but another 30 hours of this...? No.

***A bit late, but I finally wrote a review***	People, we are some messed up people. I broke a vow to never read a book with the word angel in it and read this book thinking it would be somewhat uplifting, a milkshake after an excruciating race, a greasy hamburger after a long camping expedition. Hey, we made it. We’re no longer extremely violent. I even read it for ammo in debates against conservative snowflakes who vote and view the world out of fear. The world’s not that bad, you all. Stop stocking up on guns, prepper guides, and moving to covenant controlled compounds. (This is coming from someone who wrote a quasi-apocalyptic novel). 	And much of that is true. Yes, this is the safest time to be alive. Yes, the crime rates and chances to be killed has decreased many fold. Pinker does a wonderful job of detailing this all out, both through stats and anecdotes and across multiple disciplines—from history to psychology to evolutionary biology to philosophy. 	However, I finished this book feeling dirty and carrying a more pessimistic view of humanity. We were so brutal for so long this current Long Peace just seems like an anomaly. Maybe it’s the pages and pages of charts around murder rates and atrocities. Maybe, it’s tidbits like this: The reason we have post-partum depression is to cope with the need to commit infanticide. Yes, try reading 700 pages of why we are so violent and feel good about the better angels of our nature. 	That said, this book is a treasure trove of facts, stats, and learnings that opens the door to many different areas of study, from atrocities and history to psychological studies on what makes us violent. If you like long (sometimes dry) non-fiction and have any interest the aforementioned academic disciplines I would recommend it. 	I would also love to see this book updated every ten years or so. It does feel a bit lacking since it was published in 2011; there is no mention of the current political climate and Pinker could do the world a great service by spending more time on how media makes money by exploiting fear and anger. Cough…and Russia.

Ok small confession to make. I was hoping to purchase this piece on the day it became available, power through it, and be one of the first to post a review on Amazon.This was before seeing the thing...But after pumping through the ~700 pages I feel its worth the size. Pinker dives through history, philosophy, psychology and politics to identify the apparent causes for the 'decline in violence.'I would describe reading the book as a combo of history, psychology and professional polemic. Obviously in picking up such a book, you're going to hear of some of the more gruesome and depressing events in human history, and some pretty scathing reviews of religon and politics. Nonetheless Pinker pursues his thesis scientifically (with a touch of humour) and even with some rigourous finger pointing maintains objectivity.While this piece is amazing, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who isn't keen on the thought of this much non-fiction crammed into one book, and Pinker's style is very dense (in the compact not hurp durp sense.) this isn't really a 'translated into plain-speak' kinda of book (fair warning).Essentially if you've got the time, and the inclination this book will certainly give you food for thought, roughly a years feeding too...

This was really really good, as in, maybe the best book I've read that year. Time and again, I was shocked to find subjects treated of keen interest to me, or which read like Pinker had taken some of my essays but done them way better (on terrorism, on the expanding circle, etc.); even so, I was surprised to learn new things (resource problems don't correlate well with violence?).I initially thought I might excerpt some parts of it for an essay or article, but as the quotes kept piling up, I realized that it was hopeless. Reading reviews or discussions of it is not enough; Pinker just covers too much and rebuts too many possible criticisms. It's very long, as a result, but absorbing.

Very disgusting! The author said ‘United States acquired a reputation of warmonger, fighting in two world wars and in the Philippines, Korea, Vietnam, and Iraq. But the cost in American lives was even smaller than those of other great powers of the country.’He does not even understand that the warmonger reputation refers to the killing of other countries’ citizens, direct or indirect, due to its involvement. Apparently, he does not care the lives of others,as he is pro-colonialism and pro-imperialism. He does not understand and appreciate the complexity of the world, but very simple-minded.

One of the most pathetic stereotypes in preface itself, had me questioning his credibility. Idiot.Feminization is the process in which cultures have increasingly respected the interests and values of women. Since violence is largely a male pastime, cultures that empower women tend to move away from the glorification of violence and are less likely to breed dangerous subcultures of rootless young men

I was captivated by this book but decided not to finish reading it after having read some critical reviews. It appears all of the convincing statistics that lead to the conclusion that the world is becoming less violent are not actually correct. Anyone considering this book should read the reviews ahead of time before embarking on the author’s fantasy.

About 75 pages in, I realized what a waste of my time this book is. I've enjoyed Pinker's previous books on linguistics and cognition. This book, though, is just a mess of selectively interpreted (and in some cases, blatantly misinterpreted) data, presented with breathtaking, unwarranted confidence.

There is a reason that I made reason the last of the better angels of our nature. Once a society has a degree of civilization in place, it is reason that offers the greatest degree of hope for further reducing violence. The other angels have been with us for as long as we've been human, but during most of our long existence they have been unable to prevent war, slavery, despotism, institutionalized sadism, and the oppression of women. As important as they are, empathy, self-control, and the moral sense have too few degrees of freedom, and too restricted a range of application, to explain the advances of recent decades and centuries.
Not long ago, I was playing the game Table Talk with a group of adults and one of the questions was something like, “If you could live in any time and place, what would it be?” We went around the circle and people gave answers like, “I'd move to Cabo (Mexico) in a heartbeat” or, “I'd love to have been a member of Henry VIII's court”, and when my turn came up, the only answer I could give was, “Assuming I'm still me in this fantasy, there's nowhere I would rather live than right here in Canada, right now. I can't think of a time or place that is safer, healthier, and offers more opportunities for women.” Granting that there are many similarly salubrious locales around the world today, there sure weren't throughout history: Would I rather have lived in ancient Greece, seeing my husband and sons off to endless wars, protecting myself and daughters from foreign invaders? Would I rather have lived in the dungheap of the European Middle Ages, under the heavy yoke of the Church and threat of the Inquisition? Would I rather have lived in a little house on the prairie, toiling dawn to dusk, pumping out a kid per year, praying at least a couple of them would survive to adulthood? Living just about anywhere in the early-to-mid-twentieth century would have been a dangerous and fretful experience – if the wars didn't come to me, my menfolk would have went to the wars; leaving me to negotiate a public sphere I was unprepared for – and even in the context of the game we were playing, I couldn't imagine a time and place that I would rather live in than right here, right now. And I didn't need the supporting stats from Steven Pinker's The Better Angels of our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined to garner grudging nods of agreement from both the women and the men I was playing Table Talk with: No matter how pessimistic the nightly news might be, this part of the world just feels safer than ever before. Pinker himself intuited this shift, and this book attempts to explain how we got to today's peaceableness after a long human history of violence, sadism, discourtesy, and disregard for others.
I am sometimes asked, “How do you know there won’t be a war tomorrow (or a genocide, or an act of terrorism) that will refute your whole thesis?” The question misses the point of this book. The point is not that we have entered an Age of Aquarius in which every last earthling has been pacified forever. It is that substantial reductions in violence have taken place, and it is important to understand them.
In May of this year, in a kind of virtual convocation address, Bill Gates tweeted to college grads, “If I could give each of you a graduation present, it would be this – the most inspiring book I've ever read”, to which he attached an image of The Better Angels of our Nature. Later, Gates tweeted, “This is the most peaceful time in human history. That matters because if you think the world is getting better, you want to spread the progress to more people and places. It doesn't mean you ignore the serious problems we face. It just means you believe they can be solved.” It was, therefore, on Bill Gates' recommendation that I picked up this book, and having now read it six years post-publication, I also benefit from the learned reactions of previous readers; which I admit I needed because even as I was reading, I wasn't totally buying Pinker's scholarship: I am not surprised to see on Goodreads that the most popular reviews give it either one or five stars. I don't want to retread worn ground, so here are links to what I found to be the best published perspectives on The Better Angels of our Nature:•Richard Feloni, on the heels of Bill Gates' endorsement, enthusiastically summarised Pinker's thesis in Business Insider.•John Gray tore apart Pinker's “questionable” conclusions in The Guardian. •And Elizabeth Kolbert staked out the skeptical middle ground, more or less where I find myself, in The New Yorker. 
For all the violence that remains in the world, we are living in an extraordinary age. Perhaps it is a snapshot in a progression to an even greater peace. Perhaps it is a bottoming out to a new normal, with the easy reductions all plucked and additional ones harder and harder to reach. Perhaps it is a lucky confluence of good fortune that will soon unravel. But regardless of how the trends extrapolate into the future, something remarkable has brought us to the present.
 Anyone who wants to know the specifics of this book can easily follow my links (or otherwise Google around), so all I want to talk about is my experience. For about the first two thirds of The Better Angels of our Nature, Pinker covers the known and conjectured history of the world, summarising everything in graphs and tables; constantly explaining how he created his graphs, what can be ignored in them, what he ignored while compiling them. I had the uneasy feeling that, as I am not a statistician, I would just need to take his word for everything, and that undermined his persuasiveness. The last third concerns the working of the human brain, and Pinker recounts dozens and dozens of social science and neurobiology experiments, and these were even duller in their recounting than the previous graphs. Whenever Pinker was telling a narrative, I was engaged; when he was sharing (questionable) facts, I was bored. And as the font was rather smallish and my mind tended to drift in the duller bits, I clocked myself at reading a paltry 35 pages/hour: at a not totally unreasonable 700 pages before the footnotes, this book still took far too long to read. I was neither completely entertained or enlightened by what I found here.And yet, I do believe that Pinker made a valiant attempt to explain a phenomenon that most of us intuitively feel to be true. And I do agree with Bill Gates that feeling hopeful about the world leads us to not give up on it. I do think that The Better Angels of our Nature is a worthwhile read, but I would encourage any new readers to also dig into the contrary opinions out there. My weaselly instincts want me to split the difference between the most popular reviews and give this three stars, but the better angels of my nature want me to take a stand, so I'm nudging up to four: this book had more good than not in it.

I really wanted to like this book, but it just had so many problems. I feel like the author was completely west-centric. Yes, violence has declined in the West, but it certainly has not in many other areas. His basic argument for why this was the case was because rationality, reason, and Enlightenment philosophy had displaced "crude religion and faith" as the public morality. In doing this, Pinker completely disregarded the philosophical undertakings of countless "crude religious folk" in crafting this new age of Enlightenment. Additionally, if that were the case, why are the atheistic regimes of Communist China and the Soviet Union the most deadly of any regime in any time in all of history? He also seems to believe that the Catholic church in the middle ages was purely a religious body, when if anything, it was primarily a political body with religious overtones, much like the Roman emperors that proceeded it. the Inquisition had much more in common with the Gestapo than the monks. The author also seemed to pretty unfairly target Christianity. When discussing religious atrocities, there are certainly other groups that did the exact same things, or worse things in the name of their God. It is a real shame, because I do feel like several of Pinker's arguments had merit. The book was also very well written. I just wish he could have kept his complete contempt of religion, religious people, and everything they have done to better humankind out of his narrative.

I found this book interesting, but having read War! What Is It Good For?: Conflict and the Progress of Civilization from Primates to Robots which covers very similar territory to this book, but provides a more compelling narrative, I was slightly disappointed.The first chapters look at different types of violence - war, rape, genocide, murder, torture, slavery etc... and give statistical evidence that it has been reduced over time. In some cases the evidence is hard to come by because historic records are very incomplete, but you still get a 20 page chapter with graphs to tell you that. Ian Morris' book makes the same point in half the time. Alongside the statistical analysis, Pinker explains that violence has reduced due to the coercive power of the government and the analysis of the difference in rates of violence between the USA and Europe was fascinating and the observation that previous elites were more violent, not lower social classes, again however I felt the Ian Morris book provided more insight on how the process unfolds.This book finishes with an examination of the forces that guide violence - seeking gain, sadism, ideology, revenge, need for security etc... This part was a bit short on examples and to me felt like having spent so much time demonstrating that violence has declined there were no more pages left to really examine why people were giving in to these forces less now than in the past.If I hadn't read the other book, I'd have rated this very highly, but obviously I preferred Ian Morris' work.

Stunning book! Probably the most fascinating nonfiction I've ever found!In recorded form, this was 36+ hours long, but it was divided into sections that seemed like full books in themselves.What a work of scholarship! In order to demonstrate the shift toward greater kindness and less violence in the world, Steven Pinker first examined, thoroughly, the many forms that cruelty has taken since our earliest primate ancestors. He then summarized the relevant studies in the sciences and social sciences that document changes in human behavior that make this the safest time in history for a human being to live. He goes into the neuroscience of self-control, as well as many other psychological and sociological explorations of "the better angels of our nature." (Of course, I felt gratified that he found intelligence and education highly correlated with liberal political views - and liberal views the ones that represent our "better nature"!)Some parts of the book were too technical to enjoy - I just tuned them out. But other parts felt so rich in important new concepts that I'm going back over them. This whole book is one that I know I'll revisit many times!
Hardly counts as a book, more like a paper full of statistics. Could be easily published as CSV file with numbers available to parse with software.

Pinker's Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined is one of the most impressive books I've ever read, which is not to say that I found it always convincing. This book is not only interesting because most readers will learn a lot, it's also interesting, perhaps even inspiring, to observe Pinker attempting to prove his thesis that violence has declined -- and then to explain the whys. I sometimes find myself thinking "this guy must have spent months in the library." Maybe he had his students do the preliminary research.There's an interesting, and in my case dual, intuition at work when we talk about violence. On the one hand, I feel like the world must be more violent than ever before. After all, guns, nukes, tanks, drones. On the other hand, I've often noticed that when I ask my students whether they'd like to travel into the past, or when they'd travel to, they don't want to go at all. For a long time, I thought they were just overly cautious or just not particularly curious about history yet. But now I've come to wonder if they just understand that living in a developed nation is in many ways very comfortable compared to living in the past. For many of those students, they know that a trip into the past could lead to discrimination, violence, or in some cases, enslavement. Pinker attempts to put intuition aside and, as much as possible, focuses on data, which is presented in many charts and graphs.Here are some highlights and observations, which I've updated as I read this book.-Why did violence in the USA increase during the 60s? Pinker offers a few takedowns of the Baby Boomers here. While I've mostly encountered the 60s as a righteous time for the counter culture, Pinker points to suggestions that doing what you feel like sometimes meant being violent or even rape. But what about the dominant cultural norms? I didn't understand why he would not have cited the Vietnam War and its draft as an influence. If the central government is usually a pacifying force, what happens when it begins to act in a way that people consider ignoble?-The Spanish Inquisition killed a lot of people in its program of, paraphrasing, "destroying lives to save souls."-Erasmus wrote a book on etiquette and hygiene -- I was really shocked by the number of things that I take for granted as gross that needed to be expressed in this book. It seems like hygiene is a big deal, and for many reasons. In genocide, for example, it's not uncommon to dehumanize the target group by denying them access to hygiene. "Look at them -- they're like disgusting animals."-I don't think we fully understand what torture -- and torture in public places -- was like. I actually went to a museum about torture in Prague once. It was interesting but disturbing. The idea that people would routinely be tortured in public places is something I don't think people understand when they view the past romantically.-Keen's Empathy and the Novel gets a nod here. So someone other than me did read that book.-Pinker writes with clarity, wit, and insight. I particularly enjoyed when his grandmother told him to wear a watch. He is usually generous in his consideration of counter claims and gentle in his rebuttals. But he is also merciless in his exploration. He'll make a claim and support it once, twice, three times, four times... Bring in the Count from Sesame Street.-This is one of the only TED talk books I've read in which the book is worth reading. (Pinker's TED talk on this subject is good, btw.)-Apparently Peacekeeping forces are very effective! "Democide" is a word! Democracy and international trade have many benefits! Kant is a bright fellow, who knew?-Scenario: a married couple and one spouse kills another. A few decades ago, the victim was almost as likely to be male as female. The number of victims has fallen. Why? Pinker argues that feminists brought greater awareness of the violence of battery. There is a lot of evidence that men are far more likely to be violent than women, so what explains the decrease in both sexes? Pinker suggests that what most likely happened is that battered women, when given an escape like a shelter or greater acceptance and encouragement by the culture to speak out, were less likely to murder their partners and less likely to be murdered (and battered) themselves. I swear I encounter theories and trends that are completely new to me in every chapter.-Theories on postpartum depression and infanticide are presented in succession. I'm not sure I'm skilled and knowledgeable enough to represent either theory, but I note them because I was so surprised by them. We find infanticide awful and perhaps also unnatural, but Pinker presents evidence that, though it's awful, it may be natural from an evolutionary point of view. As for postpartum depression, he points to evidence that it is more likely to correlate to certain situations than hormones. If I understand him, he's interpreting the data as suggesting that ppd is a natural phenomena that allows mothers to consider whether they can care for the child; if they decide, yes, the family can provide for the newborn, then love tends to follow. Those mothers who fall in love instantly with their newborns may in some ways be privileged."Combine narcissism with nationalism, and you get a deadly phenomenon that political scientists call ressentement (French for resentment): the conviction that one's nation or civilization has a historical right to greatness despite its lowly status, which can only be explained by the malevolence of an internal or external foe."Taken from a discussion of ideology as an "inner demon" that leads to violence. "Groups can breed a number of pathologies of thought. One of them is polarization. Throw a bunch of people with roughly similar opinions into a group to hash them out, and the opinions will become more similar to one another, and more extreme as well. [...] The overall problem is that groups take on an identity of their own in people's minds, and individuals' desire to be accepted within a group, and to promote its standing in comparison to other groups, can override their better judgment.""The alternative to the myth of pure evil is that most of the harm that people visit on one another comes from motives that are found in every normal person. And the corollary is that much of the decline of violence comes from people exercising these motives less often, less fully, or in fewer circumstances. [...] The mere process of identifying our inner demons may be a first step to bringing them under control."University graduates who studied the humanities and social sciences could test the quality of their education, given or received, by how familiar much of this text is to them.Pinker looks at the Flynn Effect -- which notes that IQ scores rise over time -- and wonders if an equivalent moral effect has led to a decline in violence."For all the tribulations in our lives, for all the troubles that remain in the world, the decline of violence is an accomplishment we can savor, and an impetus to cherish the forces of civilization and enlightenment that made it possible."I read perhaps a half dozen shorter books after starting this one. This book might be better viewed as a sort of encyclopedia. I borrowed it from the library, but I will keep my eyes open for it the next time I'm at a book store. Even those who would challenge the thesis would be wrong to diminish what Pinker attempted here.

Before reading this book I was one of the people who thought violence was cyclical and that every one hundred years we might end up having a war. It is something very easy to believe and preach when you don’t really look into the facts. Steven Pinker’s book is set to debunk such myths that we liked to believe in for a while. He tries to gather an extended set of figures to prove his theory, that violence has steadily declined until our times and that we live in the most peaceful era of humanity. He uses facts and figures for all type of violence: homicides, wars, genocides, domestic violence. It was very easy to like this book, because it writes about ideas that I also share. For example, we can teach morality without the means of religion. Those that claim religion is the only way to make people act morally, should start by first reading the books of the Old Testament. Furthermore, an increase of the level of education was noticed in parallel with a decrease in the one of violence. It is very difficult to prove a relation of causality between them. What I liked less is that some forms of violence were discussed in less detail than others. I felt like Pinker spent a lot more pages discussing about war (both inter- and intra-state) and homicide than regarding violence against women and children and genocide. And I understand the reasoning behind the decision, namely, those forms of violence cause a larger number of victims; but it felt like the book was rushed a bit to list some other forms of violence just for diversity’s sake and then move on to conclusions. As a bonus I also got the answer to some questions I always asked myself when my mother was insisting I should read “The code of good manners” when I was a child. Because, at some point in history, society was lacking what we now consider basic education.I just wish I would have read this book faster, but I started it in a period when it was difficult for me to find enough reading time. It is not an easy book due to the numbers and charts that one has to understand so it takes a lot of time to actually read it properly.
Fascinating and I agree for the most part. But there are some missing connections and it's an ethnocentric view of violence. Like did enlightenment ideas also diminish violence in the East?

We do live in the best time in the world history,and Steven Pinker had to compile a book of 800+ pages,to convince humanity that violence has been declining throughout human history and what we did to achieve that and what we should keep on doing,inorder to enjoy the peaceful,prosperous world.Despite covering wide range of subjects,I mean alot has been covered in this massive book,from political philosophy,history,sociology to human rights,psychology and neuroscience and many more other subjects,with alot of statistics and graphs,you have to admire Steven Pinker`s approach,he manage to make this huge book highly enjoyable,entertaining, interesting,packed with mind blowing historical facts & easy readiable not a dry,dull book of historical facts and statistical data I presume it was before I picked it up.One downside though,you need alot of time investment to go through this one and also a bit of open mind approach especially if you are religious or conservative.I agree with everything that Pinker has presented in this book,and I do believe is among the top 5 greatest books that I have pick up this year,including it's sequal Enlightment Now and The Moral Arc by Michael Shermer.I highly recommend this if you a looking for an optimistic book,a book to understand the world or a guide on how to create a better moral compass on 21the century.And if you have decided to pickup this book also I would recommend it's sequal, Enlightment now and The Moral Arc by Michael Shermer,there is so much to be learn from these books too.

This is a huge book filled with a huge amount of data and ideas. It is a book filled with both horror and hope. I listen to it in the very well presented audible version. I don’t know how thick the book is but it is 36 hours long.I made some observations and comments as I experienced the book and I will not repeat all of them here. For me the author has a political persuasion on the left end of the scale which is something I appreciate. I finished the book having been convinced that in spite of my life being filled seemingly with constant war, the horror of the past far exceeds the reality of the present.Several positive thinkers have observed that the arc of history is bending toward justice. The author ably describes a world also bending toward less violence. He makes the case by examining the reality of violence in history as well as the science of the development of mankind.

Pinker attempts to study trends of violence throughout human history. He sees a decline in violence of all kinds, on all scales of time and magnitude. The first seven chapters document the historical decline of violence, including hate crimes, murders, domestic violence, animal cruelty, war, and genocide. The remainder of the book traces probable causes of the decline, drawing on a huge range of fact sources, from histories to atrocologists to evolutionary psychologists. To sum up, here are the factors that don't show a consistent relationship with violence: weaponry and disarmament (when people want to be violent, they'll do so regardless of available weaponry and rapidly develop more, whereas when they want to be peaceful, the weapons are not used), resources (wealth originates not just from natural resources but also the ingenuity, effort, and cooperation used on resources. A country rich in minerals could experience more war and civil unrest while everyone scrambles for it, or less because other actors rationally understand that peacefully trading will result in more money for everyone), affluence (wealth doesn't correlate with dips in violence, nor are richer countries less violent), or religion (ideologies can be used for violence or for peace). Factors that do show a consistent relationship with violence: a state that uses a monopoly on force to protect its citizens from one another, commerce, women's involvement in decision making and society's respect for the interests of women, the expansion of the circle of sympathy, and increased use of reason. I've stuck points that particularly struck me in the "status updates" section; go there for more specifics and quotes.I was overall impressed. The sheer number and breadth of sources Pinker draws upon is really impressive; even if you discount a number of the facts or his interpretation of them (for instance, I don't believe that a test showign differences in men and women's reaction to hypothetical cheating necessarily reveals an innate, biological difference between the sexes when it could just as easily be due to being socialized to react and think about sex differently), there still remain a mountain of evidence upon which his arguments can still rest. I also think this book suffers from an unfortunate tendency to focus on 19th and 20th century Western Europe and the USA; relatively modern western thought and social movements are given vastly more time and attention than any others, and although I understand that Pinker can draw upon those traditions most readily (and can count on his English-speaking audience to do the same), I still wish a global history of violence used more a more global lens. His data on violent crime, wars, and genocides is decidedly global, but his anecdotes, examples, and the philosophies he draws from are almost exclusively western. That said, his arguments convinced me. I think he demonstrates pretty conclusively that violence, both as a whole and as individual categories, has decreased over time, and his theories as to why made sense to me.

When I first read reviews of this book last fall, I was profoundly unconvinced to the point of feeling almost irritated at Pinker, despite having read and enjoyed at least one of his prior books. This is a great argument, then, for actually reading the book, because I found it an enjoyable read, written in a personable voice. And, to the extent that it makes any sense to offer overarching theories across such a broad sweep of history (cf. Jared Diamond), I found this one convincing.This is a very, very long book that I read over more than a month and had to return to the library for a while in the middle. If I were to attempt to summarize the author's argument, I'd simply be writing my own unconvincing review. So I'll just offer a few details that I found interesting that bolstered his argument. First, he discusses infanticide as a formerly common practice that is now rarer in almost all societies. This is one example of a form of declining violence that modern people might not even realize they've been freed of. Second, he presents extensive statistics on "deadly quarrels"--plotting murders and wars on the same chart, a murder like a tiny war. The point is that quarrels of various sizes break out with various frequencies, so it is not statistically unlikely that something as violent as World War II could have broken out amid a general, much longer-term, decline in violence. Finally, he includes a discussion of the prisoner's dilemma, recast as the "pacifist's dilemma." Why be peaceable when your neighbor might attack you first? Then he shows how innovations like commerce and evolving ideas of honor can change the pacifist's dilemma so that being peaceful is the winning strategy.Those are just a few details that stuck out for me. The book's length is a weakness; sometimes Pinker goes so far down a road that you forget where you were going or why. He is a peppy enough writer (without steering into Natalie Angier territory) that I didn't mind, but it didn't help his argument. In the end, the individual chapters are worthwhile even if you don't buy into the stratosphere-level thesis.

A stunning analysis of historical trends, drawing interesting psychological/political conclusions.But as usual, thanks to Goodreads reviews, I discovered a number of enlightening new reasons as to why I was wrong to have enjoyed a book as much as I did.Apparently some of this book is poorly reasoned and some of its conclusions may well be grounded on made-up statistics. Problem is, I can't be bothered to work out which those were or where in an 800+ page book. Sounds like someone else's job that should've been done before they sold me this.Therefore my only course of action is to believe none of it, just in case? But over the last month, too much of it has sunk in.That's not why I deduct the star. I did that because it's so long!! (I've never successfully stayed conscious for any sizeable book with that orange Penguin spine. It's like a warning label: you will snooze a bit.)

The 20th century was famously soaked in blood, but it turns out that it may have been the most peaceful ten decades in human history. Pinker's basic thesis is that over any time span, at any level, human beings have gotten unprecedentedly less violent, to the point where even the worst pockets of violence on the planet today would barely qualify as average in past eras, to say nothing of the the expansion of tolerance and reciprocity to entirely new areas due to the many revolutions in racial/gender/sexual equality. It's a book that has to be read to be believed, both because of the depth of its argument and because of the horrifying details on just how awful to each other people used to be. Unlikely as it may seem, humanity might actually be progressing.

I've been a fan of Pinker for a long time. This is the worst book he has written. I started out reading it with an open mind, but ended feeling disenchanted. The books length seems to indicate that Pinker is trying to convince himself that violence has declined. He never really succeeds in convincing the reader.

The book argues that things have actually improved. I find it hard to believe that any sane and half-well-read person would think otherwise, without entire chapters on medieval torture. Someone else might like it, but I found it too exhausting. Quitting ~1/3rd through.

I've been profoundly impressed with the two Steven Pinker Books I've read. I heard him say in an interview that he's a workaholic and I can really believe it. He's one of these non-fiction writers who really staggers you with the way he can tackle a subject from a vast, distant perspective but yet who can sift through the nitty gritty of innumerable scientific studies and papers. When you read a Steven Pinker book you know that he's going to come at a problem from many different angles. You aren't likely to come away from the book feeling like you've had the wool pulled over your eyes or that he has selectively covered certain areas that support his thesis and ignored others. He's also very good at covering all the counter-arguments to his position, and he frequently gives them their due, conceding ground when he sees that it is warranted. All in all I find him to be a staggeringly balanced writer. There are so many highly respected non-fiction writers in the world who do an excellent job but still are clearly coming from one side of the aisle, chauvinistically forcing their ideology at the expense of the objective truth. The impressive thing about Pinker is that he's so neutral on so many topics that you frequently don't know where he's going with a topic. It seems like he'll be critiquing something and then he'll move onto the next aspect of the subject and I'll have to follow everything he's saying very closely to figure out if he has a positive or negative opinion of the thing he's discussing. You can never pin him down and he always seems to tip toe along razor thin fences of nuance.The basic premise of this book is that violence has been declining and that we now live in the most peaceful time that there has ever been. The automatic response to this suggestion, for most of us, will probably be incredulity. What about terrorism? Domestic abuse? Knife crime? Gun Crime? Civil wars? Yeah sure. There's plenty of that about. But there's always been plenty of that about. Not only that but there used to be a whole lot of other stuff too. Think of all the practices that were totally normal a few centuries ago. Slavery. Hanging. Torture. Child cruelty. Animal Cruelty. Duelling. Most major countries seemed to spend most of their time at war with someone or other. Steven takes us through all the different measurements of violence and demonstrates to us, beyond a doubt, that the 21st century is a totally unprecedented golden era of peace in the history of our species. After establishing this fact, he moves onto looking for the causes of the decline in violence. There are a lot of different candidates to discuss. Feminisation for example. Women are less war-like than men and a world where women have increasingly more influence is bound to be less violent. Hobbes' Leviathan is another. When we know that there are policemen and prisons and law courts to ensure that most people behave lawfully, we do not have to rely on violence in order to protect ourselves and our property.Free trade and Capitalism is another. When we are trading with the world and making decisions based on increasing capital, costly wars with our trading partners are going to hit us where it hurts.Democracy. When the people have a system of governance where their interests are considered they don't need to overthrow the government in a bloody coup.Literacy. We only consider violence to be wrong when we regard the subject of the violence as belonging to the same in-group as us. Meat-eaters do not regard the steak on their plate as coming from a system of "violence". If the steak were made of Human then their attitude would probably be very different. Most warring cultures in the history of the world have felt little or no empathy for their enemies. So where has the modern culture of empathy come from? Well, primarily from literacy, from our ability to pick up books (or more recently to watch films) that let us into the lives of others so that we can see that these strange people are fundamentally like us and that their suffering is like our own.Hopefully this all gives you the gist of the material. Violence has declined. Why has it declined? Here are some arguments. Now those arguments will be broken down and examined for credibility. Etc.Yeah, it's a really thought-provoking and eye-opening book that will change the way you think about the human race. However, it is pretty damn long. It's a very enlightening read but I don't know if most people will be eager to slog their way through 800 pages of not especially light reading on a grim and unsettling subject. I would definitely recommend it but it's not a book to be entered upon lightly.

This is a fascinating book, and many people will be surprised by what Pinker has to say. We routinely tell ourselves that we live in a violent world, that for all the comforts of civilization wars are more common, more terrible, and more fatal to non-combatants. Anyone who follows the news can cite examples of terrible atrocities that are the basis of our certainty that the human race is demonstrating a destructiveness and depravity towards other human beings unknown in the simpler, gentler past when knights and armsmen fought other knights and armsmen, leaving the civilians largely undisturbed.Stephen Pinker explains, with examples, details, and cites to original sources and current research, that we have it all wrong, and the past was a far more violent place than we typically imagine, or than we experience day to day in all but the most violent places on Earth now. And those "most violent places" aren't our modern cities in developed countries.He examines the levels of violence and the rates of violent death in primitive human hunter-gatherer communities, mediaeval Europe, and modern hunter-gatherer societies. He mines information from physical anthropology, historical records, recorded causes of death, death rates and causes of death in modern hunter-gatherer communities, and the trend is both clear and quite different from what our reflexive biases often tell us. Hunter-gatherer cultures generally have startlingly, even shockingly, high rates of death by violence. This stems from raids and conflicts with neighboring groups, the need to have a reputation for being too strong to attack and/or likely to take revenge if attacked, and other conflicts that, in the absence of a functioning government, individuals have to prevent or resolve for themselves.He traces the significantly lower but still high rates of violence in early agricultural settlements, as government begins to evolve but is still, itself, pretty violent, and then the evolution of things that start to resemble the modern state. We are introduced to Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, and Jean-Jacques Rousseau and how their theories both described and influenced the growth of government, Hobbes' "Leviathan," and the concomitant increase in self-control and decrease in private violence. He describes in enough detail to make the point the behavior that resulted from the expectation that mediaeval armies would feed and pay themselves by "living off the land," i.e., raiding villagers, and damage the enemy's wealth by burning the fields and killing the villagers. Torture was also used routinely, openly--and often as a form of public entertainment.Fewer mediaeval Europeans were likely to die by violence than hunter-gatherers, but it was still a shockingly violent time by modern standards.Pinker marshals evidence from the fields of sociology and psychology as we move closer to our own time, as well as crime statistics, war records, causes of death, etc. He does not shirk examining the effects of the two World Wars in the past century, as well as civil wars, the Rwanda genocide, and other painful modern episodes.He also looks at less obvious declines in violence, such as hookless fly fishing and the elimination of many kinds of "entertainment" that used to be taken for granted. The banning of dodgeball by some schools and summer camps, and speech codes at universities are discussed as ridiculous extremes that are nevertheless simple overshoots of what are generally beneficial trends.Stephen Pinker has a track record of excellent books using psychology and sociology to examine major aspects of modern life in an interesting, informative, and enlightening way. He's done it again, and in this volume lays out a powerful case that the growth of effective government, the development of political forms that placed a premium on self-control, the growth of modern literature (and, eventually, movies, tv, and the internet), democracy, open societies, and international trade have all contributed to dramatically lowering rates of violence and creating a startlingly safe and peaceful world--for now. He makes no claim that we've changed human nature, or that the trends that have produced our current peacefulness could not be reversed.This a compelling, enlightening, and highly readable book.Highly recommended.I received a free electronic galley of this book from the publisher via NetGalley.

This wasn't the easiest book to get through; it's long and quite dense at times.As always though, Pinker delivers a tightly-packed, expansive and extremely thorough overview of violence and its decline. I especially enjoyed the final part of the book where he explores moral psychology.

The title of the book fully explains its main idea: This is the most peaceful time in the entire human history.Do you find it hard to believe? I will tell you why: we are living in the age of open skies.A world in which we receive news from all over the world.This creates a collective illusion that our era is a continuous bloodbath...but it is not! And consider this:the last time superpower countries engaged in a direct fight was 72 years ago(the longest interval to be recorded in the entire history) in the world war two....but was it the greatest atrocity of all times? in absolute numbers, it is among the biggest 3 but if we plot the lives lost during it in relation to the world population at that time it will rank 9th!!! what about smaller countries?statistics point out that they go to war less than before and the percentage of deaths is much lower.And terrorism? of course, September 11 is the largest terroristic attack...but if you look at the big picture, the total number of killings due to terrorism in 2001 is a way lower the average number in the 70s or 80s!!(and the curve is keeping sloping ever since)Although the term"genocide" was first coined during the early years of the 20th century, the total percentage of victims of such crimes is lower than the average of most centuries of recorded history.But never think that the decline is restricted to the massive atrocities only.The rate of homicide was in a semi leaner decline over the course of the past 5 centuries and it still is.In order to appreciate the difference: the chances of a male English aristocrat to get murdered has declined from 25% in the 15th century to almost 0 per 100,000 today! and it is not restricted to the high classes or the developed countries only: it is the same for almost every single country on our planet(the ratios differ of course but the change is always fascinating).Every calculable indicator of violence(ranging from mass killing to animal mistreatment) has shown an almost steady(and adorable) decline.And you do not need centuries to notice it, it is observable on the measure of decades.explore this important website for more statistics: https://ourworldindata.org/............ The first 7 chapters of the book are devoted to state all these facts and trying to explain them leaning on a massive corpse of statistics and metanalyses of historical data besides exploring the suggested theories.The atmosphere changes in the last 3 chapters which try to explain the origin of violence and the resistance against it through the core of human biology, psychology and sociology.

Steven Pinker takes a hypotheses that, reflexively, almost NO ONE in our era wants to believe in: that human violence in all of its measurable forms, has decreased increasingly and exponentially over time. He then proceeds over about 700 pages to organize, display, and rigorously analyze what is surely one of the most formidable collections of data assembled by any popular author in order to prove that idea.This book deals with something perennial in humanity as a species (our propensity for violence in all of its forms), and the only real weakness of this book, for me, is that at times he can be a bit reductionist and overgeneralize a bit.BUT...that's also a by-product of tackling a subject so large and seemingly so universal to the human experience. There's no way anyone can take on a project this large without glossing over some major aspects of social history, etcThis is hugely, intimidatingly erudite, encyclopedic non-fiction that swings for the fences. In an era of eye-rolling "interdisciplinary studies" Pinker brings ideas to bear in this book from fields as diverse as cognitive/social psychology, social/religious history, neuroanatomy, game theory, literature, feminism, anthropology...ad infinitum. The ability of a human mind to collect and correlate all of this knowledge and data for the sake of proving a single, massive idea about human progress is profound, to say the least.The idea that humanity has gotten better over the eons is anathema to people of all political and ideological stripes. Pinker uses a massive body of research to show and explicate (in exhaustive detail) that we, as a species, are fundamentally wrong about that belief in a very major way, and to posit why it has become so.I must agree with Bill Gate's assessment: this is, unquestionably, one of the most important things I've read in my life. I recommend this book unconditionally.

Later edit (2020). Yeah, this is an incorrigible fluff piece. Bumping down to one star from two.Later edit (2018). I have read this book shortly after it was released in 2011. Back then I barely knew any history, and barely knew anything about modern history. The glaring oversights made by this book in trying to twist and turn reality to get to the conclusion that everything is better are just staggering. It is a shinning example of ideology informing one's scientific inquiry so deeply as it to be pathetic. Pinker is the perfect example of the social theorist who projects modern societal organization into the past. I now consider this book to be quite poor. And one day it will be worth writing a more in-depth review as to why.Original review:I don't think I've ever read a work of more sober optimism than The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined.One might criticize Steven Pinker's elevation of investigative journalism (with regards to murder rates in medieval times), to scientific evidence, but nevertheless he makes other very poignant arguments in favor of his hypothesis: that overall, the present is better in terms of overall violence than the past.

This is a book of fascinating ideas argued convincingly. Unfortunately, it is also a book that is about twice as long as it should be. I started each chapter fascinated by the ideas, often bogged down by mid chapter, and sometimes needed to skim through to chapter's end. I felt that much of the material could have been included in an appendix that could be referenced without breaking the narrative flow of the book, and that much more could have been trimmed altogether without harm. Frankly, I believe the book could have been twice as powerful if half as long. Five stars for ideas and content, one for editing.

Pinker marshals huge piles of facts in defense of a thesis that seems self-evident: that there is less violence in the world (or at least the western world) now than at any time in the past. He comes across as deeply conservative, firmly welded to an unchanging world view. It is a book that could only be produced by an author able to deploy battalions of research assistants and bright graduate students. I read most of the text--the graphs were barely legible because of the limitations of my Nook Simple Touch--and suggest that dipping into "The Better Angels of our Nature" at various points and reading 50 pages here and 100 pages there is a good approach.

Most useful 700 pages I ever read. He said plenty of things to annoy both conservatives and liberals. This is always a huge plus in any good book. If you feel the need to agree with everything said on every page you will hate this book. If you enjoy a book that makes you think and see something from a different way then you will gain a lot by reading it.

Truly An Eye OpenerThis book needs to be taught in primary and high schools as part of curriculum. People need to wake up and stop with their dramatic romantic left wing views about the world. The world has become a way better place and everyone needs to realize it.
This book was readable, but too long. Also I'm confused about some conclusions. Also, I think it mostly focuses on Western cultures.
I may need to come back to this. I couldn't make it through a chapter without falling asleep. At least the first several chapters were just so dry.

Now that I am done, I can look at the book as a whole, and say it was fascinating, and an amazing book to debate and talk about. Not that I agree with it all, I am still wary of evolutionary psychology, but I feel smarter at least, and have gained some new ways of thinking about the world we live in and my own pacifist and liberal nature. I love love this quote near the end of the book, and it was said by a man who survived Hiroshima, and fled to Nagasaki for safety where he then survived the other bomb: “The only people who should be allowed to govern countries with nuclear weapons are mothers, those who are still breastfeeding their babies.” Tsutomu Yamaguchi then lived to 93. I have to take back all the suspicions of misogyny of the author for him to include that as a valid and new way of thinking. It is dramatic, and I know reverse sexism; but he also cites studies where male testosterone is lowered by men who are spending quality time with their families, so there are possibilities for enlightened governance with both sexes.Now, the author might be pulling out all the tricks and optical illusions of a magician with graphs and charts and maps (oh do i melt at maps) but he is answering questions I didn't know to ask, or think to ask. He may be drowning us in study after study of impoverished unemployed psychology grad students who are required to participate in research to graduate. Are they a true cross section of humanity that can be generalized to all of humanity?However, the good first: For example, a simple yet elegant reason why people from New England and Mid Atlantic region may be so different in temperament and how they view guns for example than southerners is that the northern states were settled by more “urban” Europeans coming from parts of Europe that had central government with structure and justice and the South by more “rural” people who were more nomadic, independent, less affected by government, theorizing that central government vs. anarchy is related to the evolution away from violence. The author cites psychological studies throughout, but one that impressed me most was one comparing how southern and northern students responded to a incognito researcher who mumbled an insult to them as they walked by; then they had their blood drawn, and interviewed by another researcher. The southerners had higher levels of testosterone and cortisol (stress hormone) and behaved more dominantly towards the 2nd researcher. The theory withstands a test of homicide rates now also; the highest homicide rates are in the “ghetto” that tends to have the worst relationship with government through law enforcement, more like an anarchic state within a country, leading to more vigilante justice because they don’t or can’t trust the government to be fair.Apparently there was a popular theory in Freakonomics that I missed that linked a decrease in violence in the 1990’s (when New York redeemed central park and disneyfied times square) to the legalization of abortion with Roe v. Wade. It stated that the abortions were preventing unwanted children, who were fated to become murderers and criminals, thereby decreasing homicides. It was popular and widely accepted and entirely false. Words are everywhere as in most books, but his writing style is eloquent and rich with new and fun words you don’t read every day, and I feel smarter just by reading his sentences. His sentences bring me pleasure even if I am tuning out a few subjects about the study of war and such. in•nu•mer•ate : unfamiliar with mathematical concepts and methods; unable to use mathematics; not numerate. Used to call our media guilty of innumeracy and why it gets so much wrong. praetorian : (in the ancient Roman republic) one of a number of elected magistrates charged chiefly with the administration of civil justice and ranking next below a consul, associated with corruption. penury : 1. extreme poverty; destitution. 2. scarcity; dearth; inadequacy; insufficiency.arrogate : 1. to claim unwarrantably or presumptuously; assume or appropriate to oneself without right: to arrogate the right to make decisions. 2. to attribute or assign to another; ascribedemocide : any mass killing of civilians by a government or militia. atrocitologist: one who studies atrocities.eschatological : any system of doctrines concerning last, or final, matters, as death, the Judgment, the future state, etc.surmise : to think or infer without certain or strong evidence; conjecture; guess.ignominy : disgrace; dishonor; public contempt.dekamegamurderers : 4 governments that are responsible for ¾ of 141 democidal deaths (Soviet Union, China, Nazi Germany, and China again (1928-49))meme : a cultural item that is transmitted by repetition in a manner analogous to the biological transmission of genes.recrudescence : breaking out afresh or into renewed activity; revival or reappearance in active existence.eponymous : giving one's name to a tribe, place, etc.: Romulus, the eponymous founder of Rome. egalitarian : asserting, resulting from, or characterized by belief in the equality of all people, especially in political, economic, or social life. augur : to divine or predict, as from omens; prognosticate; to serve as an omen or promise of; foreshadowalembic : noun, 1. a vessel with a beaked cap or head, formerly used in distilling. 2. anything that transforms, purifies, or refines. Abrogation : to abolish by formal or official means; annul by an authoritative act; repealDiametric : in direct opposition; being at opposite extremes; complete, along a diameterComity : mutual courtesy; civility.One of the origins of genocide, which by the way, is a word not invented until 1944 at the Nuremberg trials, can be a desire of some disturbed leader for a return to an older, utopian way of life, and a rejection of the sophisticated urban landscape where people mix in commerce and business. It is tied to a belief that their own ethnic group settled an area and is the superior race, and they usurpers must be annihilated. This was a motivation of Hitler, since he associated Jewish people with the progress of a city and he wanted to make more land available to the Aryans for farming. Again, it is a possible elegant explanation or one of many, for the great divide between the politics of cities and rural towns. Not that country folk want to annihilate me, but they might be suspicious of what I see as progress within the great diversity of city, whereas they view in in fear. There are some historians that claim the 20th century is unique in the amount of genocides, but it was just never called that before, nor was it interesting to historians at the time, lumped in with cattle and oxen. The chapter called the “rights revolution” was one of the harder chapters to get through. He opens with a charming anecdote about his skill at dodge ball as a child, and then ridicules the fact that it has been banned in schools. There is not much doubt that “political correctness” can be absurd at times, but this sentence is very biased: “But now the Boy Gender has lost another battle in its age old war with camp counselors, phys ed teachers, lawyers, and moms.” Those pesky moms, I imagine, had to fight with all the cool dads who wanted to keep it right? Maybe the sentence would be okay with “parents” instead of “moms,” implying that only moms could be concerned about the welfare of their children. If I were a father, I would be mad as hell. The author charmingly relates that he wasn’t athletic or graceful or talented at sports, but could withstand pain. So he is admitting that dodge ball causes pain, and he must not have children, because when he grew up in Canada, there were no 14 year olds killing each other as there is now, and children have gotten bolder and bolder in bullying. I saw the jocks in my time throw the ball as hard as they could while making it look effortless, and I have felt the pain of the red marks on the poor skin of the smartest, kindest boys I knew. I could also note that as this chapter dragged, and the second half of the book continued, I found new and intricate words less and less. I don’t think what he was saying about banning dodgeball or other play fighting leads to more violent behavior, because he has already debunked that myth, that suppression of more innocent violence builds up and needs to be aired and does so in an uncontrollable way. It is actually a lovely way that our intolerance of violence has spanned the continuum from war, genocide, rioting, lynching to hate crimes, rape, assault, battering, to bullying, discrimination, etc. He says that, but then uses phrases like “contagion of rights,” and “overshooting of the campaign…to prevent abuse and neglect. And “puzzling customs, peccadilloes, and taboos.” I wanted a dispassionate and fair book, and apparently this man has an agenda to restore dodgeball. While rape is “incomprehensible form the vantage point of contemporary moral sensibilities,” it makes sense from an evolutionary point of view. I can’t believe I wrote that. I am learning more and more about evolutionary psychology which unfortunately for me “seems to be true” but offends my intuition. Most women I know are not jealous of their cheating partners because their genetics are at risk as the male spreads his around. Even if that is a subconscious motive, it is not the only motive, but destruction of trust, fear of future deception, fear of not being sexually attractive to their partner, anger at being a fool, and sense of betrayal are all concrete, real emotions they may have. What I do agree with is that there is some perpetuation of the ownership of women in the custom of a ring to mark a woman and not a man as “taken” and how fathers “give away” their daughters. So I don’t plan on an engagement ring, but am not sure that it is that damaging. What is terrible is the capitalism-encouraged pressure on the guy to get the flashiest ring possible or risk being accused of not enough love. More about rape: “it is the nature of sexual reproduction that a female should evolve to exert control over her sexuality…she should choose the time, the terms, and the partner…which predicts that a woman should abhor being raped.” Sure, sounds true, but what I know what women hate about being raped is again, nothing to do with genetics, and choices being taken away, but with the absolute pain of forced intercourse, the delicate tissues being damaged in a way that would be like a penis stuffed into a man’s nose, with pain not relieving for a very long time; the pain from the muscles being battered perhaps torn; the pain from the multiple strikes to delicate and sensitive areas of the body, face, throat, breasts, etc.; the risk and presence of STD’s that are not preventable; and the emotional aftereffects of being violated and not being able to stop it. Oh, and the questions that society have always had about rape, oh, a miniskirt? Oh she was drinking too much and grinded against him in the club? Oh fuck-me heels? Full disclosure: I have not been raped nor have any of my closest friends. Moving onto domestic violence, apparently men and women are equal in the times they use violence against their partners. The author clarifies the definition of DV as a more “systematic intimidation and coercion,” which is almost solely the practice of men. I can live with it, I am sure there is a lot of slapping and pushing that women initiate. He calls it “small stuff” unless it qualifies as an “assault” and is reported. If you have been living in the same world I have, you know that is the part that is blatantly false and made ubiquitous in made for tv movies and are visible realities in the faded and healing bruises of the women who are finally forced to go to an ER due to a broken bone or a slash that needs stitching; and because women will rarely report all the rapes, the black eyes, the bruised stomachs that they receive. Did you know that many batterers will stab themselves with a knife or injure themselves somehow so they can imply self-defense? Where are the statistics on that? Oh, they must be hidden in the “small stuff” that each partner does equally to each other. I can’t even go into the postpartum depression and infanticide section. He suggests PP depression is not a “malfunction, but a design…loosely based to measure hormonal imbalances.” And then quotes a disgusting quote by Plutarch from the 1st century that is ridiculous. I can assure you, I have seen a thousand births, and a thousand newborns “so naked, so shapeless, so foul and resembling more jus slain than one just born, he is an object for non to touch or life up or kiss except for someone who loves with natural affection (i.e. a mother).” I am not a mother, and definitely not to them, but they melt the heart of anyone with one. And to bond, mothers must “overcome considerable psychological obstacles.” I am starting to think this author is a misogynist. It was interesting to learn that the fear of kidnapping of children has led to most parents driving their kids to school, which has led to more children getting hit by the cars they are driving. The number of kids walking to school has fallen from 60% to 10%. So with relief I left the rights chapter and delved into the psychology chapters which I thought would explain our inner demons, what they were all about, and our better angels. Evolutionary psychology is just not my cup of tea, unfortunately. It starts out by trying to convince me (he calls me dear reader) that I am “wired for violence”, since when I was in my terrible twos, I bit my sister. Oh and 70-90% of men and 50-80% of women have had a homicidal urge within a year. Yes, they were all those nonviolent college students, but let’s extrapolate to everyone. I am sure that there is a wiring in my head that could become active, if I became psychotic or had traumatic brain injury; but I must be in the 20-50% percent of women that do not ever have homicidal thoughts. True confession: I hit my dog across her snout other night because I thought a coyote was stalking us and she wouldn’t run with me. I do not believe that almost all men have homicidal thoughts or that half of all women do. I am sure some do. Dear author, I am not lying as your student shouted out in your lecture. This is warped thinking. Show me the study replicated several times, with multiple cultures and countries, and I will admit I was wrong. I looked at one of the articles he cited and it was misquoted. The results were far less than he said, and stated the people had a homicidal thought in their lifetime, not in the past year. I am questioning the validity of this work. My instincts are being confirmed by the controversy over evolutionary psychology. For example, there was an experiment that was about self-control; the researchers tried to drain self-control and see how people responded. Participants were placed in front of fresh baked chocolate chip cookies and also radishes while the delicious aroma of cookies was being piped in and told to eat 2 or 3 only of one or the other as assigned for a taste test. They gave them unsolvable logic puzzles to solve and then observed them. It was significant to them that the people that had eaten the radishes worked less hard and took less time on the puzzles than the other participants who got the chocolate chip cookies; it could be interpreted that they had to use so much strength to resist the cookies they couldn’t focus on the puzzle. Maybe. Maybe the chocolate did its trademark thing, made them feel good in the pleasure center, and they had more incentive or motivation or feeling of wellbeing or patience. Maybe the simple sugars in the cookies gave them a boost which the author cites in another part of the book as a deterrent to violence. Maybe the harmony of eating cookies with the scent surrounding them compelled them to work harder while the radish eaters felt a disconnect they couldn’t pin down. With this particular study, they did replicate with other stimuli than food, so I might be more convinced. But it is an example how it is controversial.  I do appreciate this overview of the author’s ideas: “throughout this book, I have assumed that human nature, in the sense of the cognitive and emotional inventory of our species, has been constant over the ten-thousand year window in which declines of violence are visible, and that all differences in behavior among societies have strictly environmental causes. That is the standard assumption in evolutionary psychology, based on the fact that the few centuries and millennia in which societies have separated and changed are a small fraction of the period in which our species have been in existence. Since most adaptive evolutionary change is gradual, the bulk of our biological adaptation must be to the foraging lifestyle that prevailed during the tens of millennia, rather than to the specifics of societies that have departed form that lifestyle and diverged from each other only recently.” The last quarter of the book has some interesting theories such as how game theory is used to evaluate history and patterns; who can forget the Prisoner’s Dilemma, which is not a zero-sum game, which might be my favorite new phrase that I am testing out in everyday life. There is research on self-control and strengthening “self-control muscles” as mentioned above, rational thinking, how intelligence affects violence, and morality. I might go back to those at some point, I didn’t feel they were too earth shattering. Overall, what a book, beyond thought provoking to so mentally satisfying.

Some facts:-	As a proportion	 of the world population of the time, WWII had the ninth-highest death rate of all known wars. WWI had the sixteenth-highest.-	The number of nuclear states is at its lowest since the 1950s.-	Compared to the late 1970s, there are about four times as many democracies, and a about quarter as many autocracies.-	Interstate, intrastate and extrastate conflicts have declined, both in absolute number of conflicts per year and death rates per conflict, consistently since 1992. Genocide has declined consistently since the end of WWII.-	Racially motivated murder has declined fivefold in the US since 1996.-	The number of white US citizens who claim to disapprove of interracial marriage decreased from almost 100% to around 30% between the 1940s and 1990s. Segregationist attitudes fell from around 70% to around 5% in the same period.-	Homicide rates in the US have fallen by about 50% since 1973. Incidence of rape has fallen by about 75%. Victims of domestic violence, both male and female, have declined in number in both the UK and US since the mid-1990s.-	Vegetarianism rates have tripled in the UK since 1984, and increased even more sharply in the US since 1995.Starting this book, I had four concerns that I didn’t think Pinker could match: what about nuclear proliferation? What about the environment? What about the depletion of resources, and John N. Gray’s speculation that this will lead to a great deal of war in the 21st century and thereafter? And what about the factory farming industry, which has billions of animals a year living in intolerably cruel conditions? Pinker anticipates all four of these objections, although he deals with the nuclear threat better than others. It does turn out that concern for animal welfare is rising steadily and has been for some time, and in some cases this translates into actual better treatment of animals; while it doesn’t look like demand for factory farming is going to go away in my lifetime, factory farm conditions continue to improve, and he makes the point that, once the animal welfare/rights movements reach a certain critical mass, it’ll put more pressure on the process of lawmaking. It turns out that environmental damage and resource depletion, contrary to popular opinion, don’t cause war, although obviously they are bad things in themselves. However, Peter Singer notes that “Solomon Hsiang and colleagues at Columbia University used data from the past half-century to show that in tropical regions, the risk of a new civil conflict doubles during El Niño years (when temperatures are hotter than usual and there is less rainfall). If that finding is correct, then a warming world could mean the end of the relatively peaceful era in which we are now living."The writing starts off with good humour and a delightful sense of irony, but it gets a little drier and duller as it goes on. This is not entirely the author’s fault – there’s a shift away from historical narrative toward data analysis, and it’s a lot harder to be interesting with that. And because I wanted to read the book carefully, it sometimes felt like a slog. I realise that an ambitious hypothesis like this one needs to be explained and defended at length, and I applaud Pinker for his scope and energy, but there’s too much repetition and throat clearing and I honestly feel that maybe a hundred pages could have been shaven off at no big cost.This is not the first book of this kind, but seems to be the biggest, most comprehensive, and most ambitious. Most importantly, it goes beyond the claim that the world is getting more peaceable, and attempts to explain why. Some of its explanations are better than others (I’ll get to that) but honestly, I’m impressed and pleased just that people are even trying.There are a couple of less promising bits of news – violence is getting more common in Islamic parts of the world, and among poor black Americans. Pinker makes – convincing, I think – efforts to explain why these exceptions exist. And in spite of them, the overall world trends are going in the right direction. Not very appeasing if you live in Somalia or a New Orleans slum, but appeasing if you have a “citizen of the world” kind of perspective. These negative trends are slight, and outweighed in scope and scale by the positive ones.I’m one of the few remaining people who think the Iraq war did more good than harm (I’ll talk about that when I finally get to my review of A Long Short War), and I think Pinker underpraises it, despite having to acknowledge some of the things which I think go in its favour. I think Pinker has to adopt a stance that fits with the modern zeitgeist, in order to be able to have common ground with his audience about what qualifies as progress. But doesn’t that fact make the book’s claim kind of tautologous? I remember that Julian Baggini says it’s a myth that the world is improving, because we’re simply blind to the prejudices and biases of our day; we don’t realise that the zeitgeist is the way it is, and we like it simply because we’ve grown up in it. I don’t really agree with Baggini’s position – I don’t think it can explain why I have different views to the norm, and it also seems sort of nihilistic or relativistic – but it’s something worth thinking about.A lot of the critical reviews of this book, both on this site and elsewhere, are very poor. Several detractors admit they haven't even read the book, and various others clearly haven't read it properly. For instance, John Arquilla criticizes the book for ignoring civilian deaths, which is not true. Robert Epstein says that Pinker doesn't address the concern of a nuclear Iran, which is not true (it's right there on p.373–375). There are people (such as Arquila) who evidently don't understand the concept of a trend and think it's sufficient just to name some violent events. There are others who accuse Pinker of confirmation bias, and consequently dismiss his case, but not once do they ever provide statistics to contradict his own. A case of pot and kettle, perhaps? People attack him for using the dictionary definition of “violence”, instead of some obscure and unworkably broad one. The most common criticism is that Pinker measures violence rates, rather than absolute figures...how ridiculous. Is it better that nobody exists so that absolute numbers drop to zero? Each new human brought into the world has an opportunity to become a psychopath, a murderer, a zealot, so the fact that more and more people are not doing so is vindication of his position. If you have infinite patience you can read Reality Denial, which manages to make all of these asinine criticisms and more.That doesn't mean there are no good criticisms of the book though. As Miquixote notes, Pinker seems to think an ideology is something only other people can have. Ideologies cause all this war and destruction so we need classical liberalism instead, which apparently doesn't count as an ideology. This is only a semantic problem, but it’s one that makes it impossible to understand what he means when he blames wars on ideology. Pinker claims that rationality and classical liberalism are two of the main reasons things are getting better, and that the two are related. To support this theory he cites the studies which find Lib Dem voters to be smarter, on average, than voters for other parties. Other parties, that is, except my own (the Green Party). Ah, he says, but when you control for class the Green Party falls behind! He never explains why one ought to control for class. He also dismisses the often socialist and environmentalist views of the intellectual elite because they are, he thinks, more prone to "daring opinions, clever theories, sweeping ideologies and Utopian visions".
