So the link between intelligence and political position matters right up to the point where it starts to contradict Pinker’s brand of liberalism, and anybody beyond that point is subject to ad hominem arguments and dismissed.Pinker also tells us, in favour of his "gentle commerce" theory (for which he finally admits after several hundred pages there is no evidence), that "whether or not a leader's power is constrained by a ballot box, in a market economy it is constrained by stakeholders who control the means of production..." So capitalism corrupts the democratic process and Pinker is citing this as a good thing? I have a major political disagreement with him here: it seems that, when forced to choose, he prefers pacifism to democracy.There’s an interesting defense (borrowed from George Eliot) of the value of fiction, in that it expands our moral sphere, enabling us to feel sympathy for people we normally wouldn't. But is this necessarily a good thing? Notice how many people interpreted Humbert Humbert as the victim of Lolita? I know that Tony Soprano and Walter White are psychopaths, but ain't it just so hard not to root for them?Despite these problems and a few others, the overall argument that violence has considerably declined is very convincing, and made with remarkable ingenuity. What's really impressive about Pinker's effort is that he has managed to meet almost every conceivable criticism. Einstein was a controversial writer too, and when a pamphlet was published entitled “100 Authors Against Einstein”, he retorted "If I were wrong, one would be enough." I’m pleased to say that after all the dozens of raging critiques of Better Angels I’ve read, the main theory remains intact.Pinker says his next book will be "a style manual for the 21st century, applying the insights of linguistics, psycholinguistics, and cognitive psychology to the crafting of clear and stylish prose." What Goodreader wouldn't want to read that? I can't fucking wait. I'm serious.__________AUGUST 2016 UPDATEI just learned of this study which finds an impressive correlation between the rise and decline of lead poisoning (as a consequence of leaded gasoline) and crime in various countries. To memory Pinker doesn't consider this plausible causation in his book.

The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined by Steven Pinker“The Better Angels of Our Nature" is the reference quality book that that successfully and thoroughly posits the reasons why violence has declined over time. In this massive and persuasive book, Steven Pinker Professor of Psychology at Harvard University, follows the facts wherever they may go and provides compelling arguments backed by sound science. What makes this book great is the quality of the material presented and the absorbing topic being pursued. Pinker succinctly establishes the premises and systematically goes after them with scientific diligence. This 832-page book is composed of the following ten chapters: 1. A Foreign Country, The Pacification Process, 3. The Civilizing Process, 4. The Humanitarian Revolution, 5. The Long Peace, 6. The New Peace, 7. The Rights Revolutions, 8. Inner Demons, 9. Better Angels and 10. On Angels’ Wings.Positives:1.	Rigorously researched book in the hands of a master.2.	Violence is a fascinating topic. Pinker covers this topic from virtually every angle and I mean from every angle. This is a meticulous book, I can’t stress this enough.3.	Accessible prose. 4.	Great use of charts and illustrations. Very few books provide as many charts as this book. Chart after chart that effectively conveys what he has put so well into words. 5.	This book posits the basic premise with gusto, “violence has declined over long stretches of time, and today we may be living in the most peaceable era in our species’ existence”. I have not read a book that has made a more compelling case.6.	Thoroughly explains MANY kinds of violence that have moved in the same direction.7.	Great quotes, “Across time and space, the more peaceable societies also tend to be richer, healthier, better educated, better governed, more respectful of their women, and more likely to engage in trade”.8.	In a nutshell, “The Better Angels of Our Nature is a tale of six trends, five inner demons, four better angels, and five historical forces”.9.	The Six Major Trends that make up our species' retreat from violence: 1. The Pacification Process (the transition from the anarchy of the hunting, gathering, and horticultural societies); 2. The Civilizing Process (the consolidation of a patchwork of feudal territories into large kingdoms); 3. The Humanitarian Revolution (the first organized movement to abolish socially sanctioned forms of violence like despotism, slavery, dueling, judicial torture, superstitious killing, etc...; 4. The Long Peace (since World War II the great powers have stopped waging war on one another); 5. The New Peace (since the end of the Cold War in 1989, organized conflicts of all kinds, have declined; The Rights Revolutions (since the Universal Declaration Human Rights in 1948, has seen a growing revulsion against aggression on smaller scales).10.	The Five Demons: 1. Predatory or instrumental violence, 2. Dominance, 3. Revenge, 4. Sadism, and 5. Ideology.11.	The Four Better Angels: 1. Empathy, 2. Self-control, 3. The Moral Sense, and 4. The faculty of Reason.12.	Five Historical Forces: 1. The Leviathan, 2. Commerce, 3. Feminization, 4. Cosmopolitanism, and 5. The Escalator of Reason.13.	This is an enlightening book. I have learned so much from this book. So many interesting theories, anecdotes, and history revolving around the concept of violence. Excellent!14.	The Bible as one long celebration of violence. Right off the bat Pinker puts the Bible in perspective. 15.	The book is full of amusing historical anecdotes of course involving violence. "Andrew Jackson, immortalized on the twenty-dollar bill, carried bullets from so many duels that he claimed to 'rattle like a bag of marbles' when he walked". 16.	Hobbes and his logic of violence. The three principle causes of quarrel: 1. Competition, Diffidence, and 3. Glory. And the Hobbesian trap.17.	The Leviathan theory, law is better than war. A recurring theme.18.	As with every book from Pinker, the best use of current knowledge, science. Evolution.19.	The motives of warfare.20.	The most violent centuries of human history.21.	The explanation of the strange idiom "to cut off your nose to spite your face".22.	What spearheaded the European decline of violence.23.	Pinker will overwhelm you with numbers and how those numbers make sense. As an engineer, I'm impressed.24.	The author starts many great topics with a series of questions and then proceeds to go to work.25.	The differences between husbands and bachelors.26.	The author brings up so many amusing historical tidbits.27.	The great crime decline of the 1990s.28.	Many social issues of interest are covered with a luxury of details.29.	Great quotes, "Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities" - Voltaire.30.	The fascinating macabre world of the instruments of torture.31.	Witchcraft as one of the most common motives for revenge. So many horrible stories.32.	The prominent voices of the Age of Reason.33. The psychology behind Global Zero.47.	The kinds of organized violence.48.	The four causes of most childhood deaths.49.	Divisive ideologies.50. The decimation of Al Qaeda's leadership.54.	A fascinating look at the support for jihadist militants.55.	A look at laws and practices of Muslim countries.56.	Climate change and violence?57. Nature versus nurture.84.	The historical direction of morality.85.	The Flynn Effect.86.	Rising intelligence and the link to less violence.87.	Intelligence and liberalism. Interesting.88. Links worked great!Negatives:1.	The book may overwhelm you. There is so much here (over 800 pages) so it will require an investment of time.2.	The author has progressive views (for the sake of honesty so do I) and may rub the conservative voices the wrong way.3.	A couple of editing issues...minor issues considering how massive this book is. 4.	I'm an atheist but even I can find some positive things to say about some religious practices.5.	Having to buy multiple copies of this book, I rented it but I will purchase it for reference sake!In summary, this is a fascinating, massive book about the decline of violence in history. Steven Pinker has written an encyclopedic, enlightening, and ambitious book that covers practically every topic related to violence. This is a book that I will reference for the rest of my life. It’s that thorough and complete. However, this massive book will overwhelm you at times. There is so much in this book that at times it can be repetitive and will test your patience to read it all. All that being said, this book is a worthwhile read. It will reward you with enlightenment on such an important topic. Highly recommended, it’s definitely a keeper. Further recommendations: "The Blank Slate" by the same author, "The Moral Landscape" by Sam Harris, "Justice: What's the Right Thing To Do?" by Michael J. Sandel, "The Braintrust: What Neuroscience Tells Us about Morality" by Patricia S. Churchland, "Mistakes Were Made (But Not By Me)by Carol Tavris, "Human" by Michael S. Gazzaniga, "Misogyny: The World's Oldest Prejudice" by Jack Holland, "A People's History of the United States" by Howard Zinn, "Ideas" by Peter Watson, "Guns, Germs and Steel" by Jared Diamond, and "Against All Enemies" by Richard A. Clarke.

Subtitle: "Why Violence Has Declined". The opening sentence of this book's preface is: "This book is about what may be the most important thing that has ever happened in human history." Well, then. Steven Pinker has never been one to shy away from big topics, but he also is not known for bluster which he cannot back up. So, needless to say, this is not a book of Many Small Ideas. This is a book about One Big Idea, and it is aiming high.The book apparently grew out of the 2007 Question on the website edge.org: "What are you optimistic about?" It was a hard time to ask such a question, with the re-election of George W Bush and two ongoing wars in Iraq and Afghanistan all doing their part to bolster pessimism. Steven Pinker's reply was that he was optimistic about violence declining in the future, which seemed a non-obvious answer at the time. To provide more evidence to back up his assertion, he went on to write this (700 page, plus notes) book.For such an optimistic book, it is a hard read for the first few chapters, not because it is in any way badly written, but because the content is so disturbing. The first section of the book is titled "A Foreign Country", and the country in question is the past. In order to demonstrate that violence has declined, nearly continously over the entirety of human existence, he has to explain to us just how violent the past was. Not just violent, but sadistically, systematically, and thoroughly violent. Violent towards not only wartime enemies and murderers, but towards petty thieves, women, children, animals, and just about anyone lower in power than you. Violent as a matter of principle, as an ongoing lifestyle.This requires Pinker to undo what has been called "the pacification of the past", a phrase for the tendency of textbooks and museums of history to gloss over how brutal virtually every society in the past was. So, for several chapters, you get to read about torture, rape, punishment both cruel and unusual, murder both premeditated and not, and warfare going back to the Stone Age. Pinker admits in one chapter to having his sleep disturbed by his research. I was a bit worried about that from just reading it.It does get better, though, as you move on. Using many different sources of data that all paint the same picture, he shows humanity moving from a world in which 20% of males died a violent death (hunter gather society), a rate of several hundred homicides per 100,000 people per year, down to less than 100 by the high Middle Ages in Europe, down to 10 by the early 1700's, down into the low single digits by today (in Western Europe, close to 1). That is a reduction in the rate of violent death by more than two orders of magnitude. To put it another way, from the point of view of where we began, as Stone Age hunter/gatherers, the problem of violence has been 99% solved.Of course, 99% is not 100%, and even in the last 100 years there have been upticks (notably WW1 and WW2). Even these, though, on a per capita basis, are not as off the scale as they appear when viewed in absolute numbers; for example, the wars of religion in early 17th century Europe were similarly deadly (relative to population), and the fifty-year periods at the end of the 19th and 20th centuries were more peaceful than any other periods in recorded history (when viewed relative to the population, i.e. looking at the chance of any given young man dying in war rather than in absolute numbers).Of course, WW1 and WW2 are, if exceptions, nonetheless pretty big ones. WW3, if it were ever to happen, would quite possibly be large enough to outdo the death rate of the Stone Age, while simultaneously sending us back to the Stone Age. Thus, it is worth looking at not only whether violence has subsided (it apparently has, albeit unevenly), but also at why it has subsided, in order to try to figure out how to get even better results.Here, Pinker's analysis is less impressive, in my opinion. His answer, more or less, is that violence has declined because of individualism, humanism, and technology. As we are able to read books that take another person's perspective, trade with people in other countries in mutually beneficial ways that would be disrupted if we went to war, and expand our mental circle of "those who deserve rights" to include other countries, women, children, other races, and even animals, we ended up less likely to view others as objects to be destroyed if we want.Well, sure. This seems, though, to be describing the result, rather than explaining it. It also doesn't do a whole lot to explain what would be the best way to help the process continue. As an example of this kind of weakness, Pinker's analysis of WW2 more or less subscribes to the idea that it wouldn't have happened if not for Hitler, or if it had would not have been as destructive. It's a result of Pinker's highly individualistic belief system that he has a hard time seeing the problem in 1930's Germany as being a system in which someone like Hitler could come to power, rather than Hitler himself. Personally, I think there were probably hundreds of anti-Semitic egomaniacs who could have understood how to use radio, film, and graphic arts to ride fascism to the top of the German power structure, if Hitler hadn't gotten there first. Radio, film, and modern color printing enable nationalistic propaganda to have a reach it hadn't before, and until the experience of the late 30's and early 40's had provided a vivid example of how badly that can go, any democracy in a deep economic depression would be vulnerable to takeover (which is why Mussolini popped up at around the same time). This doesn't jive well with Pinker's classic liberal philosophy, because it more or less puts the blame for fascism (and the wars that it caused) on technology and democracy (which both Mussolini and Hitler used on their way up, even though they eliminated it once in power), two of the things he wants to credit for a decline in war and violence generally.Pinker also avoids any credit to monotheistic religion for a decline in violence, preferring to quote some of the most violent and repugnant sections of the Old Testament (and there are plenty). Nonetheless, many historians would say that the Catholic Church had more of a pacifying effect on post-Roman Empire Europe than Pinker is ready to give it credit for, and the link between the rise of monotheism and the decline of human sacrifice is pretty hard to ignore (although Pinker manages to ignore it nonetheless). Pinker also wants to give partial credit for the long-term decline in violence to the spread of literacy (if you can read about the viewpoint of another, even if in a work of fiction, you are preparing your mind to sympathize with the viewpoint of others in real life). He avoids mentioning the obvious role of Protestantism and Islam in spreading literacy, in order to facilitate reading holy texts.Still, as a thorough survey of just how far we've come, it's a great work. Steven Pinker has clearly dug deeply into the topic, and it's one we have a need to understand the reality of, not just the impression recent headlines might give. In the end, despite the difficulty of reading the first few chapters, it is an optimistic book, and it leaves the reader inoculated against the pessimism that modern atrocities might otherwise bring up. Let us hope that a generation from now, a successor can write a book (or whatever the future equivalent will be) that explains not only how far we've come, but why, and how we managed to keep those positive trends going in the 21st century.
One of the best books I have ever read.

Skeptical as I was of the idea of progress in a moral sense, Steven Pinker convinced me that civilization really has progressed in terms of the way we treat each other. The book is really divided in two parts, first a historical study in which Pinker amasses enormous statistical detail to show that there has been a continual progression in the reduction of violence, and second a psychological study to unearth the causes, the constraints and the directions of this progression.Pinker’s erudition is overwhelming. The footnotes and bibliography reveal a breadth of study beyond what I could imagine one person could accomplish. I most enjoyed the historical part in which Pinker isolates six trends which have contributed to a less violent and more considerate society. The trends start with a 5000 year old trend, the move from raiding and feuding to agriculture and government, and move through more historically proximate trends toward three in the 20th and 21st centuries, namely the post-World-War-II peace, the Post-Cold-War world and the Rights movements. All six trends are exhaustively documented with an endless series of downward sloping graphs, all quite persuasively. I am a bit more skeptical of the more recent trends, since I have the feeling that what has developed in my lifetime could turn around in another lifetime. But I have become enormously grateful that I do not live in Medieval or Homeric times.The psychological study is less interesting to me because it puts more weight on controlled experiments in which human subjects (college students) are manipulated to reveal characteristics which promote or inhibit violence. The experiments are ingenious, but seem to me a lot less interesting than a discussion of social issues, or even talking with the subjects themselves about how they think. But there are still fascinating pieces, such as when Pinker discusses moral psychology, how people think about moral issues. He covers psychologists such as Jonathan Haidt who have written about how moral attitudes influence political viewpoints, and gives a comprehensive and unifying summary of the current state of the debate.Pinker is a cognitive scientist, but he also wears the hats of a linguist, of a neuroscientist and of an evolutionary psychologist. In addition, he is a very entertaining writer and has a good grasp of history, sociology and current cultural history. In short, he is a very well-educated man who has a wonderful ability to bring it all together and to offer a sound basis for a positive view of the future.

I'm afraid that if I were to mention all of the good things I had to say about this book my review would be as long as the book itself. Better Angels of Our Nature has the informational value of a textbook but Pinker's writing style can make you feel as though you're reading an enjoyable novel. This narrative of our violent past and much less violent present elicited in me feelings of vindication in some respects (I've never been too nostalgic about the past) and challenged me in others (broken glass policies have some strong evidence that would suggest they work). The mountain of knowledge that just rolled over my head has me struggling with how to apply what I've learned to my own life. Though the book seemed to be fashioned as a case for optimism, which it did inspire in me, I couldn't help feeling a bit pessimistic in light of the data as juxtaposed to where we find our current politics. Some findings from Pinker's analysis; Braggadocio leads to more war (Khrushchev and Kennedy independently noticed this and backed down rather than reduce civilization to a smoldering crater). Trade leads to peace as the two parties now have a vested interest in the other's well being for sake of profit. The general intelligence (apparently only a controversial concept outside of expert circles) of the president is strongly correlated to what bi-partisan historians rank as bad outcomes for the country(war, recession, strife). I am now sitting with these facts...On a happier note, it was interesting to learn of the evolutionary roots of violence. I was surprised to find out to what extent sex played a roll in human cruelty, although I shouldn't have been considering most things about us evolved to help us have sex, to keep us alive long enough to have sex, or to keep our offspring alive long enough to have sex. I wasn't surprised by which half of the species sex inspired violence in. While we're on the subject of inspiration. It was inspiring to see, in a very step-wise manner, how humanity has been making strides towards peacefulness and egalitarianism. I have a number of books that I always recommend when someone asks me what to read and this one just joined their ranks. 5+ stars.

An amazing and astonishing book, and one that I think that everyone should read. Although I have to admit I found the last few chapters a bit more of slog than the first several. Pinter expects people will have a hard time believing that violence has declined dramatically throughout history, and especially in recent decades; after all we hear about murders and wars and so on on the news all the time. So he spends the first several chapters going over all kinds of violence (wars, murder, rape, torture, witch hunts, genocide, etc.) and provides charts showing the decline in all of them throughout history, often with more detail on how they have declined recently. He also goes over why it's believed each kind of violence has declined. His tone is analytical and occasionally wry (when needed), since the sheer numbers of people who have suffered and died, and the few times when he gets into details (mostly in the chapter on torture; where he spells out what was standard procedure in most of Europe throughout much of its history) are truly horrifying. One statistic that stuck with me is that the rate of violent death in pre-historic groups (as figured from the remains we've found) was 15%, and that number is also characteristic of many hunter-gatherer cultures in recent history. Think about that; of every 100 people you know, 15 of them would die by violence. The murder rate in the US today is about 3 people per 100,000. The most boring, beige, suburban subdivision begins to look like the epitome of civilization, as indeed it is. The later chapters go into more depth on the reasons that violence has declined tremendously in the last few centuries, and especially the last sixty years. Pinter is not trying to say that violence will never go up again, or that it will ever totally disappear, but that by figuring out what ideas and movements have contributed to the decline of violence we can hopefully encourage those ideas, encourage peace and peacefulness, keep the rate of violence low and hopefully make it decline more.

Yes…. I looked forward to reading this book and was not disappointed.Personally when people start bitching about the new generation that are stuck in their electronics…. What will come out of them…. Etc… etc… I usually answer that the same was said about my generation, who grew up with TV's and rock music. But if you look at the world today, a world that is ruled by people of my generation, and compare it to the previous generations (that did not grow up with tv's and such), you see that the previous generations…. The ones that led the world to WW1 and WW2 were much worse and in general the world is a much better place today.This book basically argues that the level of violence is declining in the world, and specifically in the last 65 years has declined to rock bottom levels.The book discusses all topics of violence and describes them in all history (and prehistory) and shows with lots of detail, graphs and research that we are living in a golden era of nonviolence. Wars, crime, atrocities of governments against their own people and against other people, family violence, violence against women, violence against children, violence against minorities and more. There are pages of horror descriptions, be prepared.The author gives various reasons for the decline and is very persuasive.While reading it I was fascinated, and discussed the book with anyone who was ready to listen, and was really into it. It occupied my mind and ruled my thoughts.But the book is long…. And it goes on and on….. and repeats various points… and repeats again… and says the same thing in other words… and says the same words in other things….. Somewhere around chapter 8, is where I started losing him. From that stage, I skipped pages and skipped through the book.For that reason I give the book only 3 stars (probably would give 3.5 if I could). Somehow, I cannot give more to a book that I chose to skip most of the last third of the book.Still, I recommend it… but be prepared to skip (hold a skipping rope in your hands or something)

Pessimism is widespread these days - especially about the prospects for living in more peaceful world. And it is understandable, as we are bombarded with reports of murder, suicide bombings, armed conflicts, hate-crimes, and uprisings... and so much more.But is human nature - the way we treat each other on a global as well as individual scale - actually getting worse? Steven Pinker says no... and offers over 800 pages of content to support his claim that "believe it or not, today we may be living in the most peaceable era in our species' existence."Pinker has compiled massive amounts of data, taken from a wide range of sources, on all sorts of forms of human conflict and cruelty - ranging from international war and genocide to torture, rapes, infanticide, the abuse of animals, and more. And the outcome is that almost all the trends point in the same direction: downward.This is a massive book... as in 36 hours on audiobook and 800+ pages in print. But the size of the book is justified based on the huge subject that Pinker takes on, which is twofold: 1) Demonstrating that Violence has, indeed, declined over history. 2) Explaining why violence has declined over the course of history.I won't get into the arguments or data, because it's far too much to share here. But if this topic interests you then this book will provide you with some interesting thoughts that are well-supported. I'll just leave one of the final thoughts from the book here:"The forces of modernity - reason, science, humanism, individual rights - have not, of course, pushed steadily in one direction, nor will they ever bring about a utopia or end the frictions and hurts that come with being human. But on top of all the benefits that modernity has brought us in health, experience, and knowledge we can add its role in the reduction of violence."

In some ways this might be one of the most important books about Humanism and Enlightenment values ever written, because it charts, scientificallyand even mathematically, the trends that contribute to a quantifiably more peaceful world. Fearmongers would have us believe that the world is a worse place than it once was, but the truth is that the past, which featured slavery, genocides and torture beyond all reckoning, was much much worse. Even if we look at the terrors of modern American industrial military torture complexes, at least we have an active (though by no means sufficient) counter current calling the government out on its crimes.such a thing would be almost unimaginable during the time of the Inquisition.The book is exhaustive, in the sense that it is long and exhausting. It took me days to read, and I'm a pretty fast reader. Pinker is nothing if not thorough, providing fodder that most authors might spread over six books. The book is at times almost Evangelical in tone,as in "Have you heard the good news? The world is a whole lot better than you think it is, and trends show it getting better all the time!"The fact that the pacification of our worst excesses isn't obvious to us is possibly a good thing: it means that we still know that we have a lot more to accomplish towards making the world a better place. Identifying those trends that allow for pacification can give us insights as to how the levers of the world can be manipulated to accelerate the changes.Conversely, those who value the status quo might find themselves now able to put the brakes on the system.Pinker is quick to point out that these trends don't guarantee future peace and stability, or that there won't be more devastating terrorist attacks, wars, genocides or other atrocities. The trends point towards peace, for now.

I read a lot of depressing non-fiction books, so it is nice to read one that actually presents some of what is going well in the world, even if it is tempered with a fair amount of caution. Pinker presents a powerhouse of a book, with carefully nuanced arguments, tons of data, and extensive references to back it all up. As I like to do, I read several of the one star reviews of this book before writing my own, and I found that even with the most wordy of them, they presented no real solid refutations of the general ideas presented in this book. It was all complaining about Pinker not giving enough credit to one ideology or another, or giving to much. One reviewer said he hid the weaknesses of his data, which is ironic and utterly untrue, since he consistently discussed the weaknesses of any particular data set, and was very careful to explain how things could be over-interpreted, and what kinds of conclusions could not be drawn, even if they were tempting.One point Pinker made that stood out for me was "the pacification of the past", in which textbooks, museums, and I would argue, many people including many I know, pretend that the past was not as violent as it actually was. There is a tendency for many people to romanticize the past, and conjure up mythical portrayals of various older civilizations and societies. I see the same mentality around issues of racism, feminism, animal welfare, and many other subjects dear to progressive hearts. This book managed to give me a tiny bit more hope for humanity overall, not that I'm thinking it's going to be a rose garden. Just less bad than my usual pessimistic view. We are still fucking the environment, and I really don't think we'll deal with climate change until the consequences are deadly for very large numbers of people.So, yay?

The basic message: War, murder, rape, and torture have decreased dramatically over human history, and the only reason we don't realize it is because we lack the numerical context. The Better Angels of Our Nature is well worth a careful read. Dr. Pinker lays out the facts in extraordinary detail and depth interspersed with common sense sanity checks that leave no doubt--the world has improved. A lot. We're getting smarter, more civilized, less violent, and more compassionate.I wish I could give Better Angels five stars, but Dr. Pinker's grating rants against religion really detracted from the whole. For all the effort Dr. Pinker put into quantifying every other conceivable variable in the text, he makes no effort to calculate the number of lives religion has improved and saved versus the number who have been killed through its misuse. He does take a few paragraphs to address this issue by defining any benefit derived from religion as part of a larger social movement working in coalition with religion, and therefore not attributable to any positive effects of religion itself. Apparently Desmond Tutu's work against apartheid, Dr. Martin Luther King Junior's contributions to civil rights, and Mahatma Gandhi's nonviolent resistance had nothing to do with religious conviction. If you have a grudge against religion, it's very convenient to define religion's positive aspects out of your discussion, but it's not very conducive to logic.Edit: I've just read several negative reviews on this book. Most of them argue that Pinker's understanding of anthropology is flimsy at best and therefore calls into question most of his thesis. Anthropology is not my field, so I can't judge Pinker's accuracy. Another question to drive further reading.

The target market of this book are people who have done very well out of the capitalist system and are incentivised to remain in it. Bonus points for being a New Atheist. If this is you, do not read this review, just get the book and skim through it. You’ll have plenty of ammo to pat yourself on the back and sound interesting at your echo chamber parties and other social or digital events.If, however, you are looking for more than confirmation bias literature, you will be severely disappointed.Read Faruk Ahmet’s excellent review with which I wholeheartedly agree. My additional views in bullet points:* Pinker relishes in describing the details of torture throughout history, skillfully playing on the reader's emotions which makes the delivery of his dogma more effective* Intensive cherry-picking of facts and statistics that conform to his worldview, avoiding the other 99% of human existence through space and time* His logic goes as deep as: Marxism bad because Stalin, Mao and Pol Pot. The end* Use of biblical texts to prove how violent the past was, then throws all those events out the window saying they were probably fictitious* Miniscule evidence to show the violence of prehistoric times. Humans have an innate aggression because Our Lord and Prophet Thomas Hobbes says soIt is no surprise that Bill Gates gets a mild stiffy at the mention of this book, as do most other dinosaurs in need of a pat on the back as imperialist growth capitalism takes a slow slide down the shithole of history along with all the other unsustainable ideologies of the past.

Do you know what hemoclysm is? Or, what the difference between genocide, democide and policide is? If you don’t, it’s not necessarily a bad thing, and the good news is that they are all on the decline. Violence is on the decline on the whole, actually.It shouldn’t come as such a surprise because when you think of it we do live in a much more civilized time than ever before. Yet, it doesn’t feel that way every time we hear about an insane idiot killing schoolchildren or of other awful atrocities perpetrated somewhere in the world, so it’s nice to have it supported with numbers. Violence is on the decline across the board when numbers of crimes are calculated relative to the populations in which they occur.Regardless of its uplifting thesis, it is a difficult book to read. It is oppressive from time to time with all the minute analysis of violence and its research overkill. I felt oppressed by the amount of violence described and by all the ways people have caused harm to other people. But, it’s a wonderfully argued book, and Pinker cannot be accused of not having given enough proof to support his theses. It’s that sometimes it just feels there is too much of it. I loved the vindication of humanism, rationalism, democracy, feminism, human and animal rights, and old and boring Hobbesian political philosophy. It really is a superb book, but you don't know how glad I was when I finally finished it. It may be his best book so far though, and I thought nothing was going to beat Blank Slate.

One of my top 10 favorite books of all time and a perfect example of why I favor non-fiction. This book was thought-provoking, informative, and incredibly well-researched and has turned my perspective upside down. Steven Pinker has gathered a staggering amount of data to back up the assertions he makes (I wonder that he had the time to do the research required but he is a professor so one could guess that he has a gaggle of grad students doing his bidding). In addition to its other positive qualities the Better Angels of Our Nature was reassuring and left me with a feeling of optimism and a different perspective on the news. While I knew already that the news highlights the negative to grab our attention (and keep ratings high - see http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/29...) Steven Pinker has adjusted my perspective even more and I'm relieved to have a better picture of where humanity is headed. Here's his TED talk that's a good overview of the book http://www.ted.com/talks/steven_pinke.... There haven't been many books (especially non-fiction) that have left me with such a good feeling about humanity. And that's all based on the data he's presented, not just some twee happy ending. It's really a must-read.

Probably the best book that I've read this year so far. Really really long, but just fascinating to read about this topic. "In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul. And the Lord God took one of Adam's ribs, and made he a woman. And Adam called his wife's name Eve; because she was the mother of all living. And Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain. And she again bare his brother Abel. And Cain talked with Abel his brother: and it came to pass, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against Abel his brother, and slew him. With a world population of exactly four, that works out to a homicide rate of 25%, which is about a thousand times higher than the equivalent rates in Western countries today.""The counterpart of too much memory on the part of the victims is too little memory on the part of the perpetrators. On a visit to Japan in 1992, I bought a tourist guide that included a helpful timeline of Japanese history. There was an entry for the period of Taisho democracy from 1912 to 1926, and then there was an entry for the Osaka World's Fair in 1970. I guess nothing interesting happened in Japan in the years in between."

This book does show a decline in violence and particularly gruesome forms of execution worldwide, which is very interesting! That said, Pinker’s conclusions about why violence has declined are not convincing. The leviathan, the ‘free’ market, and the enlightenment are given the credit for the decline in violence, which is convenient for his world view. As an example of his narrow intellectual viewpoint, he briefly mentions self esteem and makes the false claim that people who commit violent crimes have too much of it. If he had bothered to look through the literature at all he’d know that violent criminals are notorious narcissists and that healthy self esteem is the exact opposite of narcissism. I’m appalled that he could so thoughtlessly spit out the Conservative party line on this issue, when programs to increase healthy self esteem are some of the most effective against violence, drug use and unwanted teenage pregnancy. A much more interesting look at the subject of declining violence comes from Lloyd DeMause (whom Pinker quotes several times). I recommend his work far above Pinker’s.As any student of climate change can tell you this is a finite zero sum world. Anyone telling you anything else is selling something, as indeed, Pinker is. He claims ideologies are the ultimate evil while faithfully attempting to bail out his own.

I'm not going to give this a long review as many others have. I thoroughly enjoyed most of this book, especially the retelling of our ancestors horrific past, and for my enjoyment alone it earned 4/5. Why not 5/5? For the many reasons already cited against the text. Is it possible to really tackle the fascinating history of violence (and it's apparent decline) by one person in one book? Frankly I think he should have taken a few more years to finish it, what would he have to say about the growing nationalism today, or the swearing in of America's least intelligent president? And even if people are less prone to creative methods of torture, don't they indulge in it just as much digitally? My biggest problem is that Pinker's main focus throughout the entire book is the Western world. He doesn't really engage with anything outside of it for longer than a sound bite, either because they lack the data necessary to make conclusions about or lack the data that supports his claims. Either way, the book is a narrow window into the world of bad behavior. For it's length, I wouldn't recommend it to most people uninterested in pulling the argument apart and looking at it piece by piece. This argument can be found condensed elsewhere -namely his TED talk, and I'm sure in other places as well. And to get the whole perspective of the topic, one should certainly peruse the one star reviews.

I can not do it. I can not and will not even try to endure the next 25 hours that Kindle says are needed to finish this book. No wonder Bill Gates likes it. It is so full of graphs, logarithm, bell curves, datasets, and all manner of things that are pulled together to make the case that the world is getting nicer. It is obvious to me that he has made a good case or there would not be as much talk about this book as there seems to be. The fact that we may be historically getting less violent is not a help to the people being killed in the middle east and the other places where tribes and groups are killing people. The death toll by gun violence in this country maybe statistically lower than it was fifty years ago according to adjustments for population but that does not make the grief for those killed any less. Because I have not read and will not read any more, I don't know if the argument is made that because we are now less violent, we can reduce our spending on military weapons? I doubt it. Because I have not completed his argument, I do not know what kind of conclusions he draws from this massive amount of research and statistic that he complied. It is more than I could endure.

This is a dangerous book with a pernicious premise. Pinker is clearly an anti-theist (not merely an atheist who doesn't believe in the divine, but one who is actively and militantly opposed to the idea of an absolute truth) who believes in humanism to the point he is willing to manipulate data to fit his worldview. He carelessly dismisses millennia of history as "myth" and claims there is no proof that the events in either the Old Testament or New Testament happened; that archeology never uncovered proof of Noah's flood (there is an entire museum with proof dedicated to the Flood in Kentucky) and archeologists cannot prove where Jericho was, but then uses archeology to back his claim that violence is on the decline. He should not be permitted to speak out of both sides of his mouth like this. Furthermore, he uses percentages to show his point. If an early tribe of 100 got into a fight and lost 30 people, that's 30%; catastrophic indeed! He compares this to WWII where the US, with a provable population of 350M, lost <2% of its population. Sure, that looks good by percentages, but 2% of 350M is 7M... a much higher number than 30 people in the tribal Indian Wars Pinker compares this to.

Considering the news reports about war, terrorism, and violent crime we hear and read every day, you wouldn't think we're living in an age which might be thought of as the most peaceful in history. But Steven Pinker writes convincingly that the incidence of violence of all kinds has been in decline for centuries, and particularly during the 2d half of the 20th century. Generally, Pinker attributes this to the blooming of liberalism and modern emphasis on political correctness. Societies are more right-thinking and are everywhere undergoing what he calls a civilizing process, a revolution in humanitarianism and a belief in the rights of individuals and groups. After writing about the psychological motivations for violence, Pinker covers comprehensively a history of it with heavy focus on the causes of war, the strong forces within societies which foster violence, and the increase in those human virtues, like empathy and reason, which are sharply reducing it. So Pinker's exhaustive study of violence and its decline moves from psychology to history to sociology to philosophy. I believe this may be an important book.

I couldn't get through more than about 80 pages of it because I disliked it so much. I question how he came up with some of the statistics but I never got to those statistics to understand how he came up with the numbers. While I think violence is likely declining in many ways due to the data I've seen, I don't know if it's declining to the extent that Pinker is claiming. I found the book incredibly depressing due to the way it was written and some of the author's views, despite the main theme of violence decreasing being positive. I also wonder about a bunch of historical claims he made as some of the violence formerly understood in ancient times is now being disputed with new evidence including by his own colleague at Harvard, William Ury. Again, I didn't finish the book so perhaps at some point these questions and seeming discrepancies were handled.

A work of alleged scholarship, whose methodological failures with all 'data' prior to circa 1850 is so incredibly astounding as to leave one with the impression that Pinker decided what his conclusion was and then went and cherry picked some 'facts' to support that thesis. Take some time to investigate the source of his data for, say, the Middle Ages. Does he cite any actual medieval historians? no. How about some primary sources? no. It's Barbara Tuchman (!) and some soi-disant 'historical atrocitologists'. Now I actually kind of like the argument in its purest form (that violence is declining), and it might just be possible to prove that point for the period after which reliable data is possible, but Pinker embarrasses himself by reaching beyond that period.

I was looking forward to reading this hoping for some good news but when I got to the part about gentle commerce my hairs started rising. Pinkers main evidence for a decrease in violence is that North America, Western and Central Europe have become increasingly less violent. He fails to adequately acknowledge that for over four centuries these countries have transferred their commerce to the colonies in decidedly ungentle ways, leaving a legacy of oppression, poverty and violence and then he continues to have the gall to suggest that if Africans hadn't deposed their colonial masters we wouldn't be so violent? Well f*** you Pinker and your over-simplified and ridiculous book, any reasonable arguments you might have made went out the window.

Liked the concept and I feel the premise has a lot of truth to it, however, after listening to the author stretch the truth for chapter after chapter I stopped reading. He never actually lied, he just distorted the meaning behind everything he was talking about. Anyone not versed in the history or passages from literature or scripture he was referring to wouldn't catch it right away. Example, he talks about Solomon and his threatening to cut the baby in half and states as a fact the king planned on actually cutting the baby in half even though the passage implies he knew the reaction of the true mother. He talks about sports as if they are designed to hurt people while never saying anything actually false, he distorts the truth with implications.

"Probably the best book I have ever read."The book changed the way I look at the world. I had false preconceptions about the changing nature of violence through out history and where we are today. The book opened my eyes to how we really are progressing better and gives me hope about the future. The book is probably the book that has changed my world view more than any other book. Pinker's "The Blank Slate" also changed my world view. That book also opened my eyes to the false preconceptions I had developed while growing up about man. And to show that I'm not a Pinker sycophant, I would just only moderately recommend Pinker's 'How the Mind Works".

Another well-known Canadian author elaborating on an attractive line of thought, another complete self-indulgent non-fiction failure. Pinker maintains as much intellectual honesty as I did writing high school history reports. Cherry-picking sources that support an idea, frequently instructing readers to ignore 'outliers' in his data such as the two world wards, and dismissing any contradicting arguments simply 'because' does not make for convincing writing. Certainly not worth anyone's time. 'I was happy to discover the result, not just because the theory of self-deception is so elegant that it deserves to be true, but because it offers a glimmer of hope for humanity.' (Location 10876)

I'm pretty sure the only reason why this book is so long is because the author likes to read his own words.I stopped reading this book soon after I began. I got to the part where the author is attempting to support his argument that modern warfare isn't as bad as past warfare by using a quote that explicitly describes body mutilation resulting from combat. Pretty sure body mutilation resulting from combat still happens and is still as horrific.Give me a no nonsense war book any day over this.

On principle I don’t usually reject reading material I disagree with, but a tactless attack on the foundation of the three major world religions led me to believe Pinker was already fighting his own ulterior crusade. You know he’s twisting the Bible for his own purposes when a nineteen-year-old college sophomore can dispute his interpretation. Not what I want from an author who’s in the process of explaining to me why the world is getting better.

He very conveniently ignores everything that happened in Iraq, and the Taliban in Afghanistan, what about the sex slave trade happening all over the world....he can say the world is peaceful all he wants, it's just as violent as ever and I think his theory of "a new code of ethics" is just bullshit. I think he missed the mark on this book

Couldn't get past the first few pages. I really tried. And not just because he calls the Bible crap. Cuz I wasn't interested enough to keep reading. I have it on my nook - may come back to it one day. Doubtful.

I was hoping to like this book despite not appreciating the author. I was annoyed right at the beginning with his contradictions and straw man approach to issues. I find him pompous and self-important.

It is hard to like or take seriously a book which has so many historical inaccuracies or contradictions. From the details of Henry VIII's wives to the dates when civilizations emerged, variously stated as 5000 or 10000 years ago, there are too many errors to believe the substance of the book.

Grossly injudicious and highly controversial reading of the Bible that then creates a dishonest argument. Provides prime evidence that when it comes to human history, academia engages in a whole lot of speculation.

Not going to comment much on this book, except to say that his thesis could have been far more persuasive if the book hadn't been so ambitious in trying to address every aspect of the subject he could think of. He presented a lot of statistical analysis that I wasn't sure was relevant.
I didn't finish the book.
Tedious. Includes graph straight from Wikipedia. Too bad, it is an interesting theory that deserves more attention.
Meat chauvinism? I'm tired of reading the author's prejudices dressed up as fact. Renew or throw? Throw.
Politically and historically illiterate. Flawed in its basic premise. Dont waste your time.
Too much in depth description of torture devices, I could not finish.
I did not manage to even finish this book. It was too heavy to read.

I will admit to being, generally, a Steven Pinker fan. His book The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature, which I read when I team-taught a course with a colleague in the psychology department, was my first introduction to evolutionary psychology. It affected me so much that it started me on a five-year reading binge that culminated in Useful Fictions: Evolution, Anxiety, and the Origins of Literature, my own book on evolution and literature. And I thought that How the Mind Works was even better. Even with this background in Pinker fandom, though, I was not prepared for how really good his newest book would be. It is a remarkably good book. It might even end up being an important book--a designation that I can give to very few books published in anybody's lifetime.In the strictest sense, The Better Angels of Our Nature is two books, or, at least, two book length arguments (at 800 pages, it can easily contain two book-length arguments with room to spare). The first and longest of the arguments is a data-driven, social-science argument that violence had indeed declined. In this, he is entirely persuasive. The second "book" is a cognitive, neuroscientific presentation of some of the possible reasons that violence has declined. Of necessity, this is a much more speculative argument, but Pinker acknowledges this to be the case.The first of these arguments, of course, lends itself to the question, "violence has decreased compared to what, over what period of time, and among which group(s) of people?" The answer, pretty much, is "all of them." But that takes a whole lot of explaining, which constitutes about 2/3 of the book. But most of this is statistical support. The actual arguments are fairly short:Violence has declined over the span of human evolutionThis is the anthropological argument, and it relies, admittedly, on some speculative data. We can estimate the number of hunter-gatherers who died violent deaths from a number of data points: trauma evident from fossilized remains, death rates among contemporary or recent hunter-gatherer tribes, behavior of closely related primate species. All of this is guesswork, but, taken together, it creates a reasonable case for saying that people alive at almost any point in recorded history have had a smaller chance of dying violently than most prehistoric and proto-human beings.The reason for the evolutionary decline = the rise of civilizations that grouped people into larger "in-groups" and decreased the number of people in the world who were your enemy.Both Interstate Warfare and cultural violence have declined over the past 500 years Pinker is able to draw on fairly substantial data sets that show that deaths from wars, homicides, raids, plunders and the like have dropped dramatically in the world--especially in Western Europe and America--from about 1500. We can trace, during this time, evolving standards of decency that have dramatically increased the perceived value of human life. In the middle ages, there were multiple engines of unimaginable cruelty: political torture, religious inquisition, aristocratic mischief, serfdom, slavery, etc. Gradually (and inconsistently), beginning in about 1500 and continuing to this day, certain categories of violence have decreased steadily as human beings just get more decent about a lot of stuff.The reasons for the historical decline: 1) The Enlightenment, which dramatically reduced things such as witch burning, inquisitioning, bear-baiting, cat-burning, peasant-torturing, slave-owning, religious warring, and all other manner of violence that ran amok in the pre-Enlightenment world. 2) The Leviathan State, which usually enforces laws against violence more or less effectively; 3) The rise of literacy, which allows people to read about and experience other people, leading to greater empathy for them.Interstate conflict over territory has decreased over the past 200 years Starting at the end of the Napoleonic Wars, there have been far fewer casualties from war than at any other time in history. This, of course, requires us to account for World War I and World War II, along with the Holocaust, and the various genocides of the 20th century. Pinker spends a lot of time talking about these issues and demonstrating that, even with these events included, deaths by violence have been trending downward since the beginning of the 19th century. Pinker presents strong evidence that the "famous" acts of cataclysmic violence of the 20th century are spikes in clearly identifiable downward trends resulting from things such as the end of slavery, the decolonization of the third world, and a growing hesitancy on the part of most (certainly not all) decision makers to engage in wars of conquest.Reasons for these declines: 1) The consolidation of state power into fewer and fewer countries that can actually fight each other; 2) Stronger international organizations that have created an international environment hostile to wars of conquest; 3) international trade relationships, which make people in other countries more valuable alive (as customers) than dead; and 4) an increase in the number of democratic governments, which are far less likely to initiate wars of conflict than other kinds of government.IWars of all kinds have decreased dramatically since the end of World War IIDespite all of the predictions for World War III, it never happened, and the Cold War ended with a whimper. There has not been a nuclear weapon used in a war since the close of World War II, and the actual number of interstate conflicts--along with the number of people dying in such conflicts--has flattened out to only a fraction of what they were for most of human history. Only a handful of interstate wars have happened since WWI (Iran-Iraq/Ethiopia-Etria/America-Korea/America-Vietnam/Russia-Afghanistan). Many other conflicts have been Civil Wars or colonial wars, but even these have decreased markedly.Reasons for these declines: 1) Nuclear weapons raised the potential cost of war to something higher than most countries were willing to pay; 2) US and USSR kept most of their allies in line during the Cold War; 3) Presence of international organizations, trade, and democratic governments decreased motivations for war; 4) the collapse of fascism in Western Europe and Communism in Eastern Europe removed from the world Utopian ideologies often used to justify massive amounts of violence.Since the 1950s, "rights revolutions" have decreased violence precipitously within statesThe second half of the 20th century has seen a rise in movements for civil rights, woman's rights, children's rights, and the rights of minorities, colonized people, and religious groups. We are very familiar with these revolutions in the United States and Western Europe, but they have been even more important in places like India, Japan, and some of the nations of Africa. These rights revolutions have been responsible for driving down (though obviously not eliminating) such categories of violence as spouse abuse, child abuse, gay bashing, lynching, and violence caused by rioting. Reasons for these declines: 1) More democracies have led to more diversity among decision makers; 2) more open societies have given oppressed groups a greater ability to influence political processes; 3) greater international pressure has pressured nations to improve their internal human rights; 4) Powerful communications technologies have introduced more and more people to each other, making it much more difficult to deny them rights.In sumI find Pinker's evidence to be more than compelling. I think that he more than meets any standard of proof for the assertion that "violence is declining"--everywhere, among everybody, for a whole lot of reasons. He clearly acknowledges that "declining" is not the same as "ending." And he clearly states that the decline is not guaranteed to continue. But, for now, the "better angels of our nature" (such as the human capacity for empathy, the will to cooperate, the ability to reason through conflicts, the ability to exercise self-control, and the desire to create a secure environment for ourselves and our families) seem to be emerging while the other angels (aggression, competition, the will to dominate, our massive biases towards our own perspective) seem to be losing the iron grip that they have generally had on our souls.The Better Angels of Our Nature confirms my own experience of the world and its people. Most people that I know (including myself) want to be good people. We like to think of ourselves as open-minded, compassionate, forgiving, open to other people, and willing to be a positive influence in the world and in our own communities. Most people I know (including myself) are also capable of being reprehensible, unreasonable, closed-minded, reactionary, aggressive jerks. And most people I know (including myself) could, under the right circumstances, become murderous thugs. One of the most important roles of local governments, nations, and international organizations is to organize society in such away that the good angels have a better chance of surfacing than the bad angels. Steven Pinker's marvelous new book is a good place to start learning how.

I think everyone involved in activism or politics (even to a minor extent) should be familiar with the concepts in this book; and if they have the time, they should read it themselves. Much of what you'll find in here goes against the common narratives or conventional wisdom you may have about the state of the world, and the state of humanity.The surprising, and important truth is: Things are getting better. Violence, in all its forms, is in decline, and has been for a long time. This book presents the amazing case that this is true, then explores the question: Why?It's good for us to acknowledge, and be grateful for, the incredible changes that have happened in the world. It puts our current problems in perspective, and makes the fight for a better world far more hopeful.But at the same time, it's crucial that we recognize there is no natural "arc of history bending towards justice". Continuing down this path is not our inevitable future. There are distinct causes of this pacification, and if these forces change or lose their power, we can easily revert into the extreme violence and cruelty of our past. (Such situations already exist, on small scales, in various pockets of the world.)What are those forces of pacification? The book describes and explains them in detail, but in a nutshell they are the following:1. "The Leviathan" - Whenever law, or a stronger, bigger force steps into a community (whether that be government, policing, or alliances/agreements between state powers), violence decreases. In other words: Anarchy is bad, people. Sorry.2. "Trade" - When two groups begin trading resources, the incentive to fight over those resources essentially disappears.3. "Feminization" - Societies that create better situations for women consistently have less violence. Giving more power and autonomy to women, even in small ways, tilt the culture away from runaway masculine aggression. Also, cultures that foster what we feminists call "toxic masculinity" (though not the term Pinker uses, it's the same thing) are more violent.4. "Expanding circles of empathy" - We evolved to care about people in our group, and to be apathetic to people outside our group. But the miracle of globalization is that what constitutes "our group" has been ever-increasing over the centuries. It began with novels, which allowed people to walk in the shoes of people very different from themselves, and continues today with the Internet, travel, and immigration. Our worldwide coldness towards "the other" is decreasing, because "the other" is becoming a smaller and smaller category.5. "Increase in reason" - Religion is not a force for peace. Sorry, the weight of history disproves that quite easily. Though sometimes ideologies like religion do move people towards peace and compassion, they have also been, arguably, the sources of our worst violence and cruelty. On the other hand, as ideas like humanism and liberalism (not the "leftist" kind, mind you) have spread, and education has cultivated our worldwide ability to think abstractly and rationally, many of the ridiculous, ideological forces of violence in the past have become unthinkable to us. (Note: #4 and #5 go hand in hand. If you have one without the other, you may not necessary see a decrease in violence. Strangely, even empathy can make us do terrible things - if it's a selective empathy, for instance - unless it is balanced with reason. And I don't think I need to explain how reason without empathy can be problematic.) We must guard and cultivate these forces with everything we have. Literal lives - and our future prosperity - depend on it.This book is, by all respects, a tome. But it's long because it's thorough in its research and evidence. If making the world a better place is something you care about, this should be a must-read. (At the very least, read a summarized version of it. ;D)

Steven Pinker is probably the best science populariser writing today, but to label him as just that does him a disservice. In The Better Angels of Our Nature he has possibly written the most important book of this type since The Selfish Gene was published back in the 1970s. I've read most of Pinker's stuff, The Language Instinct was complex and difficult, The Blank Slate reasoned and hard-edged, this is both of those things, but also, wonderfully and simply, filled with unalloyed good news.Pinker doesn't shout, scream or extemporise, he just diligently shares the evidence and his thinking about the topic in question and trusts that our reason will deliver us to the same place he's already arrived at. This book is a wonderful example of the acidic efficacy of a skeptical, forensic mind, carefully arguing an evidence-based point, the perfect antidote to the distressing herd instinct that afflicts much of humanity's thinking on a range of topics, but particularly that old bug-bear the state of the world today.There is no dewey-eyed naiveté here, this is a hard-nosed analysis of a complex topic, but it is laced with many, many reasons for optimism. What Steven Pinker explodes here is a powerful and horrific myth that stalks our lives and fills the media. We are bombarded in this age of instant news with depressing images of how difficult, violent and brutish life is, much of the underlying commentary and analysis offering a bleak perspective. The mantra basically runs that things are worse now than they have ever been (look at September 11, the war in Afghanistan, Syria, Egypt, the 7/7 bombings, the war in Iraq, the Mumbai shootings of 2008, in fact choose your violent cataclysm or social ill) or at the very least, it's not getting any better.Pinker simply asks the question; Okay, but let's look wider and deeper at the whole sweep of human history and see how those claims stand up. Are they right? From our small ant-sized perspective inside one human life-time we cannot possibly extrapolate from our particular experience, necessarily limited as it is, to the general situation for humanity over time. This books enables us to see so much further and gain more insight into the social development of our species.And what we discover is that something surprising and incredible has been happening quietly and relatively unnoticed for centuries. All kinds of violence have been slowly and steadily reducing over the course of human history. We are getting less violent and nicer to each other over time. Of course none of this takes away from the horror for the individuals suffering in the world today, but Pinker's point is that the horror and suffering we see today is very, very much lower than it was and if we can understand the forces of history that have delivered us relatively peaceful and benign societies in many, many parts of the world we can work to encourage those forces globally, supporting the better angels of our human nature to prevail over the more destructive ones.Nowadays in Western nations we live in some of the safest societies that have ever existed. Our chances of being murdered nowadays are astronomically small where for our forbears, before the rise of democracies, commerce and the feminization of social values the chances of witnessing violence or being a victim of it were almost everyday. The Daily Mail and Fox News and all those old folk huddled round the gas heater at the local nursing home reminiscing about how much better things were in the rose-tinted past are completely and utterly wrong. We kind of knew it really, but there is so much evidence to back up Pinker's hypothesis that the naysayers will have real trouble debunking it.I warn you it's a long book, a half hour reading on my Kindle rendered a reluctant advancement of 1% through the manuscript for example, but it is such an important book you need to read every word. Because this isn't just a claim that we are living through the least violent and most passive period of human history, it is a thorough-going account of the social and psychology forces that have produced this amazing miracle. It also offers clear notions and proscriptions for us and our societies about how we can foster the correct psychology and social environments that will continue this effect.If you read no other books this year, you should read this one as it offers a deep insight into the human condition in the past and how and why it has improved and still improves each and every day. Whilst not a cure to the philosophical cynicism of John Gray, this books certainly lands firmly on the "glass is half full" side of the argument.A resoundingly hopeful book, debunking the human-derived myth of the noble and glorious past we used to live when we were supposedly in harmony with nature. What we were was violent, racist, tribal and blood-thirsty. Genetically we are programmed to see "the other" as the enemy, a member of another tribe competing for our land, our reproductive rights, our food. However over hundreds of years through a process where we have gradually become more and more aware of each other and the suffering and experience of others, we have collectively began to empathise with that other and reduced our violence towards them as a result.The five forces Pinker says were central to this process of reducing violence are (source Wikipedia);The Leviathan - The rise of the modern nation-state and judiciary "with a monopoly on the legitimate use of force,” which “can defuse the [individual] temptation of exploitative attack, inhibit the impulse for revenge, and circumvent…self-serving biases.”Commerce - The rise of “technological progress [allowing] the exchange of goods and services over longer distances and larger groups of trading partners,” so that “other people become more valuable alive than dead” and “are less likely to become targets of demonization and dehumanization”;Feminization - Increasing respect for "the interests and values of women.”Cosmopolitanism - the rise of forces such as literacy, mobility, and mass media, which“can prompt people to take the perspectives of people unlike themselves and to expand their circle of sympathy to embrace them”;The Escalator of Reason - an “intensifying application of knowledge and rationality to human affairs,” which “can force people to recognize the futility of cycles of violence, to ramp down the privileging of their own interests over others’s, and to reframe violence as a problem to be solved rather than a contest to be won.”He also goes onto the detail our demons and our angels psychologically;Predatory or Instrumental Violence – that is, violence “deployed as a practical means to an end.”Dominance - The “urge for authority, prestige, glory, and power”; Pinker argues that dominance motivations can be found both on the individual level and on the level of “racial, ethnic, religious, or national groups.”Revenge - The “moralistic urge toward retribution, punishment, and justice.”Sadism - Violence caused by taking pleasure in another’s suffering.Ideology - A “shared belief system, usually involving a vision of utopia, that justifies unlimited violence in pursuit of unlimited good …”[2]FOUR BETTER ANGELS (Chapter 9) Pinker here examines four motives that “can orient [humans] away from violence and towards cooperation and altruism.” He identifies:Empathy - Which “prompts us to feel the pain of others and to align their interests with our own”;Self-Control - Which “allows us to anticipate the consequences of acting on our impulses and to inhibit them accordingly”;The Moral Sense - Which “sanctifies a set of norms and taboos that govern the interactions among people in a culture"; these sometimes decrease violence but can also increase it “when the norms are tribal, authoritarian, or puritanical”;Reason - Which “allows us to extract ourselves from our parochial vantage points.”A thoroughly informative and important book.***** Five stars, but be warned you'll be there a while but it is worth it because of the sheer sweep of his analysis and the depth with which he explores all of the issues.

Having finished reading this book, I can finally stop bothering my family, friends, and coworkers with every next fascinating argument it advances or study it references. I think my obsession with it is summed up particularly well early on, where Pinker explains the Hobbesian view that human beings are naturally violent and the Rousseauian perspective that they are naturally peaceful, basically concluding with "well, those are both compelling points that sound convincing; how are we to know which one is correct? Luckily, we have a bunch of information on this!" He tirelessly enumerates the facts of the history of violence to make the simple case that it has been in decline, both on the long view of the course of human history and even in the short term of the last few decades. He takes great care to note that many believe modern times are violent to an unprecedented degree, and his refutation of that claim benefits greatly from his dispassionate, factual approach. It doesn't really matter how sad you are when you read the news about the latest terror attack: the numbers betray the truth that people are killing each other at decreasing rates. I thought the first half was interesting enough, taking every conceivable angle at arguing the factual case that the numbers are going down. But the second half, trying to explain the psychology behind violence and understand some of the reasons that people may be engaging in it less, was even more so. Upon finishing this book, I find myself inspired to read more on the philosophers who got some things (though never everything) right, and to look at more of the objective statistics that can hedge against the myopia and bias inherent to any person's view. The phrase "standing on the shoulders of giants" keeps coming to mind as I read his references to Hobbes, Rousseau, Kant, Bacon, and others, revealing that the epiphanies of my own that I had thought so insightful were just reinventing centuries-old wheels. I have more appreciation than ever for the Enlightenment and the processes of debating and testing ideas to see whether or not they hold up, regardless of how well they agree with what I already thought. I would strongly recommend this book, both for the series of surprising conclusions it handily draws from a rich well of factual evidence and for the fascinating components of human nature it articulates over a long list of studies in the process of explaining our relationship with violence.

Only an inflated sense of our own importance could turn our desire to escape thePacifist’s Dilemma into a grand purpose of the cosmos. But the desire does seem to tapinto contingencies of the world that are not exactly physical, and so it is different from thedesires that were the mothers of other inventions such as refined sugar or central heating.The maddening structure of a Pacifist’s Dilemma is an abstract feature of reality. So is itsmost comprehensive solution, the interchangeability of perspectives, which is the principlebehind the Golden Rule and its equivalents that have been rediscovered in so many moraltraditions. Our cognitive processes have been struggling with these aspects of reality overthe course of our history, just as they have struggled with the laws of logic and geometryThough our escape from destructive contests is not a cosmic purpose, it is a humanpurpose. Defenders of religion have long claimed that in the absence of divine edicts,morality can never be grounded outside ourselves. People can pursue only selfishinterests, perhaps tweaked by taste or fashion, and are sentenced to lives of relativism andnihilism. We can now appreciate why this line of argument is mistaken. Discoveringearthly ways in which human beings can flourish, including stratagems to overcome thetragedy of the inherent appeal of aggression, should be purpose enough for anyone. It is agoal that is nobler than joining a celestial choir, melting into a cosmic spirit, or beingreincarnated into a higher life-form, because the goal can be justified to any fellow thinkerrather than being inculcated to arbitrary factions by charisma, tradition, or force. And thedata we have seen in this book show that it is a goal on which progress can be made—progress that is halting and incomplete, but unmistakable nonetheless.Yet while this planet has gone cycling on according to the fixed law of gravity, thatspecies has also found ways to bring the numbers down, and allow a greater and greaterproportion of humanity to live in peace and die of natural causes.For all the tribulations in our lives, for all the troubles that remain in the world, the decline of violence is an accomplishment we can savor, and an impetus to cherish the forces of civilization andenlightenment that made it possible.

This was my first Pinker. Apparently, he has a huge following, which I learned researching this book. I saw him on Colbert a long while back and added this to my to-read. I was very interested in the thesis that violence has decreased substantially over time and we're now living in the most peaceful time in the known history of our species.Generally, he proved his point. It's true. While it's not a patently peaceful time and things aren't perfect (to which he concedes) but it is a damn sight better than it ever has been.I especially enjoyed the "sanity check" at the beginning, in which he explores the rationality and horrific violence in the alleged basis of morality, religion. (It's alleged in that it's clear from the contemporary behavior of the followers that they follow modern principles of moral behavior rather than those proscribed in religious texts.) I also liked the chapters on violence against women, children, and gay people. It was really sobering to read how recently it was that the world mostly agreed that women and children are autonomous people deserving of dignity and not deserving of unbelievable violence.
