I always thought that laws going back pretty far in time that forbade rape was because, to some extent, I thought cultures thought rape was wrong--That it was a horrible violation of women. I thought maybe the laws had sexists bases, like women were helpless and needed patriarchal protection and that's why sometimes men murdered other men who raped. I was really surprised to learn that historically, rape was a tremendous crime against a man; raping a daughter or wife was to rob a father or husband of a precious commodity--the virginity or purity of the girl or woman in his possession. And that one of the only ways for a rapist to make what he did right by the men he offended was to offer a price for the raped woman. And that raped women lived out their lives with their rapists. Often.I was shocked at the history of violence against children and infanticide. That postpartum depression is not a malfunction, but an inborn device to remove the "rose-tinted view" of motherhood so that women could make hard decisions about the resources available to her for herself and her other children. So that she can decide if a new baby should live. My god. Postpartum depression commonly coincides with women whose lives are unsure and resources might be unreliable, so the mechanism kicks in after birth to help her do a cost-benefit analysis. So there's an evolutionary function to infanticide! And it was COMMON for so long.It was illuminating, but I have some criticisms: He speaks from an almost purely biological perspective and mostly avoids social perspectives. I know he's a scientist and I knew this book would be more oriented in the physical sciences, but I feel that whenever he encountered an opportunity for a social perspective (even a brief one), he'd avoid it for the most part. At times, it felt like he undervalued social issues and felt that biological ones were more important, applicable, and a better explanation for human behavior than social perspectives. In the section on rape, he did seem a little prickly about the suggestion that feminist movements have had a major role in the reduction of rape and other violence against women. I understand and agree that our culture "was ready for the change" and that when laws were passed to protect women and punish the men who beat, rape, and kill them, there were no riots, revolts, people beating down doors at city hall, and so forth (which is seen when government or society implements something for which its members are NOT ready) and that the violence toward and rape of women coincided with a GENERAL decline in ALL violence (suggesting the culture is becoming less violent on the whole), but it felt like he was undermining or devaluing the contributions of various movements and advocacy groups. He did give credit to the feminist movement for making it so that ultimately women had a voice in our government (voting) and held office and other positions of power and that overwhelmingly changed the way women were treated and regarded in our culture. So that's good. But it doesn't change that little sense I got from other comments in the book.Another thing that bugged me was the whole issue of rape. I totally agree that rape is not just "an act of power, not sex"--Sex plays a role in rape! Totally agree. But sometimes I felt he was being a little snide with things like saying when a frat guy hovers around a too-drunk coed, he's not thinking about reinstating a patriarchy. Maybe I'm too "politically correct" or sensitive or something, but it rubbed me the wrong way. I understand that I entered the reading of this from my very contemporary, very western paradigm, one that views most violence as so taboo that it is my cultural imperative to think, "Never okay, never justifiable, should never be tolerated" (especially in the cases of rape and infanticide) and I've recently been forced to flex that muscle. Flex it a LOT. Every Tuesday and Thursday, for a role-playing history class. We had to check our entire scientific paradigm at the door to win the game. We had to forget gravity, genes, cells, and every bit of common astronomy we've learned since childhood, including Earth's movement and the sun's position. I was impressed with my ability to manage this! And I understood reading this book that every age in every culture in every part of the world has its customs, mores, traditions, and taboos. To calm my socialized frontal lobe so that I can nod in understanding of why mothers in the 16th century commonly chunked their newborns into latrines, smothered them with pillows, or poisoned them with opium on the breast was a nice, good exercise of that muscle. But for me to accept only or MOSTLY biological, evolutionary explanations for everything and never or rarely social ones is asking a bit much. I know he didn't explicitly say that social issues are irrelevant in the matter of where we land as a culture--more violent or less violent. He didn't even imply that, but he did, in my opinion, somewhat undermine social factors. If we have always been biologically the same, then it stands to reason that society, the social business, has changed and led to this drastic reduction in violence over time. And instead of some comments to that effect at the end, acknowledgement (or at least not being blasé about it) throughout the entire book would've made it a more palatable read for me.I think the knowledge and hope that it's getting better everywhere is moving, amazes me, and assuages the occasional tendency to become morose about my fellow people. Good facts, good data.. I enjoyed it.

this book was painfully long, especially compared to the amount of stuff Pinker was trying to communicate (it could have been half the length! maybe two thirds the length). another issue is that the book felt somewhat racist and sexist and insensitive at points, like in the way Pinker characterizes islamic countries or talks about innate biologies or focuses on western civilizations or vilifies leftist ideologies. he does make other points throughout the book that suggest maybe this is not his entire persona, however, although I'm not sure if I should even be trusting someone who is associated with Epstein. the quality of the writing gets five stars - it is very good! and the depth with which Pinker discusses his topic and spells out his thesis is admirable. although I didn't like the part where he talked about specific brain parts and how it relates to human psychology (therefore convincing me that the medical field and psychology are not at all for me), it was a good addition to discuss the psychological science behind the statistics and historical theorizing that happens in the first half of the book. there is always the issue of using statistical methods and how well these analyses have been carried out, which may make or break his argument, especially with a lot of the war analysis. however, his idea that when you really reasonably think about it, violence in terms of war frequency, torture tactics, societal norms, and lots of other categories has decreased over many hundreds of years is both interesting and ultimately believable. a four star book demoted to three stars because I'm convinced Pinker is more closely associated with Epstein than he claims he is.

I agreed with the premise of the book before diving in. After eight weeks of reading, and traveling through a history of human violence across the globe, being hand-held through charts and led through study after study, I learned a lot more than just "We're not as violent as we used to be." I have always thought humans were always just sumbitches, and we haven't changed a bit. Turns out, we have. We are repulsed by things that were commonplace just a hundred years ago. Genocide unsettling? It's not new--but a revulsion to it is. That's just one example, though it's a pretty good one. If you're interested in human history and you're interested in being contrary on Facebook threads, this book will give you more ammunition than you even know what to do with. I plan to continue soaking this one in for a long time, and make an outline of its chapters while it's still fresh in my head. No, this isn't a great review, but it's a placeholder for a better one.

Brilliant for its scope and clarity. Almost seven hundred pages long, but tightly packed with citations, graphs and references. Throughout the book, Pinker underlines the assumptions behind his arguments, as well as the narrow bounds within which his conclusions hold. The effect is that Pinker makes the weak points of his arguments clear. There's little in the way of self-serving obfuscation here; this is not punditry.But despite that, Pinker's thesis is neither sexy nor politically palatable, and much of the pop criticism you'll find of this text (such as some of the one-star reviews here) don't target his arguments as much as insult him. Ignore all of this; I don't think there's much of value to find there.Other critics are more sophisticated. Most famously, Taleb. Be sure to read these criticisms (and Pinker's rebuttal).

The Better Angels of Our Nature makes the bold claim in its first pages that human violence has not only declined (in relative terms) throughout the modern era, but has done so in virtually every measurable category, from war, to homicide, to non-fatal acts of aggression, to punishment of crime, to attitudes about acceptable behavior. Like many readers, I suspect, my eyebrows went up a little. Really? What about the World Wars? The Holocaust and other genocides? Terrorism? Serial killers? All the horrible crimes on the news?However, armed with an abundance of statistics and historical anecdotes, Pinker makes a persuasive case that wars and mass exterminations, on average, really do kill fewer people than in the past, even taking into account the 20th century's major cataclysms (which he sees as exceptions to the overall trend). Other forms of aggression have also subsided considerably, the shocking events captured by the modern media notwithstanding. Pinker dispels the PC notion that man lived as a peaceful “noble savage” in pre-modern times, and provides a free-ranging tour of the history of violence, as understood by historians, economists, anthropologists, behavioral psychologists, primatologists, and evolutionary biologists. Few stones are left unturned in a quest to seek not only if and why violence has declined, but what causes human beings to be violent against each other in the first place.If you're wondering, Pinker attributes the decline to three major causes. One is the "Leviathan" proposed by Thomas Hobbes in the 17th Century, a state with the monopoly on the legitimate use of force. It seems intuitive to me that people would behave better towards each other when there’s a "parent" figure to mete out justice, forestalling the cycles of revenge that occur when humans seek their own justice, and Pinker makes compelling arguments that this is true. As centralized states with complex economies formed, it became an imperative to the ruling class to cut down on internecine warfare that disrupted its own interests, and aggression became a less rational choice to everyone else invested in the system, as well.Another major cause that Pinker identifies is a change in cultural attitudes. As certain forms of oppression, violence, or cruelty became unacceptable, this put pressure on others. The formation of "rights" in a society, not surprisingly, opens the door to other rights, as the progressive-minded call attention to inconsistencies in social or political norms. Then there was the rise in humanitarian empathy that followed widespread literacy, when novels such as Uncle Tom’s Cabin made it easier for people to step into the shoes of those outside their own circles.While this is a somewhat long book, I was never bored with the wealth of detail. Pinker goes out of his way to anticipate opposing positions and respond to them. While I didn't agree with his reasoning on everything and was skeptical of some data points, I felt that he drew in enough support from different places to make an overall convincing case. He also gets credit for not playing too strongly to contemporary politics. While he's writing from the left and takes positions that are bound to annoy a few conservatives (e.g. we're overreacting to terrorism and Iran, medieval Christian churches tortured heretics out of genuine commitment to their faith), he goes after "politically correct" orthodoxies as well. For instance, he criticizes the view that "nurture" matters a lot more than "nature", goes after the notion that people behave aggressively because of low self-esteem (bullies are acting out natural dominance behavior and tend to have a high opinion of themselves), and observes that sadism is unfortunately not a “perversion”, but a product of normal human tendencies that kick in when emotional counterbalances are removed.I particularly enjoyed the last section of the book, which explores the psychological and evolutionary motives for violence, as well as aspects of human nature that resist it. In exploring the “demons”, Pinker considers game theory, dominance behavior, alliance forming, our natural bias towards seeing our own bad behavior and that of others in very different light, and our unconscious tendency to go along with the crowd. If you aren’t already familiar with the implications of famous social psychology experiments, such as Stanley Milgram’s frightening demonstration of the human instinct for blind obedience, you will (and should) be. In the “angels’” corner are moral instincts, rationality, and empathy, which are explained in terms of the findings of other experiments. Fascinating stuff, if you're curious about how human behavior "works".All in all, an absorbing, meaty book that gave me plenty to think about, and made me feel profoundly grateful to be living in the civilized 21st century. However, Pinker leaves it ambiguous what his lessons might imply for the future, and I found myself still in possession of several big worries. What will happen as we face continued economic turmoil? Increasingly intelligent (and job-taking) machines? Global climate change? If nothing else, though, I feel assured that the people alive today are better equipped to peacefully respond to serious systemic threats than any generation that came before.

This is the most insightful book I have ever read. The author destroys countless myths about the idolised past and does so with empirical evidence at every step. The author demonstrates how violence is partially driven by the qualities embedded by evolution, how it can be understood through the lense of the Prisoner’s dilemma and how various historical developments can modify the payoffs of the dilemma matrix to make peace a more attractive solution. Most importantly, the author abolishes the notion of pure evil and shows how every average human being is capable of inflicting harm motivated by predation, dominance, revenge, ideology or even sadism.The book starts with a number of chapters reviewing the history of violence - from never ending wars in Homeric Greece to cruel punishments in the Middle Ages to wars and genocides of the 20th century. The author discusses how, regardless of common perceptions, the world has gradually become more and more peaceful. The book then moves on to discuss the inner demons and the better angels - psychological qualities that push humans towards or away from violence. The author then summarises the consistent reduction of violence throughout centuries by suggesting the pacifying elements that include the emergence of the Leviathan, feminisation, trade, and increase of emphaty and reason.This book is huge - 841 pages - but it is worth every page and by the time I finished, I wished the author had expanded more on the implications of the reduction of violence and potential future developments.
One of the most significant books I have ever read.

I've never read such a long book that could be summarized so easily, and yet still be a fascinating read. Bottom line is that violence has been decreasing worldwide for centuries. Right now is the most peaceful time humanity has ever experienced. And that is awesome.

Steven Pinker’s The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined is hands down the best non-fiction book that I’ve read in my life. It has completely changed the way I see the world.How much this book will change your perspective on life depends on (1) your prior beliefs and (2) whether or not Pinker’s arguments convince you. I think my prior beliefs about violence were probably about the same as your average, middle-class, American adult. I worried about violence in a general sense, although I’ve luckily not been a victim of violence myself. I worried about events like 9/11, the American wars in the Middle East, school shootings, the civil war in Syria, rapes in India, acid attacks, and practices like female genital mutilation. It seemed like every day, there was yet another news report of another atrocious event to be concerned about.And then, I read this book and my entire perspective changed. Pinker argues that despite the news reports and what the media may lead you to believe, we are in fact living in a time of unprecedented peace and that violence has significantly declined. And his argument is overwhelmingly compelling, for he uses nearly every tool and angle at his disposal. Using common knowledge facts, historical texts, literature, and statistics, he examines numerous measures of violence, including wars, murder rates, attitudes, and rape. Looking at violence in every which way possible, the conclusion is undeniable – violence has declined significantly and yes, we are indeed living in a time of unprecedented peace.The decline of violence is not necessarily an inevitable one; there are forces that contribute to its decline, and Pinker goes ahead to examine all the different possible reasons for the decline. His search for answers is most comprehensive. He explores the Hobbesian theory of the Leviathan, government structure, literacy, technology, economics, social norms, and even evolution. The strength of each contributor to the decline of violence varies significantly (for me, the Leviathan being the strongest and evolution being the weakest), and Pinker readily acknowledges the strengths and weakness of his arguments. But I appreciate Pinker’s willingness to discuss a potential contributing factor even if the evidence is not strong.I most admire the comprehensiveness of this book. In today’s academic world, it seems that scholars have become perhaps too specialized. English professors explain the world through only literature. Economists, only through economics. Psychologists, only though psychology. And even within a discipline, each scholar, it seems, just wants to find that ONE thing to explain a big idea. Their thesis gets boiled down to one factor. For example, take the idea that talent is overrated, you should spend 10,000 hours practicing to be an expert. It’s boiled down to just 10,000 hours. Or even take the idea of democracy as being the one solution to all society's ills. American policy has tried to force democracy into the Middle East, as if this ONE thing that could solve everything. And, how well has that worked out for us?This tendency to boil the solution to big problems down to one idea is a byproduct of not just increasing specialization, but also a byproduct of the scientific method, in which only one variable is studied at a time, and perhaps of scientists’ desire to find the one unifying theory of the universe. And so, we are bombarded with advice and policies that hinge on just one thing, when in fact, the real answers are much more complicated. And in this book, Steven Pinker proves that he is not afraid to get his hands messy with complicated answers.In addition to changing my perspective on the world, this book also had another profound effect on me – it made me stand in awe of the human race. Reading this book made me feel very small in the way you feel small when lying on your back in the grassy countryside looking up at the stars. The world is so vast, so amazing, and so much larger than me. I am merely one tiny spec in human history. Just a grain of sand on the vast beach, subject to the ebb and flow of the tide.Despite all my praises, the book does have a large gaping hole when it comes to Asia. For the most part, the history of violence in Asia is largely ignored. I don’t know much about Chinese history, but I do know that it too was fraught with great violence. The fact that Sun Tzu’s “The Art of War” is a famous Chinese text utilized over centuries must say something about the violence in China, and yet, that is completely neglected.All in all, I highly recommend this book. Indeed, it is a long read and not an easy one at that. But I think it’s worth your while.

The Better Angels of Our Nature is a systematic, detailed study of the decline of violence in modern human history. I initially picked up this book because Bill Gates recommended it as the most optimistic book he's ever read, and also because I immensely enjoyed The Blank Slate, another one of Pinker's works. Many causes of the decline in violence are identified by Pinker, including:1. The rise of the modern state, or Hobbes' Leviathan. Interestingly, Pinker cites studies which seem to statistically demonstrate that the imposition of a state with a monopoly on violence does in fact reduce violence. Part of this results from the fact that people do not feel the need to "self-help justice."2. A long cultural change in the 11th through the 17th centuries in which European norms evolved to curb base desires and to anticipate the long term consequences of ones' actions. 3. The rise of commerce and trade in which the Prisoners' Dilemma faced by stateless individuals and warring societies gave way to positive-sum situations which incentivized stability of transactions through the decline of violence.4. The feminization of leadership. Wars are fought overwhelmingly by men, and it appears that the elevation of women in public life (in areas such as voting and public leadership) has had a positive impact in reducing the amount of aggregate violence inflicted by individuals and societies.5. The widespread improvement in abstract reasoning. The Flynn effect seems to have measured the steady rise in the ability of individuals to manipulate and think logically about concepts from multiple angles. The rise in abstract reasoning seems to also correlate with respect for democracy and rule of law, two other ideologies with strong norms against arbitrary violence.Ultimately, the book is a bit long and at times overly pedantic. Pinker seems to revel in showering the reader with all the knowledge he's accumulated and all the research he's done in writing this book. However, in doing so he does do a great job of giving the reader an exhaustive treatment of his thesis.

I have read this book slowly and carefully over a long period of time. I give it an unreservedly positive review.Warning: I am only an "expert" in a tiny area of what the book covers, and a layman in most of the rest.I will discuss two things that I liked most about the book: the way in which it is written (both large scale organization and specific wording), and the ambitious scope in pursuing this material.Vis-a-vis how the book is written:Pinker is a persuasive writer who marshals his arguments well, presents a variety of points of view on each topic, and is clear enough that I was never confused about who is making what point, nor was I confused about the overall logic and Pinker's conclusion. He also points out carefully where the "established research" ends and his opinion begins.He also makes the story lively with interesting (but never confusing) ways of turning phrases, and with cultural references both to icons of his own time (Bob Dylan, Woody Allen) and to great thinkers of the past. With his references he sometimes renders the mood of the times he is discussing, as when he inserts Mr. Jones into a discussion of what people were trying to understand in the 1960s. Other times he illustrates an idea from a research result by quoting a Woody Allen passage about sex, or a St. Augustine passage about temptation.The use of language is rather full, as is the assumption about a "framework knowledge" of political and intellectual history. When something more specialized is required he explains it, often very well. I was particularly impressed by how he explained poisson statistics and power law distributions when discussing the statistics of war. The explanation was accessible to someone who has never studied those concepts in a math or science class.The result is an enjoyable read and deeply instructive about many subjects, even beyond the main topic of the book.Vis-a-vis the ambitious scope in pursuing this material:What struck me the most about this book is that Pinker is not at all lazy. He never cuts corners in how he explores material. If a certain argument needs to be made with some knowledge of statistical distributions, he will introduce all of material and then make the argument. When he turns from a more historical arena to a psychological one he introduces the relevant psychology and brain-physiology knowledge. I never got the impression that I was supposed to take any aspect of the argument on faith.Another part of the "no laziness" is that he consistently offers up a variety of arguments on each topic. I never got the impression that he presented his favorite argument and then one devil's advocate argument pro-forma. I felt like I was always given the full picture of the debate surrounding any topic. Sometimes a debate is inconclusive, or the "pretty" explanations don't capture the full complexity, and in those cases he rolls up his sleeves and says "with no single explanation we will need to examine how several separate factors contribute to this phenomenon" - one example is the increase in violence in North America from the 1960s to the early 1990s.I also found interesting and important the way he brings in the intellectual aspects of history. Cesare Beccaria and Immanuel Kant and many other thinkers are shown to have had a big impact on the development of ideas. He taps into other philosophers, such as Thomas Hobbes, to show the origin of crucial insights in how aspects of societies evolve. He presents a convincing picture that the maturation of ideas is an important part of history, specifically how people and governments decide to wage war and to allow or disallow violence.Pinker also discusses the development of taboos in societies, returning to it when he discusses individual psychological factors.THe "no laziness" I observed was inspiring, reminding me of some of my scientific collaborators (not all of them, sadly) who truly complete projects rather than getting a "minimum publishable unit".I strongly recommend this book to anyone interested in the topic (the history of violence, both warfare and crime). If you feel that you do not have some of the background to read it comfortably, you might look at some books I have discussed on goodreads - accessible history books:* The Way of the World: From the Dawn of Civilizations to the Eve of the Twenty-first Century* Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind* A History of Western Philosophy
This classic from Steven Pinker is his most influential book! Why violence had declined and why doomsday narrative about our world is misguided?
My favourite book, will be sending a copy to my friends

I read many great non-fiction books, but this is one of only a handful I'd single out as being a truly important book. The kind of book that presents a new way of thinking or looking at the world that might actually make the world a better place. Bill Gates called it one of the most important books he's ever read, and I'd add it to that category as well. I give it five stars for this, resisting the urge to dock it a star for being so large and difficult to read. It took me a year of off-and-on reading to make my way through the 830+ pages, but it was worth the effort.Steven Pinker's message in writing Better Angels is to demonstrate that the world is, in fact, becoming more peaceful over time. The decline of violence holds over pretty much any measure of conflict between human beings: from war, to torture, to homicide, domestic abuse, rape, and even schoolyard bullying. This strikes many as counter-intuitive, or worse - dismissive of current suffering in the world. The latter concern is expressed by people who have not read the book, because Pinker makes it abundantly clear that there is still a long ways to go in reducing violence. Many find the message counter-intuitive because of two factors that Pinker addresses: availability bias and forgetfulness of the past. The availability bias points to our 24-hour news cycle and the worldwide trumpeting of any act of violence. There are more people than ever, and proportionately fewer instances of violence, but we get to hear about almost all of them. Each of us can immediately call to mind recent conflicts and violent outbreaks all across the world. At the same time, we forget just how violent the world was in the past: public lynchings, coliseum battles, inquisitorial torture, duels, honor killings, and other formerly banal expressions of violence. We remember only a handful of recent wars and forget the bulk of constant fighting that stretches into the immemorial past. And yes, to the common question, his analysis takes into account the brutally efficient World Wars. Even with those considered, and our current conflicts around the world, we are enjoying the longest stretch of peace that human kind has ever seen.Pinker exerts a monumental amount of effort in pulling together statistics from numerous sources - there are plentiful graphs to be parsed, and the reader will rapidly become adept at thinking of of violence in the terms of statisticians and demographers: incidents per 100,000 people. Using this metric, we see all the ways that modern historians have tried to extrapolate into the past the levels of conflict, and this research is painstakingly reproduced in the book. He goes so far to support his points that the reading can, at times, become rather tedious and repetitive. Pinker also provides abundant documentation and flavorful accounts of just how scary it could be to live in centuries past, sometimes veering into the macabre and disgusting. This is important, however, to drive home the point of how far things have progressed before laying out the processes and tools that have made that progress possible. Among these are the Pacification Process, the Civilizing Process, the role of the Leviathan (centralized government replacing chiefdom and serfdom), the Humanitarian Revolution, The Rights Revolutions, and various aspects of human nature. Conversely, he points to the various aspects of human nature that propel us to violence, and how we have come to check those urges in the construction of modern society. To summarize these factors would make for a very long review, so I'll simply encourage you to read the book.While many might point to various parts of the world that still engage in tribal warfare, honor killings, witch hunts, female genital mutilation, and a whole host of other abhorrent practices, it is worth noting that these pockets of violence are shrinking, and that there now exists many places that are free or nearly free of those fears. Those sanctuaries did not exist in the past. Also, if things were not improving, we'd have to ask what the point has been of promoting representative government, rights of speech, press and assembly, and all the other hallmarks of modern society. This is some confirmation that those efforts are paying off. Pinker's synthesis underlined a sentiment that I'd long held, and it was enlightening and encouraging to see the wealth of evidence he had amassed to drive the point home.

If you watch/read/listen to the news, it's hard to believe that violence has significantly declined over time, but that's the premise of this book. And, he backs up this idea with looooooots of information. He addresses the cognitive biases that make us think the world is falling apart and refutes them with data.

In his lauded but controversial best-seller The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature, Steven Pinker set out to quash a romanticized nostalgia for the lifestyle of people in pre-state societies: the myth of the "noble savage". Now, in his new book "The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined", Steven Pinker extends this rectification of prevailing but misguided opinion to grand scale, presenting a strong case for our ennobled present; we are living in the most peaceful era humanity has ever known.Pinker blows the reader away (forgive the violent metaphor) with sheer weight of analytical shot. At 700 pages of text interspersed with graphs and heaps of reference data, "Better Angels" is thorough-going and methodical because it has to be; contradicting common folk theories (like the noble savage), overriding an often overwhelming sense of unceasing or imminent violence from media coverage (see compassion fatigue), and compensating for a general lack of statistical thinking and probabilistic understanding in the lay public is no easy task. People are right to be skeptical of controversial theories, and knowing this Pinker has patiently lain it all out for us to see for ourselves that violence truly has declined with clear and unambiguously downward direction."Better Angels" is structured around an inventory of six Trends, five Inner Demons with four Better Angels, and five Historical Forces (Pinker can't help but enumerate). More than half of the book is dedicated to a chronological exploration of the Trends of our history, six paradigm shifts in the human condition: The Pacification Process, The Civilizing Process​, The Humanitarian Revolution, The Long Peace, The New Peace, and The Rights Revolutions. The bulk of the remaining half of the text is a fascinating look at psychology and sociology, showcasing a combined total of nine human traits (the Better Angels & Inner Demons) that dictate our behavior depending on their interplay with our environment and circumstance. The last five items in Pinker's syllabus, the five Historical Forces, feature in the concluding chapter and encapsulate much of the book's overall content by reflecting combinations of historical trend and human trait.The Five Major Historical Forces for Peace:The Leviathan (the state; reigns in internal violence)Gentle Commerce (economic incentives for cooperation)Feminization (empowerment of women; men are naturally more violent)The Expanding Circle (empathy; sympathizing with ever wider classes)The Escalator of Reason (rationality; application of empathy)A few minor quibbles with value judgments aside, "The Better Angels of Our Nature" assiduously justifies its subtitular contention: violence really has declined, and now it's not so hard to see why. Steven Pinker has assembled vast quantities of data to support his position, sourced in turn by the assemblies of other preeminent scholars in ethnography, anthropology, and the history of man. Add to this a trove of lab-tested social psychology, game theory, and the areas of Pinker's own expertise in cognitive psychology. The resulting dissertation, structured with the incredible skill and forethought that define Steven Pinker's books, sums these component analyses into the rational juggernaut needed to upend the conventional wisdom it is up against. Though consistently dispassionate in tone and bearing throughout, the title of this book betrays its emotional impact: optimism for humanity.( Note: a longer version of this review that expands on the 5 historical forces can be read here: http://www.thoughtskipper.com/2011/10... )

A brilliant book by the great Steve Pinker that makes the startling -- and encouraging -- claim that not only is the world today more peaceful than in previous generations, it is VASTLY more peaceful. Orders of magnitude more peaceful.The real meat of the book is in the first half, in which he brings an impressive amount of data to bear in elucidating four historical trends that each brought violence down by an order of magnitude: the Pacification Process (the coalescence of small tribes into larger societies) the Civilizing Process (the creation of the nation-state -- Hobbes' Leviathan -- and it's imposition of law and order), the Humanitarian Revolution (in which the rights of the individual begin to supersede those of the state, and the power of the state becomes limited) and the Rights Revolution (the most recent, in which those traditionally denied full social status are finally accorded full rights). Along the way he discusses many forms of violence, including state suppression, warfare, genocide, and small-scale crime, and shows that all are dropping. He also discusses the two blemishes on the 20th century, the two World Wars, and argues that they are statistical outliers on a line that is trending downward. He makes the startling point that though the World Wars were unbelievably bloody, they are neither historically unprecedented nor, amazingly, historically particularly extreme when the number of casualties is normalized by the total world population -- the European Wars of Religion following the Reformation in the 16th century were far worse!Unfortunately the book hits a brick wall about halfway through. This is when Pinker, having moved off of the historical data, delves into the neuroscience, psychology and morality of violence (e.g. what goes on in the mind of the criminal when he inflicts violence). Worse than merely being slow (and it is) this entire stretch of the book merely feels irrelevant. Practically no attempt is made to tie these areas to the historical data (how COULD you connect the abundance of testosterone, or the deficit of a neurotransmitter to the decline in murder rates in the US since the 90s?) and the relation between the two is just sort of ... implied. It feels more or less like we are suddenly plunged into different book altogether, and a book which presents its data somewhat incoherently and certainly less convincingly. If I could, I would give that book 3 stars.But the rest is so good, so eye-opening, that I still have to give it a 5. Maybe the best indicator of the book's quality is that it simply changed my mind about something: in the section on the "Rights Revolution", Pinker talks about the Animal Rights movement, the anti-bullying movement and a few other modern anti-violence initiatives. I want not to come off as horribly insensitive, but when it comes to certain social crusades (and Animal Rights is an example) I have found myself thinking thoughts like "yes, okay, it's not great that animals are abused in such-and-such a way, but really, don't we have bigger fish to fry?" And even with bullying, a certain part of me has thought boys-will-be-boyish thoughts. After all, to previous generations, our collective experience of violence would seem laughable. Wouldn't it?It would, but that IS the point. The only reason that we have gotten where we have is because of a rising intolerance of violence, because activists at the forefront have found previously laughable offenses suddenly merely offensive. So even if abused animals may not seem like the biggest problem in the world, making even that violence unacceptable plays a role in creating a future world where ALL violence is.

This is a long and complicated work to try to summarize succinctly, but here are my thoughts. First of all, thank goodness Pinker did all the research for me--and a lot of research there was. He makes a very convincing argument for why violence has declined over time, and the reasons he eventually surmises for this decline are surprising and refreshingly obvious. That said, my opinion is that, if one were to partake in more than a tourist's journey through the history of violence, one could absolutely not stop here. This book is a mere overview, and Pinker comes at the subject from a very particular perspective. He is very much the scientist-social-scientist analyst, very good at creating and interpreting graphs and numbers, and that can come at the expense of a more humanitarian lens on the subject. I appreciated his lightness of tone most of the time (especially in a book that could have been quite heavy), but at others I felt it bordered on flippant. And here are a few issues I take with his scholarship and point of view:-There is a certain lack of perspective about the context of violence or the lack of violence. For example, in talking about the decline in violent crime rates in the 1990's, after it had boomed in the '60's-80's, he credits policing and other "civilizing" methods as having made a difference. While I do not question his logic there, I would question his logic that incarceration and police violence somehow don't factor into the rates. While a high incarceration rate may "reduce" violent crime in a given society, incarceration itself implies and involves a certain kind of violence, and is certainly visited disproportionately on particular populations, such as young black men.-Ladies, brace yourself for Pinker's short-and-sweet chapter on rape. Watch him try to essentialize men (and women, to a lesser extent) by appealing to their "evolutionary" nature. Watch him try to explain that, obviously, rape is about sex and not power. It is not pretty. I cringed bodily many times. That is not to say that women are treated unkindly in most of the book. Overall, he is fairly pro-woman, just ignorant about feminist scholarship and especially rape.-As many other Goodreaders have commented, this is an overwhelmingly Western history. To be fair, he tries honestly to include figures for Africa, Pre-Columbian America, Oceania, and parts of Asia, and he even specifically addresses the dearth of information about the history of violence in most of the world. But one is left with the distinct feeling that there are more numbers and stories out there than Pinker cared to drum up. -Pinker plays off both sides of the political spectrum, and every part of that spectrum will find something to get mad at him about in this book. Anarchists and other radical leftists will undoubtedly disagree with his theories about the roles of democracy and "gentle commerce" in the decline of violence. Conservatives will balk at his vilification of "manly virtues" and cultures of honor, as well as his explicit endorsement of the "feminization" of culture to reduce violence. Readers must come at this book with an open mind and an ability to see multiple perspectives.Overall, a worthwhile read, but I would edit it back about 300 pages to get at the meat of the argument. Pinker is very thorough, examining every possibility within every dataset to come to his conclusions, at the cost of conciseness. But, that said, this book is never boring, and Pinker's tone keeps it light.

The Better Angels of Our Nature is Steven Pinker's attempt to articulate if violence among humans has indeed declined. I thought it would make a great read in this centenary of the Great War and provide a counter-point to all the doomsayers who relish in pointing out humankind's penchant for violence. Pinker's specialty is linguistics and psychology so it was odd to see him tackling something so steeped in history and politics.I think Pinker did a commendable job. Although there is a whiff of selective bias throughout the book when he presents data and statistics, overall the book is very readable and makes some very good points.Each of the chapters could make books in themselves. The earlier ones dealing with violence in pre-state societies sounds like the data is a little bit inflated to forcefully make Pinker's point. Undeniably, we know too little about these societies. But it is undeniable that homicide rate (which correlates with other crime rates according to Pinker) has gone down in the last five hundred years in the West where the data are pretty solid. Another chapter deals with the decline in behaviours such as slavery, torture, adulteress-stoning and even bloody pastimes not involving humans such as bear-bating and cat burning. Pinker credits both the growth of powerful states and national governments and the growth of Enlightenment Humanism for this astonishing turnaround.The next few chapters are slightly controversial and deal with violence decline among states. Pinker states that the 20th Century has not been the bloodiest time in record (despite overall body count being the highest, as a percentage it was not the highest). Pinker then throws some stats around that show that after the bloodletting of the two world wars, wars between great powers has declined (actually nil) and hence there is an overall decrease in body-count. Another history chapter deals with the "New Peace", a phenomenon where other conflicts such as civil wars and deaths due to terrorism has also decreased. Some nightmare scenarios such as bio-warfare and nuclear terrorism are briefly discussed so Pinker is not dismissed as prattling fool. The last history chapter deals with the Rights Revolution and how feminism and rights for racial and sexual minorities, and even animals have played their own roles in the decline of violence.The final two chapters deal with the psychology of violence. The first, as Pinker calls it about our inner demons (dominance, sadism etc.) and another with our better angels (empathy, reason etc.) I found some of the neuro-science to be hard going and too jargon-laden but the impacts and inferences to be clear and well written.Overall the book was eye-opening and interesting to read. However I can't shake of the feeling that it could have perhaps been vastly condensed by removing many repetitions and restatements. Also, another book, even by a non-specialist but such a well respected and good writer cannot be a bad thing. The Better Angels of Our Nature is highly recommended to everybody.

This is a good book, despite a few flaws, but it is nowhere near as fascinating as the response to it.Pinker's claim is pretty straightforward: that the amount of violence in the world has been decreasing over time, both generally and also within specific categories (war, homicide, etc). It is presented empirically with lots of data and graphs showing the decline over time. Of course, plenty of the data is questionable. Records are patchy at best going back to Roman times and before that it is mostly conjecture. Plus, there's always going to be debate about whether pre-civilisation peoples were Hobbesian brutes or Rousseauian innocents; we can extrapolate from data but we'll never really know without a time machine. Also, Pinker does quite a bit of cherry picking. He has no choice, given that his dataset is all people who have ever lived in the entire world.All that said, it is an empirical claim. It is wrong or it is right. Proving it wrong is simply a matter of proving that there used to be less violence, or that the amount of violence has remained constant. Instead, people have this deep, visceral reaction to the very notion. How can someone possibly claim that after [the Holocaust/Allepo/Isis/whatever has recently upset you] that the world is becoming more peaceful? Is he mad? Engaging with his analysis would be an affront to decency! You can read through the one-star reviews here on Goodreads for a selection of lengthy outraged essays on this topic. I don't think people are even particularly engaged by the content of the book, although it contains plenty to offend. Lefties will be outraged at the colonial overtones of his philosophy, while right-wingers will lose their minds at the idea that the feminization of society is a positive thing; both will freak out at the unfashionable idea of the Leviathan-type state being a force for good in the world. I think the real problem these days is that everyone is invested in a narrative of struggle, suffering and entropy, and anything that contradicts that narrative causes profound cognitive dissonance. The world can't possibly be getting better because you just need to look out your window to see it's getting worse. Most arguments against Pinker, even those with citations, seem to be starting from that principle and working backwards.One thing Pinker doesn't have a chart for is general levels of optimism over time. I'm pretty sure, however, that if you had stats on that, you would find that almost everybody at almost every point in time has had the feeling that the world is heading to hell in a handbasket and the human race is doomed. Despite this, things generally seem to sort themselves out over time. What a curious planet.

O. K., I'm convinced: violence has declined. The descriptions of medieval torture, the decline of torture generally, and the murder rates in the medieval world versus murder rates just a few hundred years later, convinced me. What was less convincing was why violence has declined. In fact, it's not clear that Pinker really has an explanation himself, even though that's the subtitle of the book. To me, it's clearly related to the general rise in standard of living. In the closing chapter of the book, he dismisses this idea after considering it briefly. My answer would be that a rise in the standard of living is a necessary, though not sufficient, condition for the decline in violence. Once you have a higher standard of living, that allows for literacy, democracy, communication, education, and all that other good stuff to kick in. There's also a slight problem here which I don't think Pinker is fully aware of. This explanation really only concerns violence between humans. Violence between humans and the nonhuman world has clearly increased since the development of agriculture. I conceive of violence broadly as any kind of destructive or manipulative force, not just the causing of suffering. In fact, it has clearly increased just between humans and animals. Domesticated mammals were likely less than 1% of all mammals at the beginning of agriculture (just dogs, basically). They are greater than 90% today. The same thing applies to wild animals, since they are also affected by human activity which crowds them out. In fact, based on Craig Dilworth's book Too Smart for Our Own Good: The Ecological Predicament of Humankind, we can say more generally that violence between humans has declined just as violence between humans and animals has increased. The other possible problem is how he deals with Stalin. I think his estimate of the deaths due to Stalin is quite high; and his attribution of these to "ideology" and to the ideology of communism specifically, rather than to Stalin specifically, is in my opinion false. But that's another argument for another day.

For anyone that follows the news, it's hard not to feel like the world is going to hell. This book is a wake up call from that negative perspective. It's not an optimistic book, but rather one of analytical research & data that shows the global trend for violence is downwards. The most interesting part of the book for me is how it doesn't spend much time on the fact that violence went down, but rather how and why it went down, and why we are still noticing pockets of violence in many parts of the world.The biggest takeaway for me was something known as the "Circle of Empathy", which makes a lot of sense. The Circle of Empathy, basically means that people have a circle of people that they care about, who they identify as being similar to them, and generally they care more about those people than people outside of that circle. I noticed personally that this concept is very true, as I have come across many people that discriminate, who always find something different about the person they are discriminating, and nearly all of the time they have no close family or friends that fall in that circle. The decline in violence therefore is a direct result of that circle expanding, but how long does it expand for? For example, should it stop at all human beings or continue to animals as well?Another nice thought that has stuck with me is the analysis given on the prevalence of violence in the Arab / Muslim world compared to Western Europe and East Asia. I really liked how the book talked about how censoring ideas and people from each other perpetuates violence, and how one of the biggest factors that contributed to the decline of the Islamic golden age was the banning of the printing press for a few hundred years. I also thought the correlation between women's rights and violence was interesting, which showed that the more feminine a culture is, or the more it empowers women, the less violent it is overall (given other factors constant). Finally, I liked that although the book has cold hard facts in it and presents its case very scientifically, it gives you reason to be hopeful in the future of mankind.

I placed this book on my shelf more than a year or so ago. At the time, I had just read through Michael Shermer's Moral Arc. It spoke on much of the same topics addressed in Better Angels (recognition and expansion of human rights, decline of violence, causes of evil, economics and wealth, etc) but was a much more concise read. I took it up at the time because I wanted something that would give me a general view of the overall topic: that of an expanding moral universe. Plus, I didn't want to yet invest the time in reading a book nearly 700 pages in length (sans citations and references).If I had known about the quality of Steven Pinker's writing at that time, I don't think I would have gone down the same path. The book contains a generous amount of data and research to support claims that humans, over time, have become more ethical beings whom have learned to curb, though not entirely eradicate, the worst of our tendencies with the process accelerated by the 17th century Enlightenment values of Reason and Humanism. Subjects such as the decline of warfare, the pacification effect, the Rights revolutions (women's rights, gay rights, animal rights and more), life expectancy and others are discussed as well as their proximate causes (the rise in intelligence/abstract-thinking, recognition of our human nature and the applications of our institutions to direct or curb its effects) . The book makes a compelling case for the idea of human ethical and moral progress over time. A major plus of the book was how it mostly avoided unnecessary didacticism and was able to get it's points across in an easy-to-understand fashion. The book was long but it was a read that exposed me to ideas that triggered a fascination to understand them. I couldn't put it down once I got started.I just met Steven Pinker last evening at an event promoting his latest book, Enlightenment Now, which is an expansion built off the ideas discussed in Better Angels. It's a read I'm very much looking forward to and one that, I would argue, is an important read to give us context as a people as to where we've been, what we have accomplished and what we still have to do.

It was not difficult for Steven Pinker to convince me, a classicist who teaches about the violent societies of Ancient Greece and Rome, that we quite possibly live in the most peaceful time our planet has ever seen. I already know better than to glorify the past as the good old days. What I didn't expect from this book, however, was such a convincing, thoroughly researched case that would teach me so many new things about such a variety of topics.The amount of research and the thoroughness with which Pinker covers the subject of violence is staggering. I often stopped reading so that I could consider just how much information I was holding in my hands. This book examines violence from the cataclysmic clashes between civilizations all the way down to kids playing dodgeball at recess. No form of violence visited upon one person by another is overlooked, and Pinker systematically leads you through the evidence of its decline.Beyond that, Pinker also digs into the how and why of violence's decline. He presents fascinating experiments done by social psychologists that illuminate our human nature, and he explains both our immense capacity and tendency toward violence as well as the faculties we humans possess to overcome it. I especially learned a lot about how human morality operates and was surprised to discover how my own demons and better angels duke it out in my everyday life.At nearly 700 pages of text, readers should expect to spend some quality time with this book, and because of the book's wide range of topics, different readers will find different sections more or less fascinating (and sometimes, more or less of a slog). But Pinker's style is straightforward and readable. If you keep a pen in hand and take some time to consider what you're reading, there is so much important information here on the human condition. Having finished the book, I am filled with a sense of gratitude, not only for the peaceful time and place in which I exist, but for scholars like Pinker who help me see the world and myself more clearly.

This massive book is so full of the most extraordinary data and insights that I think it is probably one of the best books I have ever read. It certainly met the criteria of changing my mind on a whole array of issues, not least the massive decline in killing per 100,000 of the population from hunter gatherers right through up to today. Hunter gatherers can kill up to 1500 of their number per 100,000 per year. Even 20th century Germany and Russia managed around 100 per 100,000 per year. And today most of Western Europe and the Northern states of the US manage 1 per 100,000 per year. And the US as a whole has fallen from 10 per 100,000 in the early 90s to 5 today. And along with this long term decline in killing has been a parallel fall in other forms of violence.The book is a detailed, data and evidence backed working through of the detail of this trend and its causes. In Pinker's view the fundamental causes of the decline are five: 1) Hobbes Leviathan: the power of the state to enforce the rule of law by the threat of force 2) Gentle commerce: trade builds non-violent connections that make violent seizure pointless 3)Feminization: greater power and influence for women especially over reproductive decisions changes the nature of society towards avoiding violent conflict 4)The Expanding Circle: our ability to include an ever larger proportion of humanity beyond our immediate circle, tribe, religion or nation in moral consideration 5)The escalator of reason: as our powers of reasoning grow we seem able to go beyond violence based Prisoner's Dilemma and see the rationality of cooperation.It will take me a lot of further study to absorb all of this. But based on my own field of study: conflict, his arguments and data sets are profoundly convincing. So I most strongly recommend reading this book.

I read this book a while ago and am fascinated to see the level of controversy which it seems to cause.I found it fascinating in both premise and execution. Any book of this scale, however well written, will be tough going. Graph after graph, often using exponential scales sweeping down from left to right can be repetitive but they do serve to ram home some key points.Looking at the detractors. Of course he is cherry picking the data to prove his core premise. Everyone does that. But he's managed to find an awful lot of data.He tries (but many people don't want to listen) to point out that he isn't saying that the world is perfect and that violence is a problem of the past. There is still misery and violence everywhere, but that shouldn't be used dogmatically to knock down anyone who tries to suggest that things may not be as bad as they once were."Pinker is talking rubbish. Look at what happened just last week in ...." is not a reasoned argument.However, what he does say (I believe) is that:- in many, many areas of global society death rates by violence have been reducing.- as this happens, our standards and expectations for what is acceptable shift- the overwhelming presence of the global media (social, print and broadcast) distorts our perceptions and magnifies bad news.All we need to take away from this book (in my opinion again) is that we can make the world better, man is not inherently evil, and, if we can ignore the incessant chatter of the media for a moment or two, we might be able to identify some of the things that we have been doing right and learn from them.This is my first review on Goodreads (apart from my own novel) and I am surprised that I chose a non-fiction book. I would guess that I read 99.5% fiction.

In previous books Pinker revealed himself to be a proponent and supporter of traditional Enlightenment ideas. This continues in his latest work in which he attempts to demonstrate that violence has declined and he places the responsibility on mass literacy, individual autonomy and primacy of reason. In short, secular humanism. He begins by outlining evidence that demonstrates a decline in violence. Although for anyone who has studied history this outline of past violence is hardly necessary, he makes the case better than anyone could expect. Once he established a decline in violence, he looks for the cause. The first step was a state monopoly on violence and hence the decline of tribalism and "honor" societies. Again this isn't a terribly radical idea but its only the start. From there he proposes a civilizing process -- table manners, decline in dueling, jousting etc - which culminates in the Enlightenment. Reason, autonomy and a literate society naturally progress to greater humanitarianism and human rights, that is a widening circle of empathy. Finally, he credits democracy and international trade -- the traditional classical liberalism combination. With feminism, gay rights and animals rights he believes this decline will continue. As a pessimist, I can't share his optimism. Statistically we have reached declining returns -- ie how much lower can we go? Secondly and probably more importantly active literacy has declined and society has moved from democracy to a governance based on fear. These developments don't bode well for the development of empathy and a respect of individual autonomy.

I chose this book as I wanted an uplifting one. However talking about declining violence drives the author to start with examples of brutal acts performed by men in the past, to the point that it might get hard to keep going. Later the book goes into statistics, psychology, intelligence and wraps everything up in the way I wanted originally.I am now more hopeful about the future and just sadden that I won't be around for the next few centuries to live in a less violent world.

Pinker says this book came out of his answer to the question, "what are you hopeful about?" It details the history of violence in human society from prehistory to the present day. Pinker argues that violence has generally declined, and offers an explanation of how this happened.He describes a political/sociological theory called "Leviathan" in which the government has a monopoly on the legitimate use of violence. Under a Leviathan people are better off letting the state handle punishment than taking matters into their own hands. I think of this as rule of law verses a culture of revenge.Another sociological/cultural trend Pinker credits with a reduction in violence is the expanding moral sphere which has grown in historical times to encompass all races, both sexes, and even non-human animals.He describes a psychological phenomena called the "moralization gap" whereby we forgive ourselves more easily than we forgive others. The human mind, argues Pinker, has evolved to spot unfairness and misbehavior committed by others against the self, while maintaining a blind spot for the same behavior oneself commits against others.This book is a must-read for scientific skeptics and humanists.

A tour de force from brain scientist Steven Pinker, who amasses a tonnage of evidence to prove an unlikely thesis -- that violence, rather than increasing with the mass murders and world wars of the 20th century, has actually been on the decline -- not just since the Middle Ages, but since the more ancient times of the Bible and probably before that. More startling, our present era from 2000 on -- the Iraq war, 911 and the Sudan and Syria notwithstanding -- are the most peaceful in world history. Certainly Europe, for so long such a blood-soaked continent, has never been so free of organized violence. Given how often we see people murdered in TV dramas and how often bloody crimes are highlighted in the news, these findings come as a shock. Pinker knows this, and part of the fun of reading this huge work is the way he punctures our assumptions.For those of us who were born just after the Holocaust and grew up under the threat of mushroom clouds during the Cold War, this book is a provocation -- you mean to tell me that the human race is improving? Pinker shows that, yeah, it is.

Let me preface this by saying that I have given five stars to 75% of the I've reviewed over the past few days. This warrants an excuse. To me, five stars means "if everyone in the world read this book, the world would be a better place." It's been a good summer for reading. Reading this book will leave you with:-certainty that violence has declined. -an appreciation for democracy-a rational love of literacy beyond what teachers usually instill. -a desire to cultivate self control-countless interesting and mind-boggling social experiments.-a review of psychology, literature, manners, history and sociology synthesized for the purpose of understanding violence, which is tangibly important. -a more enlightened view of race as well as a sanity check on some radical positions from the past. -an explanation for why liberals are more intelligent (!).The book offers far more than the cover gives away. If you've ever heard Pinker speak, you know he isn't famous for his lectures. This book was written by a master.

Incredible. There are books that come along and completely change the way you see the world. This is one of those books. It is a big subject, and epic in scope. It's hard to even believe how well Pinker tackles this subject. There are a lot of conclusions that he draws that make me feel uncomfortable (pointing out how state authority and gentle commerce can reduce violence, two things that feel uncomfortable to me with my romanticized view of anarcho-syndicalism), but that's what good books do: they present evidence that makes you see the world differently.I also recommend reading published criticisms of this book. The ones I have read have turned out to be largely unfounded. It is interesting how this thesis can create this knee-jerk reaction in people: "How dare you suggest we are living in a great time for violence?"He does not tackle whether our current time is the best time by other measures (ecology, for example), so don't let that get you down. He chose one topic, a massive and fascinating one, and did an incredible job tackling it. Bravo.

Not in agreement with everything Pinker said in this book and in full aknowledgement of the fact that the data reported is mostly on Western countries (due to a lack of it from other countries and probably also to prove a point), I still consider this work to be a huge effort on the part of the author, and a succesful one at that. If you were to give a reasonably educated neophyte in the field of human violence one book that could relatively comprehensively explore the field, this would be it. The whole reason of the book is that human violence has been declining steadily - and lately, pretty abruptly - and the author provides a huge ammount of data from an incredible array of fields in order to convince the reader. Just thinking about how long it must've taken Pinker to compile all of this gives me flashbacks to University work that I'd rather forget. To anyone interested in homo sapiens and our tendency to go bat shit crazy, this is a book for you. You might even be a little hopeful for our future by the end of it.

OH.MY.GOD. I can't believe I finally finished reading this book. I feel like I have been reading it for forever. I know that my family, who has been listening to me ramble ad nauseam about this book, feels like I have been at it for forever. Everything I have encountered in the last few months - movies, news stories, tv, music, etc - seems to relate back in some way to this book.I could write a book about this book. I learned so much about so many different topics. I've been keeping a journal on books I read - defining words/terms I don't know, writing interesting quotes, jotting done questions raised etc. - and I kept a ridiculous amount of notes for this book. Pinker has a very in-depth section of notes, references & an index but I still also googled certain things that came up that I wanted to know more about. Lots of going down the rabbit hole where looking up one event or person led to another and another and another.I don't even know how to go about reviewing this book. It covers so much ground and so thoroughly. Really, you have to just read it yourself. Yes, it's definitely a commitment. It's a long, dense book but it's worth the effort to read.I will randomly revisit a few topics in the book that struck me as being particularly noteworthy. There are 5 types of violence in the world: predatory - a means to an end, like killing someone for the money in their wallet, revenge - retribution for a perceived wrong/punishing someone, sadism - taking pleasure in another's suffering, dominance - the urge for power & glory and finally ideology -a belief system that justifies violence in the pursuit of the good.Certain homicide patterns remain consistent throughout the last 2,000 years. Men kill 92% of the time(except infanticide where women take the lead). Men usually kill in their 20s. Until the 1960's, cities were safer than the countryside.The emotion of disgust evolved as an unconscious defense against biological contamination.Witchcraft was the most common motive for revenge in Europe in the Middle Ages. Something bad happened and you can't figure out why? Sorcery! Usually by that neighbor you don't like!The two most violent centuries in the Europe in the past 500 years were the 20th century(no duh, the two WW's) and the 17th century. Those religious wars were no joke. Basically Europe was at war from 152o-1648. Ah, the good ol' days!In England in 1822, there were over 200 offenses that you could be executed for. By 1861, there were 4. Also, until 1800, you could legally execute a 7 year old. Then the death penalty was raised to 14. During the Tang Dynasty in China, there was an 8 year rebellion called the An Lushan Revolt. 2/3 of the population died. TWO THIRDS. That was 1/6 of the world population back then.The Golden Arches theory: no 2 countries with a McDonalds have ever fought against each other in a war. LOLThere have been A LOT of horrific human customs that are no longer normal. The process goes from the behavior being normal/unexceptional(Hey Fred, let's go down to the village square later and watch the breaking on the wheel. It's gonna be fun!) - to the controversial -(They are breaking someone on the wheel today but that's probably not an ok thing to do) - to the immoral (It is wrong to tie someone to a wheel & then break all their limbs & thread the broken limbs through the wheel spokes & then leave them on the wheel to slowly die as birds peak at their wounds) - to the unthinkable - (of course breaking someone on the wheel is illegal) - to the not even thought about (Breaking on the Wheel? What's that? A new Netflix show?)Prerequisites for a country being less violent - a competent government, a competent police force & dependable infrastructure for commerce."To kill millions, you need an ideology." - SolzhenitsynThe word genocide was not created until 1944.Ideology/GenocideChristianity: The Crusades The Wars of ReligionNationalism: The Balkans Ottoman TurkeyNazism: The HolocaustMarxism: Stalin's purges Mao's Great Leap Forward Pol Pot's uh...batshit craziness? Kill everyone who wears glasses etc.Revolutionary Romanticism: French TerrorTerrorism is a tactic NOT the ideologyWhy are Muslim countries more prone to violence? Because there is a lack of separation between religion and state. There is no distinction between the secular and the sacred so they never went through an Age of Reason/Enlightenment or Humanitarian Revolution.In the West, there were 5 vulnerable classes that used to fall outside the circle of protection and not have any rights - women, non-whites, homosexuals, children & animals.In 1975, it was legal in ALL 50 US STATES for a man to rape his wife. It wasn't a crime. It was considered "impossible" - like accusing a man of stealing his own property.The FBI only started tracking hate crimes in 1996.Animals used to be dissected ALIVE because they had no soul so hey, no biggie."I have never killed a man but I have read many obituaries with great pleasure." - Clarence Darrow.Psychopaths are 1-3% of the population. They commit 50% of the most serious crimes(murder, rape)The majority of people will hurt a stranger against their own inclinations if it is seen as part of society's legitimate projects. "I was just doing my job."Does reading fiction make people more empathetic or are empathetic people more likely to read fiction?Morality is both the disease and the cure.Most sacred values are pseudo sacred and can be induced to compromise.What is the root of the American culture wars? Both sides think they have the moral high ground because they are following different conceptions of morality. It's not that one side is evil and one side is good. Both are good as defined by the morality they follow.The decrease in the sophistication of presidential debates is the product of an increase in the sophistication of political strategists.

plenty to disagree with, but the clarity of argument and breadth of evidence is stunning. value over article form is (1) have to read it to feel the weight of the evidence, and (2) there are a million of interesting tangents into areas of social science and psychology research.takeaways:1 - violence has declined in almost every meaningful way: pacification processes (leviathan), civilizing process (reduced interpersonal violence), humanitarian revolution, long peace (less and less violent war), new peace (less civil war and less terorism), rights revolution2 - reduction in violence is a triumph of the better angels of our nature (empathy, self-control, moral sense, reason) over our inner drives towards violence (dominance, predatory, ideological, revenge, sadism)3 - core driving factors are: strengthened state, increased commerce, women's empowerment, escalator of reason, and expanding circle of empathy

Mo-nu-men-tal.I literally can't imagine what could have been added to it. Pinker analyses the violence (in historical context) in all possible dimensions (social, political, genetic, scientific, cultural, organizational, ...) - keeping in mind how enormous (in terms of content) the book is, it's still hard to believe that it succeeds in avoiding being repetitive AND it's actually very interesting to read. I have to admit that during last 10-15% I was already tired (with the topic), but that's because I was a bit overwhelmed & needed something else (other topic) to switch to.The best thing about this book that violence in fact is just a starting point - that leads you to many interesting thoughts & conclusions regarding the development of humans & societies overall (over the ages).Recommended. It's not a book for everyone, but if you're interested in behavioural psychology, how human interactions work, how people do think & (re-)act, this is a must read.

I decided not to read this after all. The writing in the first chapter is wonderful, so I really wanted to. I especially liked the section on the violence in the Old Testament! :) But when I got to the second chapter, in which Pinker talks about anthropological history, it was moving too fast. I have just read Douglas Fry's The Human Potential for Peace, which is a very careful, detailed, scholarly book. Because of Fry's book, I realize that the anthropological evidence regarding the violence of our hunter-gatherer ancestors is not clear and obvious. But Pinker breezes through it superficially, at break neck speed, with no regard for the controversies and subtleties in the field. Which makes for "easy" reading, but I just don't have sufficient trust in the book to invest the time in its approximately 700 pages.

It really does help to zoom back a little and see the brush strokes of history writ large. This very well researched book lays out that facts that the general bend of history IS towards less violence and a more peaceful existence. We live longer, healthier lives and are much less prone to be felled by an act of violence. Of course this gives little solace to the victims of violence, but helps one put in perspective the constant carnival barking of the news media selling doom. That said, I have to admit I didn't finish the book. Somewhere passed the midway point the work got a little too bogged down with statistics and one antidote after another so I put it down, and tried to pick it up again a few times, never quite getting to the end. But I do believe I have a fair grasp of his argument, and I do believe it provides a very important point of view for our times.

Luke Skywalker: "I am looking for a great warrior."Yoda: "Great warrior! Wars not make one great."Yoda uncovers a major underlying assumption that Steven Pinker has highlighted across the chapters. For time immemorial humans have attached myths like honour and concepts like greatness to violent victories. One needs grit to go through the incredibly gruesome details of cruelty that humans have been inflicting on each other to this date. You want it or not, once you go through it you would feel empathy for not just other humans but for any living being capable of suffering. You may choose to ignore the positive picture that Pinker paints. However, in this age of rising nationalism, religiosity, orthodoxy and chauvinism, we must definitely find some time to read at least a few excerpts from this book.

This book gave me many of those moments in which one's perspective toward a given issue or subject alters significantly. I'll never view in the same way such subjects as the role of liberal humanism in the human rights revolution, the evolutionary functions of violence, dominance behaviors as an evolutionary adaptation yet as maladaptive in contemporary society, Nazism as anti-intellectual backlash, tribalism, racism, globalism and trade as pacifying factors, the counterculture movements of the sixties and seventies, Hobbesian government as solution to anarchic feuding, game theory, etc etc. While I'm not certain I can agree with Pinker on every single point, I found it difficult to cogently dispute any of his assertions, so well did he argue them, and so interwoven-ly did he weave them.

If the news is getting you down, this is the book to read. Steven Pinker presents a thorough and convincing case that violence is at its lowest point in human history.
