It feels hard to believe, amid the common mass shootings in the United States, the turmoil in the Middle East and Africa, and so on, but violence in every category--murder, war, genocide, rape, abuse--is declining. And that's something to savor, as Pinker says in his conclusion. There were times when his cold, scientific eye seemed to overrule his tendency toward humanity, but overall, this was well composed and brilliantly argued. Recommended to anyone who feels weighed down by the news and is eager to hear something good for a change.

Right now, as the book is still fresh in my head, I'm finding it difficult not to consider this the best non-fiction book I have ever read. Maybe I'll regret this in a few weeks, but I'll stick to it right now - it surelly deserves this "the best of the best", even if ephemerally.The breadth and depth that the author achieved in analyzing the unifying topic of his work (the historical decline of violence) is abslotuley astounding. He leaves no trace of unchecked or unsourced data, and gives even a classical pessimist like myself a very bright picture of the future. This book has it all: history, politics, science, ethics, wonderfully woven reflections and of course, a glimpse into the great mind of Steven Pinker. All in all, this book was a joy to read, start to finish.

Very illuminating and detail-rich book about why violence has declined. Pinker describes the trend in very broad strokes and at a very large scale, leaving out details, but by and large, this did not bug me overly. As main historical forces he names the Leviathan (nation state), commerce, feminization, cosmopolitanism and the age of reason. It is very clearly aimed at a US American audience, however, and many of the examples are therefore Western ones. This I did not mined too much. Framing almost all politics he mentioned through the US binary was very tiresome, however. While I subscribe to most of the markers he mentions, I am not a "liberal". Overall, this was still a great companion read to Factfulness and I'd heartily recommend it.

This was a very good book, but long and sometimes the statistics got tedious. I can understand why he seemed determined to provide inexhaustible evidence for something he knew his audience might have trouble believing, but it's very difficult to read through descriptions of dry study after study on the same or very similar topic. However, in the sections where he is simply discussing what all those statistics mean, and later in his discussions of why the changes have occurred, he excels. His writing is clear and compelling, sometimes humorous. I enjoyed it, and would recommend to anyone willing to take a little time to learn something about humanity.

This book, while long, is thoroughly interesting and informative. The book left me feeling like I took an entire course on the history of human nature and violence, taught by one of the most captivating and knowledgeable professors I've ever had. The book was well-worth the investment in time and has made a profound impact on my outlook on the time in which I live. The frequent comments I hear about the "scary times we live in" are now easily dismissed as the nonsense they are.I highly recommend this book and I can't speak highly enough of Steven Pinker and the finesse he used in making such a wholly persuasive argument for reason and human intelligence.

Only appropriate response after finishing the book: "ZOMG". One of the most memorable books I've ever read - I went back and re-read multiple chapters to make sure I would not forget anything. Alas, if only textbooks in college were as riveting.Pinker uses violence as a lens to write two different books - a data-backed history of (violence in) the world and an overview of moral and political philosophy. I admittedly got bored in the data-backed section (although I realize its importance), but loved the other two parts.I now feel the same way I felt when I first learned about Evolution ("Oh, the Universe makes so much more sense now"). Everyone should read this book.

Steven Pinker has written a very ambitious book exploring the decline of violence over human history and the possible reasons for that decline. Some of his data sets seem to me too small for the weight he puts upon them, like the incidence of spanking to discipline children, but the evidence that violence is declining is very strong, and Pinker''s book is bringing that evidence to a broad public. I was more interested and more excited by his discussion of possible mechanisms for the decline in violence. This book is a long read, but well worth the time spent on it.

Steven Pinker is one of the most creative and meticulous minds of our generation. This book is a tour-de-force. I would put it as one of the 5 best books of the last decade. While it is a very long read, every word of it is worth the time. You will leave this book with a changed view of our world and how it has evolved. It will show how much we have changed in a very short time from a very violent species to a fairly peaceful one. I know, it is hard to believe, if you watch the evening news, but the news is not reality, it is marketing.

This book is an excellent antidote for people who can think only in negative terms of centralized government, capitalism, Enlightenment thinking, and all things modernity, while craving a return to simpler times or the imposition of a utopian ideology. Pinker's well-referenced and sober-minded assessment could inject some balance into people's overly negative views of our own society which, as he shows, is doing many things right.

Incredibly interesting and well researched study on the decline of violence. While Pinker's book offers many points of attacks for data analysts, I think it is a very courageous book and I am convinced by his main argument: that the world has become less violent. Overall, very insightful and one of the best non-fiction books I have read.

One of the best things I've ever read!WHAT A WONDERFUL EXPERIENCE.My own sense of my understanding of existence is vastly richer than before.A book of hope and optimism based on the best accumulation and correlation and analysis of data I've ever seen.I did not want it to end.

A spirited defence of civilisation itself with a lot of interesting diversions along the way. It is interesting that, for all that it read to me like a defence of enlightenment liberal politics against prelapsarian conservatism, it is from the left that the book has been most attacked.

Much of the citations in this book do not support Pinker in the ways he thinks that they do. While I wanted to like this book, I was not terribly impressed. The main argument ends up seeming like a cop-out that dismissed legitimate political grievances when put into practice.
I didn't need much convincing about the overall thesis, but was nonetheless surprised by the breadth of the evidence for the decline of violence and overall progress.
I just finished this it was one of the most important books I've ever read permanently changing My outlook on many things most notably humanity.
Best book I've read this year. Pinker uses a combination of statistics, evolutionary psychology and cultural change to explain why violence has declined. Masterpiece !

Steven Pinker intends this book as a positive remedy to a time and country in which most citizens grossly overestimate the amount and impact of violence and crime. And for the most part it does what he intends.Pinker is a scientist (psychology) and he's much happier working in the realm of statistics than in history or political science. He's also Canadian, which may distort his view of the U.S. to some extent.To extol the comparative humanity of our current world Pinker digs up a wealth of examples of just how horrible our ancestors were. He aso paints a picture of the gradual progress toward the current age. So for a considerable part of the early chapters we learn a great deal about ancient torture techniques, the high incidence of infanticide, the prevalence of lost noses from tavern knife fights, child abuse, and tales of village sport such as getting together to beat a pig to death before having it for a town meal. We also learn about medieval battles in which the main goal was to expand one's personal fiefdom by invading a neighbor and killing as many peasants as possible. And don't forget execution techniques, which included hanging children for theft. Or slavery.Our ancestors were pretty horrible, and Pinker makes that point in case after case in nearly every part of the world. People killing other people was very common and far more common than what we see today. This includes the waging of war. Despite the massive death tolls from war in the 20th century, Pinker points out that as a percentage of population wars have been far less deadly than in past centuries. He also lists body counts for dozens of conflicts, most of which most people have never heard of, for which historians can estimate fairly reliable body counts. He even digs into the Bible to point out the various genocides and events like David, before becoming king, happily collecting foreskins of Israel's adversaries.He tries to puzzle through what changed, and at times one gets the feeling that he's not sure it has been a completely positive change. How did we get from a time of casual slaughter to a time in which it's considered rude to make fun of another person's race, gender, or national background? The terms PC and political correctness are used a lot by Pinker, usually in a pejorative way. He seems to fall along the conservative stance that political correctness is thought control, instead of being a way in which people can make a firm point about maintaining civility in a diverse culture, and that calling people "snowflakes" or humorless for having a reaction is a less-than-subtle method of saying "I'll be as rude as I want and your disapproval takes away my free speech."Pinker also tries to probe the dramatic drop in homicides and violent crimes from the 1960s to today. He digs through dozens of ideas, some more convincingly than others. He points to changes in police work, such as New York City's "broken windows" policy of up-close-and-personal neighborhood policing. Here he misses the point that this also led to "stop and frisk" and regular civil rights abuses, including the high proportion of black arrests for comparable crimes among other races. He makes false equivalencies from the 1960s between the "violent left" (Black Panthers and SDS) and those on the opposite extreme responsible for decades of lynchings, bombings, and "disappearances" of those with opposing ideas or different races. Internationally Pinker seems to be of the opinion that many countries could do with a good dose of western civilization to make them less violent, because that's worked so well since the 1500s.These distractions aside, Pinker hits a positive stride in the last chapters of the book when he gets to work with statistics and failures by humans to make rational appraisals of the dangers around them. In a world in which the media focuses on incidents of violence, despite their decreasing numbers, it can be natural to make the assumption that the world is a violent place, more so than when we were younger. I don't know that some media have changed that much in the past century. We do live with 24-hour news coverage, and violence is easier to report on than political subtlety. But the type of coverage just came in different wrappers in the past. Check out old copies of Police Gazette if you have the chance. Salacious and violent stories have always drawn our attention.Pinker points out that our survival instincts lead us to overestimate dangers. So even though you're more likely to be killed from a bee sting than by an "Islamic terrorist" we focus on the most unique danger as opposed to one that is more common and mundane.On the whole, the book is filled with a ton of interesting and unique factoids, along with as clichê-strewn a prose style as I've read for some time. Whether he's on-point or not regarding causes he does make a reasonable point that, for whatever reason, we are less violent and less tolerant of violence than even recent ancestors were. We, as a nation, could relieve a great deal of day-to-day anxiety simply by being more aware that we live in a world far more peaceful than other humans have had the opportunity to enjoy.

“An ideology can provide a satisfying narrative that explains chaotic events and collective misfortunes in a way that flatters the virtue and competence of believers, while being vague or conspiratorial enough to withstand skeptical scrutiny.”Steven Pinker's The Better Angel of Our Nature gives the reader an account of how violence has apparently declined. It explores the nature and reality of terrorism, genocide, conflicts... All the aspects that have transpired throughout history, and how religion and ideology has played a part in the human experience so far. The book mostly takes part in 10 chapters which are listed here for a feel to the layout of the work:Chapter 1 - A FOREIGN COUNTRYChapter 2 - THE PACIFICATION PROCESSChapter 3 - THE CIVILIZING PROCESSChapter 4 - THE HUMANITARIAN REVOLUTIONChapter 5 - THE LONG PEACEChapter 6 - THE NEW PEACEChapter 7 - THE RIGHTS REVOLUTIONSChapter 8 - INNER DEMONSChapter 9 - BETTER ANGELSChapter 10 - ON ANGELS’ WINGSStephen Pinker firstly gives us the biological perspective, the Darwinian model that comes with the survival of the fittest. To make his case Stephen attempts to show how violence has supposedly decreased as we reach our present place in time. The reasons for this decrease do include aspects that come with a civilised mentality: Empathy, morality, education and the responsibility that comes with utilising intelligence rather than relying solely on force.Another titular counter, that comes with Pinker's evaluation about the decline of violence, is that since ancient times, medieval times, renaissance times, all the way to the modernity present... The reason that political correctness has given citizens greater pacificated behaviours, the element that comes with domestication and peace is that human beings have quelled their savage natures. I find myself doubting this decrease in violence, even when someone else counters with potential causes such as poverty and war, or where you live in the World... The conflicts that are happening in the World today are showing the opposite. Whether we have militaries around the World that exist to not just provide defensive measures but to be used in battlegrounds the Truth remains the same: War is big business and one aspect that facilitates change in geopolitics. The diplomatic methods and careful interaction taken by political entities reflects at times a certain distrust between various players, even if they are allies or enemies, the stance that if you scratch my back then I scratch yours remains one component among many. I think after over 800 pages here via The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined I'm left with a somewhat long critique of Religion being a main reason for past aggression and violence that perpetuated wars. The wars of the 20th century are looked at by Pinker as still being an indication of declination when it comes to violence. It isn't just the fault that comes with a religious mentality but one that comes with territorial expansion that comes with past empires tendency to view might as right and weaponry, strategy, resources, numbers giving the advantage. Often such tactical decisions may have taken place under the cloak of a premise that included belief. Whether we have armies, from ancient or medieval times for example, on the offensive burning, raping and pillaging... This rather gruesome aspect of conquest and warring was still present in the 20th century and even in our current 21st century. While human beings have the potential to do great things, depending on what they are can come with a burdensome price. Yet Pinker sees humanity and the World through what one could call rose-tinted glasses, radiating a positivity and politically correct charged case that things are getting better overall. Many would applaud his efforts and yet more would be sceptical and say have things really gotten better overall? Especially when we look at impoverished parts of the World... When we look at the poverty and crime still present (And in some places quite high!) can stats really show that suffering has diminished? I think out of the data collected many of us are wondering about what hasn't been included... Although many academics want to show we are at a crucial moment in our time as a species, that the direction we are heading isn't all doom and gloom.“Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities. —Voltaire”Pinker has a humanistic approach to how he views existence, (And it often attacks Religion for being a root cause, in a similar yet not as extreme reasoning that caused the French Revolution or that of Karl Marx to want to break away from the Church and State forms of control...) at times it is commendable, what could be viewed as decent, honourable and sustaining, at others bordering on a rather seemingly Utopic pathway that has flourishing branches of morality, intelligence, wisdom, and the biological necessity of humans being managed and controlled. It would certainly seem that when peace is inherited that many become complacent or decedent, yet those who fought for peacetime actually appreciate what they struggle so hard for. It is this domestication and complacency that sometimes has me worried, to use a metaphor what if de-clawing the tiger and putting the poor creature in the Zoo actually stops the creature from being what it was meant to be? A noble predatory animal living in nature that majestically hunts for food and lives a dangerous yet vibrantly charged existence. What would be the human equivalent if we strip away everything that gave us strength and power in the first place? It certainly is thought provoking to assess our existence in times of crisis and obviously enlightenment often comes through ardent struggles and challenges. The evils that beset mankind are often ones that take away those very aspects of freedom and liberty we have to keep alive. I'm not sure how political correctness and pacifism can do that when these very things backfire at times, weaknesses to be exploited by those more extreme in their actions, exploits and intellectualism. They often become forms of sterility and that is the danger that comes with the pitfalls of progressivism. In no means do I propose we abandon such versatility but also continue to explore the potential consequences that come with good intentions and ethical considerations. Overall Pinker's work is very detailed yet long, I must admit I was bored a few times and thinking I've read or heard this before... Yet the book has statistics, charts, plus certain ideas of influential scholars identifying six prevailing trends: The Pacification Process, the Civilizing Process, the Humanitarian Revolution, the Long Peace, the New Peace, and the Rights Revolutions. Turning from history to psychology he identifies five inner demons that lead us to violence: Predation, dominance, revenge, sadism, and ideology/religion. Before moving onto the four better angels: Empathy, self-control, morality and reason. Then giving the reader an interesting examination of violence in human history before explaining these trends accompanied with a psychological methodology. Worth a read and look for anyone interested in human nature plus the angels and demons that have haunted human beings since the dawn of time. A biological, humanistic and psychological approach from Steven Pinker.“It Begins with skepticism. The history of human folly, and our own susceptibility to illusions and fallacies, tell us that men and women are fallible.”

Another hit by Steven Pinker. I read this one a bit out of order having recently read Enlightenment Now. It was apparent speaking to many that this was the foundation for that book. I expected a lot of the same, which it was to some extent, but this also had a lot more ideas, different explorations of reasons and a lot more detail which was nice. With detail and thoroughness comes length and this one is a bit more of a chore to get through but it's well worth it for all of the information it conveys. Pinker delves into such a huge variety of topics and does not disservice to any of them as he really does get right into all the details they require.The fact that violence is decreasing drastically is well established. This is quite contrary to what we hear so often but it's incredibly evident from a bit of research. If I'd have read this when it first came out I would likely have been mostly surprised but as I'd become quite familiar with the arguments, largely because of this very book, I had long ago come to terms with the idea. Still always good to have proper data and arguments to firm up my beliefs and there are some details and aspects I'd not thought of or didn't have details on. For example the idea that violence in media/fiction increased is so pervasive and I'd never really known to counter the idea but Pinker establishes quite well that what we watch is actually much less violent than what we saw historically, even if there may be shorter term ups and downs in the trends.Really dug the exploration that etiquette inadvertedly leads to pacification. From simple etiquette about knives at the table being very related to violence to the more nebulous idea of self control leading to less violence. So many little contributions to peace like this aren't details I'd thought of. There really is no single simple answer to why we are more peaceful but what Pinker presents is just a barrage of small reasons which he does a good job of showing all add up to the reductions we've seen.Enjoyed the exploration of the rise of violence in the 60s until the 80s. This was more of less glossed over in Enlightenment Now as it didn't really fit the trend being discussed but here we get some good reasons. I had previously been a bit dumbfounded by this short term local maximum in violence. No doubt this wave of crime affected the attitudes people had about the decline of society as I grew up and can be seen in a lot of the dystopian fiction written in the 80s and 90s. Surely many still think things are worse than over but in the case of this time period authors were actually right to observe a rise in violence and only in retrospect does it seem inappropriate to have extrapolated that things would just get worse. When I see stories of a future crime ridden New York I know this doesn't represent the city I've seen in recent years but it makes more sense through the lens of the 80s and beyond. Pinker, being a logical analyst of the issue, does not attempt to give any sure fire reason for this increase but gives good ideas for things that could have contributed and awards them a reasonable level of confidence.Great analysis of War and terrorism. Not only demonstrated increases but really attempting to break down the specific causes. I don't chose to be overly optimistic about this because, although we've seen a great decline things could change. I do appreciate that the trends leading to reduction are likely to continue though.Upsetting exploration of infanticide. I never would have imagined this to be so common. Now on top of unplanned infant mortality, disease and high rates of violence as being undesirable traits of the often glorified past we can throw this on top. The evolutionary explanations for how this would have made sense are a bit troubling.Enjoy the exploration of gender. Men are violent for sure. We seem to be much better off having women have as much freedom as possible. A well demonstrated point that too many men, especially frustrated single men, make for bad situations all around! Couldn't help but think of the trendy incel idea, which wasn't really topical at the time of this book's writing, as some of this was detailed. Pinker clearly shows that being in a relationship or marriage is good for keeping men out of trouble and that a lack of relationship options leads to all sorts of terrible shit.All around love this book. So much information. Everyone should read this one!

The Better Angels of Our Nature – by Steven PinkerDo you realize that in many ways, you are living in the most peaceful period that's ever happened in the existence of our species? There's so much here. The book is massive and dense, yet valuable in its insight. Thankfully much of it is graphs, research blips, and quick summed points.  While on a level most of us know but argue with this.... The University of Cincinnati found in a study that eighty five percent of what we worry about never comes true. Contrary to the rampant bad news and doomsayers around us, while pessimism is on the rise,... violence as a whole is not increasing. There is documented, scientific studying that shows worldwide violence has been decreasing since 10,000 BC. "There has been a continuous decline in war, murders, and other violent crimes. Slavery has been nearly eliminated. Overall, murder rates have dropped by about one hundred times from the Middle Ages to today." Despite the fact that people think war violence is increasing, there has been a ninety percent reduction in war related deaths since World War II. Life expectancy has more than doubled in the past one hundred and fifty years. Poverty levels have dramatically dropped. A century and a half ago, seventy five percent of the world population lived in extreme poverty. Now that number is under fifteen percent. Developing regions realized a forty two percent reduction in the number of undernourished people in the last twenty five years. Citing everything from the Bible, to Marx, to tribalism, Pinker comes full circle on the Better Angels of our world. It's hard to agree with him on all of it because there are some wide sweeping generalizations mixed in, and we aren't entirely parallel in viewing the topic of religion, but for the most part he has provided a heavily thought out and credible reason for optimism. This is not to say that we should stop trying to reduce violence or lower carbon emissions and improve the earth and kindred relationships. It's just that most of the planet lets their lives be driven primarily by fear and worry. "Everyone is worried about home invasions, sharks, and hurricanes. You know what they should be worried about? - Car accidents, television, and junk food. But those aren’t as newsworthy."-------------------------------------------------------------- “We are not enemies, but friends. We must not be enemies. Though passion may have strained, it must not break our bonds of affection. The mystic chords of memory will swell when again touched, as surely they will be, by the better angels of our nature.”― Abraham Lincoln"As one becomes aware of the decline of violence, the world begins to look different. The past seems less innocent; the present less sinister.""Everything in human affairs is connected to everything else, and that is especially true of violence. Across time and space, the more peaceable societies also tend to be richer, healthier, better educated, better governed, more respectful of their women, and more likely to engage in trade.""Of all the varieties of violence of which our sorry species is capable, genocide stands apart, not only as the most heinous but as the hardest to comprehend.""People today think of the world as a uniquely dangerous place. It's hard to follow the news without a mounting dread of terrorist attacks, a clash of civilizations, and the use of weapons of mass destruction. But we are apt to forget the dangers that filled the news a few decades ago, and to be blasé about the good fortune that so many of them have fizzled out.""States are far less violent than traditional bands and tribes. Modern Western countries, even in their most war-torn centuries, suffered no more than around a quarter of the average death rate of nonstate societies, and less than a tenth of that for the most violent one.""The decline of violence may owe something to an expansion of empathy, but it also owes much to harder-boiled faculties like prudence, reason, fairness, self-control, norms and taboos, and conceptions of human rights.""Instead of asking, “Why is there war?” we might ask, “Why is there peace?” We can obsess not just over what we have been doing wrong but also over what we have been doing right. Because we have been doing something right, and it would be good to know what, exactly, it is.""The growth of writing and literacy strikes me as the best candidate for an exogenous change that helped set off the Humanitarian Revolution."

Well, I haven't exactly abandoned this... I never undertook to read it all anyway. As you might recall if you read the exchange of comments after my review of On Rape by Germaine Greer, Fourtriplezed and I agreed to read each other’s suggestions: he had never read anything by Greer, and I hadn’t read The Better Angels of Our Nature, the decline of violence in history and its causes (2011) by Steven Pinker. Mercifully, since the Pinker book is 802 pages long, I wasn’t asked to read the whole book— just the sub chapter in Chapter 7 ‘The Rights Revolution’ which is called ‘Women’s Rights and the Decline of Rape and Battering’. So this is not a ‘book review’, it’s just a response to the part of the book which I was asked to read…Pinker’s book has been nominated for a swag of awards: the Royal Society Science Book Prize Nominee for Science Books (2012), the Julia Ward Howe Prize Nominee (2012), the Best Book of Ideas Prize Nominee (2012), the Samuel Johnson Prize for Non-Fiction Nominee (2012), and the Cundill History Prize Nominee for Recognition of Excellence (2012). There are also numerous reviews from people who’ve read the whole book. See Tim Radford at The Guardian; and (notably) Peter Singer at the NYT. The admiration seemed to be universal so of course I went looking for another PoV—actually, I went looking for a female reviewer and couldn’t find one, (strange, eh?) but did find John Gray at The Guardian and include him here for balance. And I do that because I found a couple of examples of intemperate language (such as referring to ‘proclamations from bully pulpits such as the United Nations and its member governments on page 414) which made me feel uneasy about The Better Angels, but not enough to make me want to read the whole book…So… I read the prescribed chapter, but for good measure, I also read the Preface, which I summarise thus:Pinker argues that contrary to popular opinion and the impression we get from mass media or our own experiences,…violence has declined over long stretches of time and today we may be living in the most peaceable era in our species’ existence. The decline, to be sure, is not smooth; it has not brought violence down to zero; and it is not guaranteed to continue. But it is an unmistakable development, visible on scales from millennia to years, from the waging of wars to the spanking of children. (p.xxi)He maps the decline of violence by identifying six trends, five inner demons, four better angels and five historical forces:Six trends (chapters 2-7) consists of *the Pacification Process (from the anarchy of the hunting, gathering, and horticultural societies…[…] to the first agricultural civilisations with cities and governments, beginning around five thousand years ago. (p.2)] Yes, I hear you. Pinker has consigned Aboriginal societies from the oldest living civilisation on earth* to the category of ‘anarchy’.*the Civilising Process between the late Middle Ages and the 20th century best documented in Europe: the consolidation of a patchwork of feudal territories into large kingdoms …[…] … with centralised authority and an infrastructure of commerce. *the Humanitarian Revolution, beginning in the Age of Reason and the European Enlightenment in the 17th and 18th centuries. This brought the first organised attempts to abolish socially sanctioned forms of violence like despotism, slavery, duelling, judicial torture, superstitious killing, sadistic punishment and cruelty to animals. *the Long Peace, dating from the end of WW2. Pinker says this is unprecedented: the great powers, and developed states in general, have stopped waging war on one another.  [John Gray in his review refutes this because of the number of proxy wars that have taken place].*the New Peace, since the end of the Cold War in 1989: a decline in organised conflicts of all kinds—civil wars, genocides, repression by autocratic governments, and terrorist attacks.*the Rights Revolutions, symbolically inaugurated by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, has seen a growing revulsion against aggression on smaller scales, including violence against ethnic minorities, women, homosexuals, and animals which has led to a cascade of movements from the late 1950s to the present day.It was this last chapter, and the chapter about violence against women that I was asked to read.*The Five Inner Demons are predatory or instrumental violence; dominance; revenge; sadism and ideology;*The Four Better Angels are empathy; self-control; moral sense; and reason.*The Five Historical Forces are those which favour our peaceable motives and that have driven the multiple declines in violence:  *the Leviathan (a state and judiciary with a monopoly on the legitimate use of force); *Commerce (trading partners who are more valuable alive than dead); *Feminisation (moving away from the glorification of violence); *Cosmopolitanism (embracing the perspective of the Other); and *Escalating Reason (applying knowledge and rationality to human affairs).So, to ‘Womens Rights and the Decline of Rape and Battering’ in the chapter about the Rights Revolutions…The difficulty I have with Pinker’s approach (in this chapter that I’ve read) is that it is reliant on statistics, and mostly US statistics at that. On this topic, having anything meaningful to say about the prevalence of rape in the past (whether the near past or very long ago) is problematic. So Pinker leaps over centuries of past violence with this:The prevalence of rape in human history and the invisibility of the victim in the legal treatment of rape are incomprehensible from the vantage point of contemporary moral sensibilities. But they are all too comprehensible from the vantage point of the genetic interests that shaped human desires and sentiments over the course of evolution, before our sensibilities were shaped by Enlightenment humanism. A rape entangles three parties, each with a different set of interests: the rapist, the men who take a proprietary interest in the woman, and the woman herself. (p. 395)See, I have a problem just with this paragraph. Why is the woman placed last in that last sentence, eh? And there’s a curious slide in the logic:*rape is hard to understand now that we have contemporary moral sensibilities*rape is not hard to understand from a genetic/evolutionary PoV*we have outgrown those desires and sentiments since the Enlightenment*but now I, Pinker, using the present tense ‘entangles’ include the men with a proprietary interest in women, as if we have not outgrown those pre-Enlightenment views…Hmm. To read the rest of my thoughts please visit https://anzlitlovers.com/2018/11/14/t...

At 832 pages (36 hours on audio book), this is by no means a small book. Although I thought parts of the history and analysis were fascinating, the book's topic is fairly disturbing (death, murder, torture, violence), which I found depressing to dwell on at such length. The author has a great sense of history and makes a compelling case that humanity's past was much, much more violent than the relatively peaceful world we live in today. I felt more appreciative of the present after this book's thorough detailing of all the progress we've made in several aspects of society. Pinker offers interesting examples of violence and conflict from different historical eras, but I felt too much was drawn from European Middle Ages and onward, and I wished the book had included more stats and examples from Roman and Eastern civilizations. The most interesting concept I learned about in the book was the "Republic of Letters", which was a term for the Enlightenment authors that corresponded across great distances of time and space. Pinker describes how intellectuals during this period used letters and books to exchange and refine their thoughts, which led to new ideas about governing nations, and eventually those ideas were used to create a more peaceful world. I found this description of the power of sharing ideas to be very inspirational, and it made me think of the great potential we have today with all the idea sharing tools made possible by the internet (Twitter, blogs, podcasts).One aspect of this book I found enjoyable, but challenging, was the author's constant questioning of data sets and theories. Pinker starts describing several trends and a theory about why violence decreased in one area, only to discuss at length why that theory may be incorrect. It was a good reminder about why we should be very skeptical of theories and rigorous with our data analysis, but I often impatiently wondered, "What does the author believe to be true? How many ideas do we need to explore and reject?" I enjoyed this historical overview in the first half more than the list of behavioral studies in the second half for this reason. Many of those same studies (e.g. the Stanford prison experiment) come up in so may books I read, like "Thinking Fast and Slow" (which was published around the same time), so I'm less excited to read about them yet again.In the last chapter the author finally divulges his conclusions, and it feels like a closing argument to a long court case. Rewarding, but a lot of mental work along the way. Overall, I enjoyed the intellectual work out, and am left with a new perspective on human history (the path of decreasing violence) and several interesting ideas I'd like to read about more.

I had finished reading Factfulness just a few days before starting this book . It was a book I loved very much. But after reading the first few pages of The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence has declined , I almost concluded that I would probably not enjoy the book much. Very soon, I realised I was wrong.Being accustomed to reading fictions and having just started with Non-Fictions, I found it difficult to comprehend some phrases and had to re-read them to understand better. Every now and then I had to find out meanings of words used in the book I had never heard of. I got past that struggle after the first 100 pages or so. Even though I had to look for meanings of words and re-read phrases used throughout the book , it didn't seem like a struggle after the first 100 pages. That is when I started enjoying the book. I discovered many new concepts and facts. When I hear about certain incidents and altercations from people around, my mind starts wondering if it is a Hobbesian Trap kind of situation!! The baby boomers influencing the rise in the number of homicides from the 1960s to the 1990s and why they did was something that I found really interesting.I really liked the fact that the book mostly had quite a balanced and unbiased take on most matters.As explained in the book, statistics has proven that a country where women are better represented in governments and other professions are the ones where violence has declined and the country's economy shot up . It felt great to know that the feminist movement has done good to the world and the undermining of the movement by some people is usually uncalled for. I was fascinated to know that the phrase "Try not to look with rose tinted glasses" is not just a phrase but a natural and biological phenomenon experienced by human beings.Why Reason more than empathy has led to a significant fall in violence is beautifully explained with real-life examples.I recommend this book to everyone who wants to understand a little more about human beings and how our instincts played a part in the history of violence.

Oh boy... this one is hard to rate. There are certain sections that were REALLY interesting. I really liked the first quarter of the book and STRUGGLED with the middle half. That's why it took me so long to read. Some of my favorite sections were about how utterly brutal the Middle Ages were and so-called Biblical times. I also liked the bits about how the United States has gone through cycles of violence and peace. Some parts of the chapters were very fascinating, morbid, and surprising at times (the Wild West... oof.). The sections The Long Peace and the New Peace, especially the New Peace, were absurdly long chapters and for me they really dragged. There's a too-long section about European conflict which seems odd in that only the U.S. and Europe have really been highlighted in this gigantic tome, while Latin America and to some degree Asia have a more reduced focus. I suppose the historical pieces were not all that interesting and I got tired of looking at endless graphs. However, a long chapter needn't be horrible. I did like the Rights Revolution bit quite a lot and I was glad that the author included both homosexuality and animal rights. Inner Demons later on was kinda... eh. The psychological effects behind evil have been done to death and honestly been written more impressively by other authors (sorry!). I definitely feel that this book could have been a lot more enjoyable with a lot more editing. It's just not necessary for a book to be this long nor to have 100+ page chapters. Overall, I would say that I enjoyed this book, I definitely learned new information, and I agree with his overall thesis and think it holds up. It's kind of a shame that some of the book has already aged in that it doesn't cover school shootings (now a huge omission) or the Trumpian era or even Russia and Crimea. I would think the author would have something to say regarding the shootings (maybe should look that up...). I would say that it's better to digest this book in chunks (unless you have a compulsion to do a book challenge... *cough*) and to skim over some of the denser, slower chapters. I would say I still recommend this if the topic piques your interest and you do not mind the formatting.

This book is too long and overanalyzes its topic. The topic, decline of violence is a worthy subject and worth discussing. The pace is terrible, it’s slow and each chapter groans under a weight of detail and charts and too much argumentation. The book suffers from bad editing, not so much bad writing, but too much writing. The book could have been half as long and still made a good argument. The length of the book actually weakens the argument. It does seem that a culture of physical violence, assumption of violence occurring and official government violence have all declined. But, the author argues so much and so long that I wondered if his argument is really weak and he’s trying to hide that fact under a weight of data and authority. He also doesn’t seem to address the possibility that people are just channeling violent impulses into safer less physically violent actions, such as aggressive social media trolling and the like. I guess the book met my expectations as it did outline why the author feels physical violence has declined and supports his case. That said, I give this book a 3. It’s interesting, and proves to the author’s satisfaction that physical violence has decreased over the centuries. But, the book is too long for effective argumentation and doesn’t address two critical areas, first, whether physical violence is merely being transferred to other channels of what might be called non-physical violence and second address the fact that cultures tend to oscillate between ideas. It’s possible that an event or culture might bring back physical violence to earlier levels…it’s a fallacy to assume as this book does that physical violence levels will keep decreasing especially given that it’s human nature reacting in culturally approved manners.

This is a fascinating and informative book, which I should never, ever have given to my Dad as a Christmas present.Firstly, although father is not adverse to fact dense books, he is a slow and careful reader and this book is a long slog.Secondly, while this book has an uplifting premise and the word "angels" in the title, it's filled with gore, vileness and gruesome records of atrocity.Dad, I read this book so that you wouldn't have to.Pinker expects his readers to be resistant to the idea that violence is on decline (just look at the news!), so he bolsters his position. His argument begins with the idea that far from being angels now, we have forgotten the devils we used to be: murdering children, torturing women, and likely to stab each other over dinner.It's a history of homicide, democide, genocide, ethnocide, politicide, regicide, infanticide, neonaticide, filicide, siblicide, gynecide, uxoricide, matricide, and terrorism by suicide. Ugh!Also, people in the past (use say 1910 as a barometer) were morally stupid, and even, by today's standards, somewhat retarded.Cold comfort. All this is depressing, as Pinker admits, "After reading eight chapters (the book is 10!) on the horrible things that people have done to each other and the darker parts of human nature that spurred them, you have every right to look forward to a bit of uplift in a chapter on our better angels."It's accurate to say that the final chapters are "a bit" of an uplift. Pinker says he wrote this book as an answer to the question, "What makes you optimistic?" Judged by this book, he is unlikely to be accused of being a Pollyanna.He does, however, counter some of our factually mistaken and scientifically unsupported pessimism.• There's not an inevitable cycle towards war and catastrophe. It's even statistically improbable and there's a trend away from it.• We're not ruled by a violent bias toward predation, dominance, and vengeance. Human nature also includes peaceful traits, which evolution seems to be selecting for, of compassion, fairness, self-control, and reason. • Things aren't getting worse. They are getting better. "The forces of modernity — reason, science, humanism, individual rights — has brought us benefits in health, experience, and knowledge as well as a reduction in violence."The data is coldly reassuring, while Pinker assesses, "The decline of violence may be the most significant and least appreciated development in the history of our species."  Pinker cautions against forces that favor violent outcomes such as ideological and utopian thinking and warns us of the dangers of pluralistic ignorance, when people, "...endorse a practice or opinion they deplore because they mistakenly think that everyone else favors it," and punish dissenters.He suggests forces that favor a pacifying effect: art and literature (fiction, satire, first-person accounts, and reportage); democracy (electing smart and open-minded leaders, establishing policies, norms, and taboos); feminization; and "rights" movements (human, civil, homosexual, women's, and animal and, in general, "...a commitment that other living things, no matter how distant or dissimilar, be safe from harm and exploitation.") as well as, "conditions of democracy, prosperity, decent government, peacekeeping, open economies".His approach is rational, moderate, and a counterpoint to authors who find that humanity's increasing traits of empathy and compassion are a source of improvement and inspiration. Rather, Pinker points to our increasing powers of abstract reasoning and understanding of the economic benefits of cooperation. He's quite enthusiastic about this in his way.Pairs well with: The Expanding Circle by Peter Singer, The Empathic Civilization by Jeremy Rifkin; The Age of Empathy: Nature's Lessons for a Kinder Society by Frans de Waal; and Twelve Steps to a Compassionate Life by Karen Armstrong. For more info:The TED talk: Steven Pinker: The surprising decline in violencePeter Singer's review in The New York Times "Is Violence History?"Of note: This is a nice vocabulary expanding book: putsches, suzerain, altricial, eschatological, obloquy, parlous, autarkies, atrocitologists, frugivores, prelapsarian, armentarium, equipoise, immiseration, hagiographic, bafflegabA sobering note: The kind of arguments used today in discussions of abortion, animal rights, stem cell research, and euthanasia were earlier (and horrifically) used to justify infanticide (the merits of which people also used to debate!):"In 1911 an English physician, Charles Mercier, presented arguments than infanticide should be considered a less heinous crime than the murder of an older child or an adult: 'The victim’s mind is not sufficiently developed to enable it to suffer from the contemplation of approaching suffering or death. It is incapable of feeling fear or terror. Nor is its consciousness sufficiently developed to enable it to suffer pain in appreciable degree. Its loss leaves no gap in any family circle, deprives no children of their breadwinner or their mother, no human being of a friend, helper, or companion.'" Quotes:"...as long as war is regarded as wicked, it will always have its fascination. When it is looked upon as vulgar, it will cease to be popular." — Oscar Wilde"...biology and history suggest that all else being equal, a world in which women have more influence will be a world with fewer wars.""Though nothing can guarantee that virulent ideologies will not infect a country, the vaccine is an open society in which people and ideas move freely and no one is punished for airing dissenting views, including those that seem heretical to polite consensus.""One could say that for every presidential IQ point, 13,400 fewer people die in battle, though it's more accurate to say that the three smartest postwar presidents, Kennedy, Carter, and Clinton, kept the country out of destructive wars.""But it is just as foolish to let our lurid imaginations determine our sense of probabilities. It may always be something, but there can be fewer of those things, and the things that happen don't have to be as bad. The numbers tell us that war, genocide, and terrorism have declined over the past two decades — not to zero but by a lot."

Very thorough (long!) and meticulously researched, this book, with its message about the decline of violence over many millennia is surprising good news for humanity--I like that, and I think we all need to hear that. "Better Angels" is not for everyone--it reads like a text book, albeit an interesting one. I found the second half of the book especially hard to get through--all the talk about lobes of the brain, psychological experiments, etc. I think I'm a fairly educated person, but some of the big words and explanations were a little over my head. My one complaint about the book was his negative treatment of religion. He spent a lot of time talking about all the awful things that had been done in the name of religion (especially Christianity) throughout history, but very little time on any of its positive contributions. That is because he believes there are very few positive contributions. I realize that this is a popular opinion nowadays, especially among atheists (Pinker admits he is one), but I think an argument could be made (and has been made by certain theologians and religious historians, as a quick search on Amazon can show) that many of the teachings of Christianity--the love of God for all people and forgiving those who have done wrong, for ex.--have greatly influenced the Western governments and culture that have contributed to the decline in violence. I can overlook this bias, however, as this is a monumental, important book, and Pinker deserves credit for that.

Highly engaging through the first half then I steadily lost interest as it progressed. Like many books of this type: I'm really glad someone wrote it, but I didn't necessarily need the whole thing personally.Also somewhat obvious trigger warning: it deals with a lot of violence :/"In an influential article called “Crime as Social Control,” the legal scholar Donald Black argued that most of what we call crime is, from the point of view of the perpetrator, the pursuit of justice.""The Old Testament tells us to love our neighbors, the New Testament to love our enemies. The moral rationale seems to be: Love your neighbors and enemies; that way you won’t kill them. But frankly, I don’t love my neighbors, to say nothing of my enemies. Better, then, is the following ideal: Don’t kill your neighbors or enemies, even if you don’t love them.""Perhaps the least contentious claim about human nature is that humans are apt to have sex under a wider range of circumstances than those in which they are capable of bringing up the resulting babies.""The art of politics, Tetlock points out, is in large part the ability to reframe taboo tradeoffs as tragic tradeoffs (or, when one is in the opposition, to do the opposite). A politician who wants to reform Social Security has to reframe it from “breaking our faith with senior citizens” (his opponent’s framing) to “lifting the burden on hardworking wage-earners” or “no longer scrimping in the education of our children.” Keeping troops in Afghanistan is reframed from “putting the lives of our soldiers in danger” to “guaranteeing our nation’s commitment to freedom” or “winning the war on terror.” The reframing of sacred values, as we will see, may be an overlooked tactic in the psychology of peacemaking."

After a few false starts a few years ago, I finally powered through this book. And I'm glad I did.Pinker has made a persuasive case, bolstered by the breadth and depth he gives the topic. I understand Pinker has his critics (Noam Chomsky comes to mind) but it seems to me that one cannot gloss over this work with a soundbite here or there. It's a serious work that if it is to be refuted, requires serious engagement. I am cautiously convinced that Pinker has proven his theory that violence has decreased significantly across the human species.That said, Pinker makes what I think of several common mistakes that don't affect the central thesis. First, he false into the "We" trap much too often, speaking of "humanity" as a universal platonic ideal. He fails to significantly grasp the differences in values that can exist among humans, though he dances very close to the topic several times.Additionally, he lumps the "tribes are bad" meme into much of his discourse without recognize that all Tribe is, at core, applied communal love. It is a communal technology that can be used for good or evil. Most humans remain tribal, long for tribal relationships, but our modern world has banned them. I often think that Pinker and many other academics really mean to criticize religious viewpoint when they say "tribe" because it's more politically correct to condemn tribes.That said, this book is a must have on the shelf of those who would seek to understand the human condition.

This is a big book, but despite it's length, the writing is so clear, and the ideas in it so provoking, that I didn't have any trouble completing it. Pinker writes beautifully. Here's but one example. When explaining how murder is very often the actualization of fantasies that we all harbour, Pinker writes:“The small number of premeditated murders that are actually carried out must be the cusp of a colossal iceberg of homicidal desires submerged in a sea of inhibitions”. Pinker accomplishes an enormous task: he uses a mountain of data and graphs to make a persuasive case that violence has declined massively throughout the ages. Thus the first part of the book is a history of the world and a shocking exposure of its barbarism. In non-state societies, pre-civilizaiton, the average annual death rate in warfare exceeded 500 per 100,000 people. Pinker does an excellent job of putting perspective around this statstic, and the many others that he uses. For example, Germany's average annual death rate from warefare in the 20th Century was 144. And the median national homicide rate among the world's countries is 6, with modern Western Europe enjoying a rate of 1. The worst decades of U.S. history (70's and 80's) in the most violent U.S. cities had annual homicde rates of 10 to 45.Why were ancient people's so violent? Pinker provides many explanations. One is that they put a low value on other people's lives becuase pain and death were so common in their own. Life had lots of nasty surpises, such as famines and plagues. With so much suffering, people may have reasoned that God was sadistic, and they were therefore quick to sacrifice others using brutal, bloody means such as burning at the stake, breaking on the wheel, or Judas's Cradle. Indeed, a belief in temporal bodies but eternal souls justified some of the worst violations of human life. With life being short and uncertain, people were rationally less willing to sacrifice present pleasure for future pleasure. Pinker supports this hypothesis by showing a sharp decline in interest rates, while controlling for other variables such as inflation. Modern people are willing to accept a lower rate of interest since they can be reasonably assured about living long enough to enjoy the benefits conferred to their future selves, enhanced by modern institutions for saving. Self-indulgence, or a lack of self-control, led people of past eras to steeply discount the future, and thereby ignore the longer-term consequnces of seeking immediate gratification.In Pinker's telling of the civilization process, it becomes astoundingly clear how disgusting our ancestors were to our eyes. Their habits and hygiene were completely unregulated by the self-restraint, social norms, and taboos to which we are all inculcated from a tender young age. It is clear, therefore, that what we take as our 'second nature' is aptly named; it is not our first, animal nature and had to be learned. Pinker makes the interesting point that much of our culture's norms, such as table manners, swearing, dressing modestly, have their roots in the civilizing porcess. Now that we are civilized, and do not need to fear being harassed or assaulted, some of these norms (such as women showing a lot of skin or men cursing in public) may have outlived their purpose. Another explanation for our violent pasts center around the lack of a state, or Hobbes's Leviathan. For example, in non-state societies, people are left to pursue their own justice. Without a state to pursue justice blindly and using the principle of proportionality, people are vulnerable to the "Moralization Gap", whreby they interpret the "harms they inflict to be mild and forgettable but the harms they suffer to be unprovoked and grievous". In contrast, the law can weigh harms without the self-serving distortions of either the perpetrator or the victim.Yet another reason for our ancestors endorsing torture is a fascinating and convincing case made by Pinker that torture is an acquired taste, like our taste for dry wine, aged cheese, or hot peppers. The pheonomenon describes the way that "neophytes must overcome a first reaction of pain, disgust or fear on the way to becoming a connesieur". Having provided a full account of our violent past, and the reasons therefore, Pinker sets about to explain the extraordinary decrease in violence beginning around the 18th Century. Pinker identifies many exogenous forces that led to this decline, such as an effective state and judiciary, gentle commerce and the opportunity for positive-sum games, the feminization of society and a shift in culture from honour to dignity, the perspective-taking enabled by the spread of books and travel, and the force of reason in dispelling any basis for privileging one's interests over others.In his discussion on morality and taboo, Pinker makes the interesting point that no societies build their moral underpinnings around the Golden Rule or the Categorical Imperative (universalizable principles). Morality in practice is a set of relational models consisting of Communal Sharing, Authority Ranking, Equality Matching, and Market Pricing. Morality then consists of respecting or violating the models. Over time we have shifted our moral framework toward the values of personal freedom and autonomy, displacing the role of the first three models in our moral lives. In fact, for Pinker, morality seems to consist of the interchangability of perspectives and the opportunity the world provides for positive-sum games. This leaves us with a moral evolution that stops at Market Pricing, essentially the language of formal contracts and the workings of the modern economy. Pinker's account of the decline of violence clearly privileges the world of commerce and markets. A free market respects people's freedom (it it not value-laden), puts a premium on empathy (becuase the yardstick of business is satisfying human needs in markets), and keeps people peacable in order to preserve the networks of cooperation and trust that facilitate trade.

Bill Gates recommended this book as the most inspiring book he's ever read, so I ordered it from the library without knowing anything else about it. When I saw it was 800 pages (700 + notes, index, etc.), my first thought was "maybe not." This book is a one of those that takes the long view--as in it encompasses the entire history of humankind--to make the point that violence of all sorts has declined dramatically. The point is supported by many graphs and illustrations and is quite convincing. Certainly we have come a long way in terms of what's considered acceptable treatment of heretics, prisoners, women and children, so there is reason to be optimistic about the future. However, it is scary thinking about the fact that the long peace we have enjoyed (at least here in the United States) could come to a sudden end via nuclear button pushing. Unfortunately, the book is about 400 pages more than I was interested in reading on the subject, so full disclosure: I did not read it all. However, what I did read was quite interesting and well written. I enjoyed Pinker's explorations into human nature (are we basically violent/bad or peaceful/good?) For the record, he says the most violent human beings are 2-year-olds. Somehow most of us grow out of that stage.

Pinker makes a bunch of arguments in a variety of ways generally pushing the argument that violence has declined over the centuries through a variety of things which could broadly be called “progress”. The book is so wide ranging that there isn’t much more of a central argument than that, although there are some individual interesting arguments.What he seems to fail to take into account is the increased potential via technology and interconnectednees to let smaller groups (and eventually individuals) essentially wage large scale violence against the broader world. I will accept his broad arguments for decreasing desire by individuals, groups, and societies to violence, but this only really applies to “mainstream” society; it doesn’t matter if 6.5b people are increasingly successful and peaceful if a sufficient minority (which may someday consist of a single individual) decides to engage in mass scale violence.

Proud to say I made it through the whole book! Not sure how an author who writes a book like this has any time for anything else in his life.ProsThe book demonstrates very clearly that violence of all types has declined throughout time. Humans today live much more peaceful lives than at any other time in history or prehistory. Lots of charts and graphs that make the point dramatically and unequivocally. Also talks about the causes of past violence, the causes of our current relative peace, and why those causes exist. I felt very smart reading this book.ConsStrong anti-religion perspective. Written in 2011, so includes the required George W. Bush bashing. Author is a baby-boomer, so ode to baby-boomer section. Overly strong emphasis placed on the importance of reason (as opposed to faith/religion). I felt attacked for my faith.

It shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone that Steven Pinker is a good writer. So even though this is a 700+ pages book with a ton of research descriptions and graphs, it manages to stay captivating throughout. In his signature manner, Pinker carefully reviews all the available evidence and possible explanations for the surprising finding: today we live in the most peaceful time in humanity's existence. His treatment of the topic is so thorough that it's virtually impossible to come away from this book without a little more faith in humanity, as well as an understanding that many of the world's trends are in the right direction, and it is in our hands to keep them on track.I believe the book carries a very important message for our times, and does a wonderful job of delivering it.

On the whole, I think this is a good book, but an incomplete one. While I don't think, or feel, that violence has declined, he does have data on his side. However, it is easier to push a button, or sit in the comfort of a War room, than actually lead troops to battle!He does cover aspects like domestic violence, rape, child killings, and this is good. As he also does the topic of genocide. The analysis is, in general, good. However, I feel that the book is incomplete on account of a few things"One: it is a Western book. The data covers Europe and the US. You cannot extrapolate to Latin America, Asia, Australia and Africa! This is a sad fact of the book, Two: I don't think he explores causality. Some aver that the rise of Muslim terrorism, and Hindu fundamentalism is because of the actions of the British, in India, between 1858 and 1947, wherein they systematically tried to drive a wedge between the two communities. True? Some sort of analysis on causality would be goodAnother example: the West has had a different growth trajectory, demographic situation, culture than the rest of the world. the forces that drive violence is different. He has not gone into this at allA good book, but incomplete.

The book has invaluable information, immense research behind it. So, why I gave 3 stars, you may ask? Because it statistics, economy, philosophy, psychology, history in one enormously long book. The reading experience was like a landscape with high mountains and deep valleys. It has interesting/enjoyable parts, when the reading was seamless, and dull moments, when I had to put it away for a few days/weeks. Probably this is why it took me almost 8 months (!) to read it. Not everyone will enjoy the aforementioned different genres equally. It is at least 3-4 books shoehorned into one. It is an interesting book, with a huge amount of (invaluable) information, and research behind it, but the wide range of topics won't be suitable for everyone's taste.

The first 30-40% of the book describe in detail the level of torture and death that preceded current times. While effective and thorough, this could have been condensed quite a lot, as after a while I was just waiting for the author to move on.After that, the second half of the book picks up and delivers its title: explaining why violence has declined.A variety of fields of violence are covered, from the decline of deaths by war right up to the decline of violence against minorities, with statistical evidence for the decline and possible reasons and theories. In the end, the book leaves the reader with a feeling of bitterness towards the past and optimism towards the future.

Okay, so it took me almost exactly six months to meander my way through this massive book, but I'm so glad I did. Steven Pinker's almost over-researched, diligently supported conclusions are impossible to dismiss or ignore. And the reasons he provides for the measurable decline in violence are made more vivid in light of the apparent efforts of the current political "leadership" in the US to reverse each and every one of those trends. This book is essential reading not just to see in detail the long-acting forces that got us here, but to appreciate just how amazing "here" actually is and work to continue to accelerate the rate of positive change in the face of reactionary resistance.

There is so much here I almost wish he had made this into 3 or even 4 separate books but I understand why he didn't. The structure is excellent, well laid out, and easy to follow. The first section is the history and analysis of human violence, followed by the statistical explanation that violence in society is decreasing. This alone could be one book. The quantity of sources is astounding. It would almost be easier to cite who Pinker doesn't cite. Once this premise is established the next sections deal with the whys and hows. He also discusses some common misconceptions about what isn't responsible for decreasing violence. He does this with quotes from citations from Kant, Locke, and Hume, to Darwin, Dawkins, and just for fun George Carlin. The vocabulary may cause some folks to struggle, and the source references are clearly that of an academic but with all that said there is a great deal of humor added to lighten the otherwise heavy topic. If you enjoy the application and analysis of statistics, application and analysis of philosophy, or the explanation of modern scientific findings in relation to anthropology and the human condition you will enjoy this book. All that said it is a heavy lift. It is very much a non-fiction, science/data/history/philosophy nerd's book.

The bad: taking into account the book's massive size, the only thing I would add would be periodic summaries. Either at the end or by chapter. Sure, you can have the world's history of violence broken down in a couple dozen chapters, but you don't get a bird's eye view when you're deep in it, nor do you get it at the end. But not a "bad" thing per se. Complementary, maybe.The good: an excellent (if at times depressing) compendium on the world and its history of violence, as well as the main causes and attenuators of violence throughout the ages. You get to understand a different side of humanity after you read this book. This should be required reading.

On many occasions, looking at the news around us we tend to believe that the world is worse than it was earlier. But is it so? So far I had looked at evolution from features and intelligence perspective. How to survive was the key driver for us. But here we look at evolution from emotional lens. Compassion, empathy, relationship, anger, revenge etc. And the author gives a very clear trend of each of them. Being from an analytics background I thoroughly enjoyed the numerous charts which gives a very factual indication of how the world is turning out to be a less violent place by each passing year. A great read to restore a bit of faith in humanity.

Fantastic book, loads and loads of information, analysis, deduction..800 pages long..it will take sometime to finish it :)Steven Pinker has traced the history of violence (state and individual) that humans have perpetrated against other humans. He makes the case that we in the 21st century live in a World that is far safer and less violent..He not only makes a case based on data, but also analyses the reasons as to why this reduction of violence has happened. A lot of it is very logical. One can only hope that this trend towards peace continues to get better and World become very safe for our children

Exhaustive and a bit exhausting.Pinker’s account of the decline of violence is hard to argue against, even when the two world wars are accounted for.Additionally, the comprehensive sweep of his scholarship avoids the myopia of focusing on the near present. That slavery, torture, women and child beatings were considered the norm for many thousands of years is striking evidence of how far humans have ascended in.just the last few hundred years.That many of these accomplishments in reducing violence have not entailed violent revolution is also of note.Critically, I might have done with less interpersonal psychology and discussions of the prisoners dilemma.

I put this off for WAY too long. It is dense and took forever to get through but it is well worth it. Pinker outlines a history of violence to show how violent the world was and establish a trend. Once established, he then starts to look at why this downward trend of violence has happened. He explores a number of social, political, and economic factors that could explain why humanity is moving away from violence. Along the way he debunks many well-established myths about why violence happens in the first place. This is broken down further by examining many different types of violence. It is a wonderfully optimistic read about where we, as a race, have been able to bring our society.

Pinker's tome is the most provocative and optimistic thing I've read all year. His data is a compelling argument that violence really has decreased by orders of magnitude, that the human condition is simply better than it was before. I found the history more resonant than the psychology--if you can't read the whole thing, read the introduction and the chapter on murder.He argued that as we civilize, as strong states grow a monopoly on violence, and as people look to those states rather than to themselves for justice, that we become less violent. It gives me newfound hope for the power of government to truly change norms, and a different perspective on modern, often left-wing attempts to wrest justice back from government.

This was a worthwhile and interesting read, full of frightening factoids that - despite the book's overriding argument of a decline in violence, seem to imply the opposite in the context of the events of the past year and current political climate. Example: "Integrative complexity is related to violence. People whose language is less integratively complex, on average, are more likely to react to frustration with violence and are more likely to go to war in war games. Working with the psychologist Peter Suedfeld, Tetlock tracked the integrative complexity of speeches of national leaders in a number of political crises of the 20th century that ended peacefully (such as the Berlin blockade in 1948 and the Cuban Missile Crisis) or in war (such as World War I and the Korean War), and found that when the complexity of the leaders' speeches declined, war followed."Read at your own risk.

Violence has declined! The idea is counter-intuitive (especially about the century that saw 2 world wars and the use of nuclear weapons), but Pinker provides the statistics that back his claim. As always, his writing style is very readable, often witty, and always on the money scientifically. It's a long book (nearly 700 pages), but if that's not intimidating I recommend this addition to his work.

This book was on my to read list for a while. Looks like all books from Pinker were on chaotic reading order. But it's a great book, pretty much like any other Pinker's. Steven knows how to be extremely comprehensive, draw in almost too much reference without sounding preachy and confused. This is not just a book about why violence has declined. This is THE book on history of violence in its many ramifications, with history, psychological, philosofica, politica ties. Highly recommended.

This is the kind of book that requires multiple re-reads to truly absorb and appreciate the immense amount of data and information contained therein. History, psychology, philosophy, anthropology, theology, *atrocitology*, statistics, sociology, political science and more--all these fields of academia have been drawn together to painstakingly demonstrate that indeed humanity is seeing an ongoing decline of violence in our world. I am grateful to have taken the time to read this, and would urge any hungry mind to consider consumption of this great text too!

Sank right into this one. Wonderful overview of the multitude of ways we are living in an era of never before seen levels of worldwide peace. Pinker is on fine display here with his distinct ability to convey the profundity of the topic to a generalized mass audience. The result is a smooth read with a lot of fascinating revelations woven into an eloquent whole that will make you feeling quite satisfied with the direction of mankind. A close friend recommended it and I can see why. Excellent book indeed.

This is a huge, ambitious, densely packed book tackling a very intriguing subject - from a very American viewpoint. While the author presents a lot of interesting thoughts and statistics (some more, some less convincing), he employs quite a bit of speculation to make his points and shows clear biases, glossing over anything that doesn't conveniently fit into his argument.

3,5.Would agree with the books general idea and there were some interesting stories/facts. But in general, this was:1. too brutal even for me,2. way too long,3. and I would like to see evidence and data for some of the claims and would like to dig deeper.

What can I say, I'm delighted that I have a privilege to live in times where we have the longest peace period. This book goes through the history of a human kind showing how we did evolve and how we did change. How some small actions changed everything. How helping solve one issue helped to address others. What is the relation between giving a choice to give birth and wars? What is the relation between intelligence and fight? I’m happy I did listen to this book, and I highly recommend it to everyone who is saying how awful the world is.

What a Chimera is man! What a novelty, a monster, a chaos, a contradiction, a prodigy! Judge of all things, an imbecile worm; depository of truth, and sewer of error and doubt; the glory and refuse of the universe.

I'd highly recommend this book to anyone, especially those that enjoy insights about the human condition. Although the main argument is quite simple (that violence has declined over time and the present isn't as horrible as people make it out to be) Pinker gives an extremely thorough explanation, drawing upon ideas from various fields including psychology, history, biology, and political science. The book will seem dense at first, but it is engaging and insightful in its entirety. It's changed the way I look at many things and made me more optimistic about the future.

It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, but an undeniable magnum opus on the whole! Obviously, many gross characterizations and tenuous linkages took place (I.e. viewing capitalism as a positive good solely associated with declining violence), but also some really important insights (like the importance of women’s empowerment!)
A must read for those that are constantly judging the past on today's ethical standards and judging the present on a false perception of what the past used to truly be like.
I highly recommend this book, especially to anyone who feels bummed out by the current state of the world.
Inspiring and full of well documented assertions. Abosolutely mindblowing.

An amazing book that shows how much effort was put into developing and writing this masterpiece. Plentiful of research and statistics which show how violence has declined over the centuries which is contrary to what a good number of people think.
Long, painful, but so so important and introspective. Worth the patience.
This book was so looong. Took ages to read. Good tho, I liked it.
