I probably didn't need the unabridged version. This was good, but it got long. I would have enjoyed the same conclusion with about half the detail. Overall, worthwhile read/listen. And good on audiobook.
Really love this book. The world IS getting better despite the pessimism others would have you believe.

Fascinating! Very well researched and a complex topic, Pinker puts data and fact base to work in this well written book that contrasts our current (peaceful) times against human histories violent context.

I believe this is the best non-fiction book I've ever read. I can't fairly summarize it, but the general thesis is that humans are much less violent today than we ever have been--both vs the recent past and on the historical scale--and it isn't even close. Excellent statistical takedown of nostalgia and viewing the past through rose-colored lenses.
Not an easy read but certainly insightful of human behavior and we have had enough empathy historically or perhaps self awareness that we have instituted laws to keep us in check.
Incredibly comprehensive book

A very well-written book. The wide perspective of Steven Pinker doesn't let place for doubt or misunderstanding. However the book might feel a little tiring now and then because it's indeed very detailed. Of course that's exactly what's important for a great majority of people and it can be very helpful to know the details in a debate for example. But if you don't have much time for reading and you are more into straight forward books I suggest reading a summary or watching some debates and speeches of Steven Pinker on the matter.
Excellent and uplifting book. Highly recommended!4.4/5
A fantastic book that makes "hope and courage" and explains why the violence is decreasing in human history :)

As usual, the book is way too long but it offers a nuanced, well-argued, and evidence-based attempt at an explanation of why the level of violence in humans has declined in history. A must-read for all those who think there is no progress.

Sublime moral history of our world from the stage of chimps to 21st century homo sapiens. The book diggs deep into the anthropological, psychological, neurobiological, and economical aspects of our nature and brings fact-based evidence to leave you with a better understanding of how we reached the most peaceful and prosperous times in history.

This is one of the most important books in years. The author (a noted Harvard social scientist) collects an enormous body of statistical and historical facts in support of his thesis that human society is slowly becoming more and more averse to violence. This is a conclusion that will be hotly denied by many, but they such persons are going to have to confront the huge body of facts that Pinker presents in this monumental 802-page book.Here are a few highlights of the book:1. Ancient primitive societies were hardly the Edenic paradises that they are often pictured to be. Careful analyses of skeletons from archaeological sites have confirmed that roughly 15% of these individuals died a violent death. Among more modern pre-state societies, similar analyses show 25% violent death. 2. In a list of the 21 "Worst Things People Have Done to Each Other," which ranks the wars and massacres with the highest death tolls, the 20th century indeed is well-represented: WWII tops the list, following closely by the Chinese cultural revolution. But when these episodes are normalized by world population at the time, then WWII drops to #9. Number 1 on the normalized list is the little-known 8th century An Lushan Revolt, which resulted in the loss of 2/3 of the Chinese empire's population.3. The "long peace" among major powers since WWII has confounded the predictions of many that large-scale war is inevitable in our time. Pinker emphasizes that perhaps the most interesting post-WWII statistic of all is zero: Zero is the number of times that nuclear weapons have been used in combat; zero is the number of times that the two Cold War superpowers fought each other on the battlefield; zero is the number of times that any of the top 40 great powers have fought each other (since 1953); zero is the number of wars fought between any European nation (prior to this there were an average of two armed conflicts per year going back to at least 1400); zero is the number of developed countries that have expanded their territory by conquering another country; and zero is the number of internationally recognized states that have gone out of existence through conquest.4. While the modern world, especially in the West, agonizes over even remote chances of harm to today's children, for much of human history little ones faced a much greater risk: infanticide. Anthropologist Laila Williamson found until very recently, between 10 and 15 percent of all babies were killed shortly after birth. 5. The U.S. crime rate rose during the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s until about 1992, but has declined since then. By 2010, the homicide rate had fallen to just 4.8 per 100,000 residents, down by more than a factor of two from its peak. Other measures of violent crime, and even property crime, have followed in unison. In the wake of the 2008-2011 recession, with millions out of work, losing homes and in desperate economic straits, crime rates have fallen even further, confounding criminologists who had predicted sharp increases.6. Pinker points out that by today's standards, even great statesmen of recent history would be considered hopelessly bigoted and violence-happy. Theodore Roosevelt excused the decimation of Native Americans as necessary to prevent the continent from becoming a "game preserve for squalid savages." Woodrow Wilson blocked black students from Princeton, praised the Ku Klux Klan, and declared that any hyphenated American "carries a dagger that he is ready to plunge into the vitals of this Republic." Franklin Roosevelt jailed 100,000 U.S. citizens in a concentration camp because they were of the Japanese race. And Winston Churchill declared that the Aryan stock "is bound to triumph," and that India is "a beastly people with a beastly religion" [Pinker2011b, pg. 658].Also of considerable interest in Pinker's analysis of the factors behind these changes. One major factor is the rise of large, effective systems of democratic government, which Pinker terms the "Leviathan" effect, named after the title of a book by 17th century philosopher Thomas Hobbes. Others include the Civilizing Effect and the Pacifying Effect, wherein people have begun to see other societies as cooperating partners capable of trade and mutual enrichment, instead of loathsome aliens that must be eliminated. It also seems that society as a whole, perhaps through improved education, is better able to see the world from the eyes of others. Whatever the reason, it is a trend that we should cherish and understand better. Pinker's conclusion resonates with both hope and gratitude: "For all the tribulations in our lives, for all the troubles that remain in the world, the decline of violence is an accomplishment we can savor, and an impetus to cherish the forces of civilization and enlightenment that made it possible."

Steven Pinker’s The Better Angels of our Nature attempts to explain two main points. The first point is that violence has decreased from the Paleolithic hunter-gatherer age to the modern era. This theory should be anecdotally evident to any student of history or pre-twentieth century literature. The author stated, however, that this theory may be contrary to popular opinion. The second, and more important, point was an explanation of this decline in violence. Pinker posits that this decline in violence was caused by both exogenous historical factors and psychological factors. The historical factors were the establishment of state governments and the predominance of classical rationalist liberalism that fostered such notions as individualism and human rights. These historical and philosophical developments, in turn, created an environment where the psychological capacity of man for self-control, skepticism, and reason (and perhaps even empathy) triumphed over his darker psychological impulses such as aggression, revenge, and sadism. 	Some of the author’s conclusions as to the “whys” of this decline in violence often may be considered off-the-cuff, unsourced speculation, and many reviewers have gleefully taken the author to task over this in arguing that this work was the biggest waste of time and resources since Ishtar. The importance of this work is that this is, to my knowledge, the first comprehensive work that attempts to catalogue this historical decline in human violence with an explanation of why such decline occurred. This work may not be perfect, but is a solid first step that other researchers can build upon, or attempt to debunk, in a way that furthers our understanding of the subject matter. That some of the author’s mini-conclusions in various subsections of this work may appear odd or appear to be bald speculation is no reason to write this book off as total rubbish.	Other reviews have commented that this book is disorganized and/or hard to follow. I could not disagree with those assertions more. The work is extremely well-organized. The preface tells the reader exactly what Pinker is attempting to prove, and why, in very simple English. The preface then summarizes each chapter. The first six chapters deal with the historical decline in violence over different eras, and chapters seven and eight deal with the psychological aspects of violence and non-violence. Each chapter is divided into sub-sections, which present a sub-issue and sub-conclusion. The conclusion then basically re-states the preface with a few examples from the psychology section thrown in to further buttress the author’s theses. In fact, this book is so well-organized and clear that a reader could probably understand about 90% of it by just reading the preface and conclusion only. (Which is perhaps what many reviewers did. I’ve never seen so many reviewers –including professional reviewers -- baldly state they didn’t finish the book, or didn’t read the whole book. Since when is this acceptable?) In addition, each chapter is well-sourced, with clear endnotes, along with a voluminous bibliography. The book also has a detailed index. 	For those of you that have been worried that the book is “too long,” consider this: of the 802 pages in the hardcover edition that I read, over 100 of those pages comprise the endnotes, bibliography, and index. The actual text of the book is only about 700 pages, and a good portion of that space is filled with graphs, charts, and pictures. Therefore, the book is quite a bit shorter than it appears.	The tone of the author was at times off-putting. The author often drops into a snarky, overly casual tone, for instance calling the Bible “a wiki,” making unnecessary and silly pop-culture references such as to the 1970’s group The Village People, and frequently writing in the first person and about his own personal experiences. The author’s tone nevertheless does not detract from his arguments or research in any tangible way.	In conclusion, whether you find the author’s conclusions well-supported, or unsupported rampant speculation – or whether the author’s thesis re-affirms what you always innately thought about society, or whether his thesis completely offends every belief that you formerly possessed -- there is no denying that The Better Angels of our Nature is an landmark work in its field. On a side note, the controversy that this work has generated should also show that as a society, Americans aren’t being “dumbed down” like many media pundits like to claim. The fact that an 800 page academic work of this nature is being widely read and discussed goes to show that people on the whole are probably better educated and more intellectual than ever, no?

Even though this book is seven years old, it rings as especially relevant in these days -- when everything you see / read in the media makes it seem as if the sky is falling and we on the brink of anarchy. This book takes a step back and gives a broader view of the history and decline of violence (of many types, from wars to domestic violence to animal rights). It's a great reminder that we have, in fact, made a lot of progress even if things aren't perfect today.Don't be put off of this book by the one and two star reviews -- mostly blowhards that want to debate one or two of the many points (and there are many debatable things in an 800 page book) of the book and claim that the book is worthless if those are shown wrong (missing the point, in my opinion).
Incrediblely written book. Pinker is the real deal when it comes to arguing a hypothesis, even if it takes him 700 pages to do it.

Possibly the most thought provoking book I have ever read/will ever read. It has permanently changed how I see humanity. This is in places both one of the darkest and also the most uplifting books I have ever read. It gives you a true appreciation for the horrors that humans have done to each in the name of Justice, Religion and in places just for entertainment. At the same time it shows you how and why we have improved as a species and why hopefully these trends will continue. This book isn’t complacent it don’t pretend or brush over that awful things still happen all around the world and that all of the trends recorded may go backwards but the author gives reasons to hope the world will continue to improve. It was very satisfying to see references to other things I have read pop up throughout. Unlike many other big idea books that I’ve read which throw down a massive, controversial, theory and then cherry pick evidence which supports it, I felt reading this that the author had given all theories a fair hearing and dealt with counter arguments effectively, rather than just pretending that they didn’t exist. It’s a shame that the 850 page word count will put many people off. Probably would have put me off if I’d known that before I ordered it!
A tedious read (especially for those who don't love stats), but also incredibly well thought-out and convincing.

Hard to believe that I not only listened to a 36-hour audiobook but also never get tired of it. While it helps that the subject matter was inherently interesting (not to mention, right up my morbid alley), I gotta give Pinker credit for keeping the material engaging throughout. He has a knack for laying out details and arguments with clarity and energy--a gift that more nonfiction authors need to acquire.

This is an impressive book in places, but is marred by political bias in some places, where it reads more like a political tract in support of so-called "liberal democracy". For example, Pinker makes the claim that free-markets value empathy, when this is a highly questionable claim, given that monopolies which market forces lead to often cannot be overthrown by consumers, meaning that empathy is hardly necessary on the part of corporate executives, and consumers themselves may not care about the actions of companies. For example, consumers of fossil fuels and of companies which avoid taxes simply don't take the perspective of the people the companies affect negatively.He also seeks to defend modern "liberal democracies", in my view, far too often. For example, on p.156, he shrugs off modern torture by democratic governments by first rationalizing them on the basis that they are carried out in "interrogation and counter insurgency operations", implying that they have something akin to a 'just cause', and then claiming that the use of torture by countries such as the United States is "universally decried", which is patently not the case, given that some US Government officials continue to be unapologetic about it, never mind some media pundits.He writes that 'fascism and communism view opponents as irredemably evil and are expansionist', but the same can easily be said of liberal democracies, which have quite openly engaged in a number of usually illegal wars to "spread democracy" and rid the target country of evil, for instance in Iraq when the United States and the United Kingdom did so. In fact, social democracies seem to be the only societies which aren't expansionist.On p.295, Pinker writes that "the occasional socialist" opposed war, which is just a blatant slander, given that socialists have been integral to antiwar movements throughout the centuries. In fact, many of the antiwar pioneers who he cites - Bertrand Russell, Leo Tolstoy and George Bernard Shaw, just to name a few - were all socialists. In fact, socialists have been integral to all of the Rights Revolutions he lists as well. He also claims that Israel has "acceded to international pressure to relinquish most of the territory it has occupied" on p.312, when in fact it continues to expand its occupation and annexation of Palestinian territory.On p.318, Pinker notes that the US supported "anticommunist forces in several proxy wars", but they were not so much anti-communists as fascist and capitalist juntas and terrorists. Later on in the book, he again adds an unnecessary political line, when he talks about capitalism leading to peace, believing arguments in favour of this hypothesis to be "sure to leave leftists speechless". Apparently, he doesn't know that many, if not most, "leftists" are not opposed to capitalism playing a role in the economy.He also says that "communal sharing supports the mindset behind genocidal ideologies", which, again, may have been true in some cases, but certainly isn't true in every case. He states this as if it is necessarily the case.Other than that, Pinker occasionally makes other illogical arguments. To support his contention that civilian deaths as a proportion of the total deaths in war have not increased, he notes that WWII "decimated civilians with a holocaust, a blitz, firebombings of cities in Germany and Japan, and not one but two atomic explosions". Yet, just because these things occurred, all it shows is that civilian deaths were high in WWII - it doesn't really support the claim that civilian deaths as a proportion of the total number of deaths has not increased.His statistics on hunter-gatherer societies have also been powerfully challenged by the anthropologist R. Brian Ferguson, although his other statistics hold up when subjected to scrutiny. All in all, the Civilizing Process (apart from the questionable link to 'gentle commerce'), Feminization, the Expanding Circle, the Humanitarian Revolution and the Rights Revolutions hold up very well. His section on 'Reason' in the 'Better Angels' section of the books was excellent, in my view, although the correlation between IQ (including tests that had nothing to do with abstract reasoning) and (classical) liberalism does not prove that abstract reasoning causes classical liberalism which causes a decline in violence.

What can one say about a book like this? It covers such an immense amount of material and moves of vast periods of time and I can't say that I have the expertise to evaluate the details and references of Pinker's argument that violence has decline over the time of human history. I do think that he argues his case quite well though and I particularly likes two of his points, firstly that we often become forgetful about the violence of the past so that we think that what we have experienced must be worse that what has been before. Secondly, he argues for the fact that reading, education and knowledge has been a key factor for the violence to decline. This is not surprising if one is acquainted with Pinker's writing, but what is very surprising is that the reading he advocates is that of fiction! His argument is that the introduction of the printing press and publication of novels meant that people were forced to take a first person perspective in another person's story. This meant that people became more inclined to see also real people's perspectives from their own standpoint.A further interesting point here is the argument that it is the change of culture that has been the cause for the decline of violence. Pinker uses much sociological research to support this claim. That is a further surprise considering his view of sociology. He doesn't, of course, use the most "poststructuralist" theorists, but still. In my view Pinker would for example really appreciate the writings of Christian Smith. Pinker's argument that culture is the force that has caused the decrease is in a way not surprising since he argues that the human nature is one and the same since the pleistocene era. But, to argue for such a strong influence of culture is still remarkable in view of his previous writing. It should be said though that when it comes to morals Pinker, in my view, has always been very close to a social constructivist.So, to the sources then, his use of them comes across as trustworthy and impressive, and Pinker's writing is of course excellent. However, when it comes to the areas where I have a little knowledge I start to be a little suspicious, say his sources for his interpretation of the Old Testament, then he refers to a journalist for example, rather than a biblical scholar. His argument about the violence in the OT certainly forces one to think about what type of source for religious faith that is, but there is not much indication that there might be another side to the interpretation of the OT.Having said that, The Better Angels of Our Nature is really quite a breath of fresh air in terms of the view of religion presented in it. Pinker argues that faith in a higher power is a bad solution if one wants to decrease violence, increased individualism and a reliant Levianth is the solution!, and a belief in a higher power is simply superstitious and stupid in his view. But, having said that Pinker does not argue that all religion is bad. Rather, he points out that some religious expressions, quakers and anabaptists!, for example, have played a significant role for the decrease in violence. A very contested argument though is his view that Martin Luther King Jr acted the way he did NOT because of this Christian faith, but because he deviated from his Christian faith. That will certainly be provocative for many.Anyway, Pinker's conclusion is that not all religion is bad, rather particular religion is bad as well as particular religious movements are good. His conclusion from this though is a little strange I think because he argues that this means that we should try to move away from all religion because the overall all idea is bad. But, is this not exactly the same with his view of the need for a strong leviathan? Surely some leviathan is bad ans some is good (liberal democracy with individualism). That does not mean that the idea of leviathan should be done away with? Yet, still, the fact that Pinker is a little nuanced in his view of religion is certainly to be praised and it is one of the reasons for why I would not want him to be included in that movement called "New Atheism". His writing is simply too good for that I think.

I must admit, as an integralist and evolutionary (mainly influenced by Ken Wilber’s work), I enjoyed the book very much. It was a delight to walk these long 800 pages in Pinker’s shoes and see the world fully through modern rational scientific perspective—in its dignity and disaster. It was interesting to see how far can one highly praised mainstream academician reach (in explaining the important matters of our world) until the objective truths reach their limits.All the empirical research and his charts were just on spot and well presented, but the subjective truths and soft sciences could be much better represented. Pinker is not a pioneering genius trying to give something staggeringly new to the world, but rather telling the same old Darwinian evolution story in a slightly new way. But he's a good story teller and throws many fascinating facts on the path—good food for the thought. Did you know that Louisiana became the last American state to ban cockfights in 2008?„...from where we sit on the time line, most trends point peaceward. We may not be entitled to a theory of everything, but we do need a theory that explains why so many somethings point the same way“.Unfortunately Pinker is not integrally informed—which would give him a beautiful (AQAL) map that represents nearly a theory of everything, exactly what he’s looking for—and that’s why he struggled with many fallacies, dilemmas and contradictions. Here is a good example as any:„It’s long been known that mature democracies have better educated and smarter populations, but mature democracies have more of everything that is good in life, and we can’t tell what causes what. Perhaps more democratic countries are also richer and can afford more schools and libraries, which make their citizens better educated and smarter, rather than the other way around.“Pretty often he reasons: „What was before? Egg or chicken? Education or democracy/schools? Nature or Nurture? Exogenous or endogenous? Inner or outer? Individual or collective?“ In integral aperspectival philosophy it’s OK to embrace multiple perspectives and there is no need to waste time and paper on this kind of debate. Inner and outer, one and many, are rather co-arising—one cannot exists without other. Or like we say in integral theory these four basic dimensions or quadrants are tetra-arising. Fixation only on one, or some of them, is called quadrant absolutism (where Pinker finds himself pretty often).Also, not being fully aware of inner subjective dimensions of life (and corresponding methodologies and studies), Pinker doesn’t use developmental studies as thoroughly as he could (though he mentions Piaget and Carol Gilligan). That’s why he’s stuck in the ‘myth of the given’, assuming that everyone should see the world as a rational scientist—ignoring the fact that there are also pre-rational and trans-rational views to the world. Hence, he mixes up higher trans- (or post-) stages with lower pre-stages and makes a classical pre/trans fallacy—putting all the excising higher stages (e.g. postmodern and integral) in the same camp with lower stages (e.g. magical and mythical). That’s also one reason why he totally ignores great wisdom traditions—dealing with phenomenological world, mind states, flow states, reducing pain and suffering tremendously—and mixes them up with mythic-literal religions.In overall, for integralists, this book gives a great deal of objective facts that help to carve out the right quadrants even more in details and to help to bring integral maps (e.g. AQAL—all quadrants, all levels, all lines, all states, all types) even more closer to the mainstream thinking and academia. What I also enjoyed was the general overview about history and its important stages: The Pacification Process (nonstates), The Civilizing Process, The Humanitarian Revolution, The Long and New Peace (inc. The Rights Revolutions). But yes, it doesn’t come even close to Ken Wilber’s magnum opus 'Sex, Ecology, Spirituality' which gives much clearer, more complete and coherent presentation about history, violence, suffering and love.

In The Better Angels of Our Nature, Steven Pinker offers up a thesis which, for some, may seem wildly unbelievable. Pinker contends that we are currently living in the least violent period ever known in human history. Using the number of violent deaths relative to the population of the time, Pinker examines trends in murder, war, terrorism and violent crime, and charts a consistent decline in their prevalence in cultures around the world. Having established this decline, Pinker sets out to find the psychological and sociological factors which contribute to the trend. The structure of the book is predicated on the idea that people will find the thesis difficult to swallow, as Pinker explains in the introduction. He spends six exhaustive chapters—well over half of this 800 page tome—in extensive statistical demonstrations of the decline. While the trends themselves are interesting, the constant barrage of statistics will likely wear thin for the reader who doesn’t find the thesis as difficult to believe as the author assumes. Overall, these statistics are well-explained for the average reader, and clearly illustrated in numerous charts and graphs. However, an understanding of statistics would undoubtedly be beneficial to any critical analysis of Pinker’s findings. Once he has established the statistical decline of violence, Pinker spends the second part of the book examining the sociological and psychological factors that encourage and inhibit violence, as well as identifying a number of popular culprits which are not actually borne out by the numbers. For example, he found that weaponry, affluence, resources and religion, while sometimes significant, were not consistent factors. The explanations rely heavily on neurobiology and the history of governance, necessitating numerous detours into the basics of these disciplines, and their relevant principles. Pinker finds extremely strong correlations between government and commerce, and the decline of violence. Not unexpectedly, The Better Angels of Our Nature makes for heavy emotional, as well as intellectual, reading. A discussion of the nature and history of violence necessitates the inclusion of a variety of stomach-churning examples, such as the burning of cats for public entertainment in medieval Europe. However, these examples prove instrumental for demonstrating the extent to which we exaggerate contemporary violence and discount historical violence. Pinker has a deft hand for defamiliarization, a technique he uses to draw historical violence in perspective with its modern counterpart. For example, although we accept the cross, a historical instrument of violence, as the symbol for Christianity, Pinker points out that our modern sensibilities would likely be offended if a group of Holocaust survivors adopted a showerhead as their symbol, or if survivors of the Rwandan genocide rallied around a machete logo. This unusual comparison forces the reader to examine the familiar, even ubiquitous, symbol of the cross with fresh eyes. These numerous violent examples are not trotted out gratuitously, or ad nauseam, but always to illustrate a particular point about how we perceive violence, or why we commit it. Despite the difficulty of getting through this book—it took me over six weeks to read—I would rate it highly, and strongly recommend it for those interested in the subject. I agree with Bill Gate’s assertion that it is “one of the most important books I’ve read—not just this year, but ever.” We need both the optimism and the insight which Pinker’s work provides since, as he points out, the decline of violence is not ineluctable—it could be reversed at any time. That being the case, it’s probably a good idea to understand what we’re doing right, and how we can do better. From http://shayshortt.wordpress.com/2013/...

This book may explain why the zombie apocalypse has been a common horror genre of late. Not that this is dealt with directly, but the book is so expansive in its explanations of other things, why not this as well? More on that later.According to Pinker, in just about every facet of violent behaviour that one can think of, the numbers, certainly in per capita terms, and often in absolute terms? I have pondered the question in more local terms over recent years: are my children safer now than I was at their age, despite, or indeed because of, the increased perception of risk? This book is full of fascinating insights into the reasons for violence and of course, why it has decreased over time. Who would have thought economics is a fundamentally moral social activity; or that the USA is such a violent nation because of a bipolar settlement and premature initiation of democracy; that some US states have an equivalent homicide rate to Papua New Guinea? This is a long book for something this technical, so the wit interspersed amidst its prose (elephant repellent) is welcome. Such is its breadth, that the parallel reads (shift and les Miserables) find an easy fraternity, whilst Life is almost specifically mentioned!Of course, Pinker is dismissive of religious belief and at times overly simplistic in his criticism; however, it is also true that religion has done itself many disfavours by its treatment of others, approval of torture and murder, and justification of such practices long after they should have been disavowed. However, there are areas which I think deserve more balance. Jesus' revolution, derided because of the violence of its climax, represented a radical departure from the violently enforced Pax of the Romans, including the attitude taken toward slavery. The humanitarian revolution was empowered in part by the reading revival inspired by Protestant churches wishing individuals (a second influence) to read the bible for themselves. More recently, scholarship has shown that Christian missionaries in Africa have been a key influence in the civilization of those countries (despite the progress that remains to be made).But these omissions do not detract from the surprising story of how we have ended up living in the remarkable time that we do, the lack of violence perhaps more remarkable than the technology revolution we are experiencing. It is painstaking in its analysis, and a long read as a result. But this is necessary I think. Each chapter generally begins describing some aspect of violence and some of the reasons that are thought to be behind it, then following this with statistical evidence before seeking to find the exogenous factors behind the trends. After looking at the social and historical externals, Pinker then looks at the internal neurological factors that might be affecting and affected by the declining violence. In the end, a few factors turn out to be common in the decline, and not necessarily the ones you might think. Reason gets a nod, religion and wealth disparity do not. For these and other factors, a simplistic opinion is not enough.Without question a must read book which will challenge the preconceptions most of us have. Take a deep breath and jump in!Oh, and the zombies... It turns out that a factor in the decrease in violence is the increase in intelligence from generation to generation, at least for the last two centuries. My theory on horror is that the bad guys speak to some primal fear, in the case of zombies senseless violence. So in some way the genre may be speaking to the fear of the violent and senseless brutality of the past. Sure, not everyone would have drawn that insight, but I'm sure there are plenty there for others to find also.

This book reads like the PhD thesis from a student who knows he has selected way too broad of a topic for his dissertation. Its goal is to convince that all manner of violent crimes and interpersonal actions have diminished over the years since... well, pretty much since the start of recorded history. Additionally it throws in the kitchen sink to make its point using everything from logistic regression to neurological biography to clips from The Honeymooners and lyrics from John Lennon. (Yes, I did say clips from The Honeymooners.)Honestly, I should have known better. This audio book made its way to my reading list despite violating my rule of no books over 30 hours. In my experience, *any* audio book over 30 hours (approximately 600 pages) needs a better editor. And this one was not an exception. With good, editing this book could have come downs to its base positions with probably a 40% reduction of content volume. It gets 2 stars because behind what I saw as the self-indulgent facade of the author, there are a few good points and interesting positions taken.But the real failure of this books comes near the end when a position is taken that, after the George W. Bush administration, non-intellectual leadership, nationalism and other forms of isolationism is a thing of the past. (My words, I don't recall the author's exact words.) In the Trump era this shows itself to be not only incorrect, but laughably so. In a mere 8 years of growing partisanship and tribalism, the complete antithesis of intellectual leadership is back is a way no one but a satire such as Idiocracy could have imagined. (If this book can site The Honeymooners in its text, I can site Idiocracy in my review.) Furthermore, the leadership of Donald J. Trump and the modern GOP is making quite obvious that worse angels of our nature can take forms of oppression to a more modern high.

"Violence has declined over long stretches of time, and today we may be living in the most peaceable era in our species' existence." (Location 128) This is, perhaps, the primary sentiment of this latest work by Prof. Steven Pinker. And for all my reservations with his ideology (progressivism) and his lack of critique surrounding statistical analyses I cannot help but feel this is a brilliant, insightful, and profoundly optimistic book. Optimism is something which has been, intellectually, in short supply for a great many decades. Though this seems odd because between the Long Peace (since the end of the second world war) and the New Peace (the end of the cold war) this is something we should all be feeling about our collective future. However, pessimism seems to be the general sentiment: from Climate Change to the geopolitics of China and India. Back to The Better Angels of Our Nature. The book is not without its faults-An out of control Progressivist ideology -Feminization theories which are deeply suspicious-Left Wing political agenda...as read by Americans-A mostly uncritical attitude to statistical analyses (some is suggested but mostly as a sop)-The inherent `squishiness' of the Social Sciences-An aggressive atheism which discounts all the positives attributes of Religion in favour of Old Testament blood thirsty hyperbole (and some from the New Testament). Personal note: I'm an atheist. -A rather hostile discounting of conservatives and conservatism (again, American in perspective): see page 662 and following for a sample of this. Note: I read the Kindle Edition on my iPad.For all of the above weaknesses and others, this is still a timely, important, concise, and articulate peace of optimism...with provisos (Pinker's not mine). Perhaps some of Prof. Pinker's most interesting observations are why he believes the world remains pessimistic about violence. One of my favourites is why the world, generally, feels violence is getting worse when it is actually declining: "The decline of violent behaviour has been paralleled by a decline in the attitudes that tolerate or glorify violence, and often the attitudes are in the lead." p. 155Our tolerance for violence appears to have fallen faster than violence actually has. This, perhaps, could force a greater decline in violence or it could have unforeseen negative consequences. At the moment this remains uncertain...to my way of thinking. This is a book which deserves several book length reviews and much closer analysis than I have given it here but it is brilliant and articulate while occasionally slipping into arrogance and ideological myopia (see progressivism and atheism amongst others). I did not give this book a full 5 stars because of the problems I have cited above, but it is a brilliant and important work that is both accessible and comprehensive (if the reader is willing to put in a little time). Highly Recommended AddendumThere are two other reasons I only gave this book 4 stars and that has to do with the book's formatting. 1) References/Endnotes are not activated 2)The index is not activated either. These are two very serious problems for readers of the e-Editions of this book. Some may feel this is not the place for this criticism but I would, respectfully, disagree because it makes looking up sources, so that I may engage more fully with the text, very very laborious. This is the typical way that publishers handle ebooks...haphazardly at best. Then they over-price them...which only promotes piracy.

This made me think of a passage in A Canticle for Liebowitz by Walter M. Miller, Jr., published in 1959: [The world has been destroyed by nuclear war, and monks are preparing to go to space to flee the clear threat of a repeat]: "The closer men came to perfecting for themselves a paradise, the more impatient they seemed to become with it, and with themselves as well. They made a garden of pleasure, and became progressively more miserable with it as it grew in richness and power and beauty; for then, perhaps, it was easier to see that something was missing in the garden, some tree or shrub that would not grow. When the world was in darkness and wretchedness, it could believe in perfection and yearn for it. But when the world became bright with reason and riches, it began to sense the narrowness of the needle's eye and that rankled for a world no longer willing to believe or yearn."This book argues the opposite: that an increase in reason (if not riches -- he says privation does not necessarily lead to violence) has led to a reduction in violence across the board and an unprecedented period of peace. I think it has an important, critical message. Violence has declined and for most people life is safer and more secure than it has ever been. We are amazingly amnesiac about history, even the recent past. When I mention this book to people, they raise their eyebrows at the title. The media is so good at promoting anger and fear that people don't even notice the safety and freedom we do enjoy.There were so many interesting things here that I never thought about before, such as "mission creep" -- activists keeping up the pressure by denying that any progress has been made. I hear this all the time in the negative comments about the current state of things. People really don't know how hard life was for our ancestors, even a couple of generations ago. This book made me feel more hopeful, not easy for a lifelong pessimist.I am a bit skeptical. It's a long, complex argument covering a lot of ground. Due to incomplete data, Pinker has had to fill in a lot of blanks and interpret much data to come to his conclusions. I have to wonder how much motivated reasoning he used. Did he have the final title in mind when he began his research? (I read that he wrote the book in response to the question, "What are you hopeful about?," which is rather a leading question.) I am his age and lived through the same cold war and the humanitarian revolutions. And I grew up in North Dakota, practically a suburb of Canada. It was easy to nod along, thinking it all makes perfect sense, but then I read a negative review and realized I was employing my own bias as someone who was raised in a conservative place and time. I've read Thinking Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman and have been viewing Steven Novella's "Your Deceptive Mind" lectures on The Great Courses, so I keep second guessing my own thinking. Pinker is careful to acknowledge the gaps in the data and human bias, including his own. He's certainly not promoting a Pollyannaish or a Panglossian view, but he's cautiously optimistic.I can only look at the world through the eyes of classical liberalism, as that is all I've experienced. And as I recently spent some time in my home state, I'm aware of just how parochial my views could be. And correlation does not equal causation -- maybe it's a coincidence that countries with liberal democracies are the best places to live. However, in spite of these misgivings, I think Pinker makes a very good argument indeed.
Likely the most important book written in the last 50 years.

I never quite finished this massive tome, despite often finding it interesting and even exchanging emails with the author about a picayune error that I found in its pages. Its message is hopeful, and I hope it's true: despite the impression you might get from the news, human life in the 21st century is improving across a wide range of metrics of well-being. Globally, lifespans are increasing, diseases decreasing, education and literacy are more common, war and crime less frequent and less deadly. From the criticism of Pinker that I've read online, you'd think he was claiming that there is some mystical force moving through history nudging us in the direction of paradise; that our progress is inevitable and irreversible; that no-one anywhere has any cause to complain; and that we ought to just sit back contentedly on our laurels. The criticism is unfair and can be refuted by simply quoting the book. Pinker knows that plenty of people are still suffering as much as anyone has in history, and that there's much work yet to be done. He knows that any progress is fragile could be reversed. His point is to make more people cognizant of the progress that has occurred and to cultivate a greater appreciation of the reason (he believes) why: the spread of science, technology and the rational ideals of the Enlightenment. Still, I'm less optimistic than Steven Pinker. Even granting his data (which is disputed), the world is still filled with planet-annihilating weapons, with ethnic, nationalist, religious and economic animosities, with endless reserves of human ignorance, arrogance, malice, stupidity and greed. Any and all progress can be undone almost overnight. Technologies that can improve human life generally have the power to harm it, and can do so regardless of intent, in ways that cannot be predicted or controlled. If I live to be a very old man, I suspect it will be long enough to expose Pinker's thesis as disastrously naive. (I'd be happy to discover I was wrong. That's the one good thing about being a pessimist: surprises are pleasant things.)P.S. 4/5/20 Perhaps it's still too early in the Covid 19 crisis to say for sure, but millions of deaths, the collapse of the global economy, and the rise of new totalitarianisms doesn't seem improbable. The thesis of The Better Angels appears weaker than ever. I wish it wasn't so.5/30/20 Covid so far doesn't seem to have been nearly as deadly worldwide as the worst initial projections, even with social distancing, feared. The world appears to be on the verge of opening back up again, how wisely no-one can yet say. We'll find out, I suppose, if there's another outbreak, as some experts claim likely in the winter. It may be a long time before we eradicate or cure the disease, if ever. Covid is part of our world for at least our near future. Other pandemics will also emerge. On the geopolitical front, civil unrest across the U.S. over police brutality could be the prelude to a full scale civil war. We may be witnessing, or soon witness, a John Brown moment. The Communist Party of China meanwhile moves against the quasi-independence of Hong Kong. The party faces insurrection at the same moment that ties with the American government are extraordinarily strained. Trump talks about resuming nuclear testing. During an election year, with record setting unemployment. To me it looks like a powder keg.  Pinker's thesis seems even weaker now than in my last update. Stay tuned.

Steven Pinker seems to have a habit of writing important books (previous topics: language, in general; human nature, in general, "How The Mind Works" for God's sake!), and though this is the first one I've actually read, I doubt it will be the last. Whereas other authors (Malcolm Gladwell especially) seem to be going after the Least Publishable Unit, Pinker wants to tackle the big questions, and provide them with big answers. Notice the plural there. This is not a book about a "tipping point" or the "wisdom of crowds", but about the trajectory and trends of the entirety of human history. What Pinker is arguing for goes against every popular media trope and man-on-the-street bit of common sense that we've accumulated over the past 100 years. These are the most peaceful times that we have ever lived in. The 20th Century was, despite what we've been told, probably the most peaceful century of human existence. There is less assault, rape and murder now than ever before in human history. To prove his point, Pinker uses findings from anthropology, psychology, politics, history, and economics, amongst other subjects. This is a big book that definitely needs to be big.This quickly leads me to the first tiring thing about this book, which is the 300-400 pages of graphs, and the concomitant discussion of data collection and statistical analysis. Getting through this was definitely a chore, and I know some people who never managed to get through it. But this is a necessary evil, I think, because many people certainly disagree with his thesis.  However, because it's so big, there were few detractions and criticisms that I could find in any review that weren't in some way pre-empted in the text. In fact, it seems like many reviewers' criticisms resulted from an incomplete reading, or an incomplete rememberance of what Pinker actually wrote. That being said, for a book with this wide a scope, there are some things that he glosses over, or mentions only in passing. Some of these are forgiveable, but others are not. For example, he argues weakly for the effectiveness and necessity of the rise of prison-culture in America, which now imprisons a greater percentage of its own population than any other country on Earth. As far as I know this has not been effective, and Pinker did not say anything to change my mind. An example of a more forgiveable flaw is that the book is centred largely on Europe and North America, though he explains that this is because much of the rest of the world had non-existent or spotty record keeping before the last couple hundred years, and I think this is an understandable excuse. It is definitely written from a point of view, as one review put it, it is "more discursive than deductive", but the point of view is backed up by literally hundreds of pages of footnotes and citations, so unless you disagree with entire fields of inquiry or schools of thought (reductionism, evolutionary psychology, liberal humanism), you're likely to find his argument persuasive.This is a very important book for anyone who is interested in warfare, history, culture, psychology or sociology. I think for many people it can, and will, fundamentally change the way they look at the world and the people they share it with. And is there really any more that you could ask for from a book?

This is really about three or four books in one - it’sa big read! The theme is that humans have civilized ourselves to dramatically lower levels of violence over the centuries.While our warmaking technologies have gotten much more deadly, and two of the most violent wars ever were in the last century, nevertheless the number, violence and duration has inexorably declined. Pinker cites lots of quantitative history to demonstrate this fact, and it reads well.In addition, violence between individuals, humans and animals, and even out groups, has demonstrably declined. The book was written before George Floyd, but I believe Pinker would make the case that the magnitude of the public response, world wide, is an illustration of how violence, when it happens, is less and less tolerated by the norms of society.Progress is not monotonic, but the trends are clear.Pinker brings in a lot of scientific ideas to explain and motivate these changes, from evolution to psychology, and is eager to see where these forces take the race in the future!

Overall I have to recommend this book, despite the fact that it's heavy and full of horrific information. I recommend it because it's eye-opening. If you have any doubts that the world is a much, much, much more peaceful place than it has ever been (and most of us do, because that's the opposite of the picture presented in daily media) then just steep yourself for a while in this book and its statistics. They are Legion. They are also depressing. Except, of course, for the fact that the world is so incredibly much better than it used to be. That's hopeful. And so I recommend it. 	I would actually have given this book five stars, despite all its horrific-ness, if it weren't for the author's smug fundamentalism in his own belief system.	He's on a tear against all religions except his own, which is scientific materialism. In the midst of the enormous mounds of research he presents, showing that all the institutions of mankind have been horrifically violent throughout the vast majority of history, he picks out religions as somehow magically causative of violence while presenting the others as merely reflective of it. And he insists that this violence is somehow endemic to religious ideals, not perversions of them. But when addressing the fact that his own religion inspired the murder of twelve million people he claims that that was not at all the same thing -- the perversion of his belief system is fundamentally different from the perversion of others'.	He also goes out of his way to attribute negative cultural norms to religions, such as when he locates female circumcision as a Muslim practice rather than a cultural one which is deeply imbedded in a broad spectrum of sub-Saharan African cultures, regardless of religion. And as the cherry on top he demotes the Reverend Dr. King from a Christian to a vague secular do-gooder, claiming that this man who studied both religion and philosophy and then did great things must clearly have been motivated only by the philosophy because... well, he can't think of a reason, but he's going to assert it anyway because it makes him feel more comfortable in his worldview.	He also suffers from a peculiar cultural bigotry that refuses to consider the worldviews of others as sincere. The man is not stupid. When he lists, for example, the persecution of people who refused to worship the local deities or who practiced witchcraft as being irrational persecution of people committing "crimes that have no victims" he shows a willful blindness to recognize that members of those cultures honestly believed that an insult to the gods could bring disaster on the whole population or that evil magic actually existed and could be used to cause assault and murder. Whether the author agrees with these beliefs, or even whether they are ultimately true, is irrelevant to the question of whether the people in those cultures were convinced that they were and were acting rationally. 	This book is definitely problematic. But, overall, the facts which it brings to light and the implications they make about the history and future of mankind so greatly overshadow the author's personal weaknesses that the book is well worth reading.
This book was really interesting, long, and full of many ideas. I’m not ready to give it a full review or rate it yet. I think I may need to read it again.

I gone through the “Better angel of our nature” by Steven Pinker; professor of psychology at Harvard university. The central thesis of the book is that we live in a less violent, less cruel and more peaceful era compared to the world that our ancestors lived in. Prof. Pinker recounts humanitarian revolutions, the long peace, the new peace and the democratic peace and their role in reducing violence. He stress that enlightenment, the rights movements, reasoning, civilizing process are the major modules which led to reduction of violence. The book with more than 850 pages may be difficult to digest for young non-Western readers, me included, but I still recommend it to my fellows. Cheers!Note: Unfortunately, I don’t have a PDF version of this book.

Pinker in his preface makes his thesis very clear: "This is a big book but it has to be. I have to convince you that violence really has gone down over the course of history, knowing that the very idea invites skepticism, incredulity, and sometimes anger. Our cognitive faculties predispose us to believe that we live in violent times, especially when they are stoked by media . . ." But what about the 20th century and its wars that were responsible for the deaths of twenty million people? It's this kind of question that Pinker might say invites skepticism. He answers it by pointing out that in terms of overall population, the number of deaths from the wars of the last century are actually statistically small.  Violence of all sorts, according to Pinker, has in fact declined, whether it's societal, as in war, or individual, as in crimes of all sorts, not only in of assaults on individuals, particularly women and children, but in assaults on animals and lower forms of life. The causes are many and complex. Generally, they have to do the powerful forces of modernity - reason in the form of better education, and coexistent with that a greater emphasis on individual rights. Science and t technology play a huge role, making it clear that violence is disruptive, especially to economical development, a yardstick by which modern industrial societies measure themselves. Geographical mobility is important as individuals are no longer constrained by irrational village and tribal customs. Pinker goes to great lengths to discuss any number of subtopics that in one way or another stem from Thomas Hobbes' theories about why humans ae violent. At the heart of them is always something that has to do with what humans hope gain from violence, rational or irrational Some of the topics that Pinker discusses that stood out for me were religion, notions of morality, self-control, revenge, honor, cruelty,authority, the list goes on and on, and concludes, finally, by Pinker stating, "I hope that the numbers I have marshaled have lifted your assessment of the state of the world from the lugubrious conventional wisdom [that violence int he world has gotten worse]. Okay, Pinker convinced me, but reading this book was like being choked to death by a python. Pinker backs up his points with endless graphs, statistics, summaries of behavioral experiments - to the point of tedium and these are what squeezed the life out of this reader. While I didn't disagree with much of what he had to say, it was mind-numbing reading. I gave up and did something I seldom do, just skim-read and relied on summary statements at the end of chapters.

Many profound insights. Only took me two years 😬 But seriously, an important, if at times dense, book. Sort of like a Guns, Germs and Steel but more of an irreverent (less textbook-like) tone. The breadth of data is pretty mind blowing and he makes a compelling argument. His definition of violence may be a bit narrow, and some parts have not aged well (even in just 9 years!) He comes across as a bit pompous at times, but I do feel like I learned a lot and found many of the anecdotes, quotes, studies referenced as good springboards for further investigation.

Once again Pinker has produced another great book (though I think "tome" has the cadence to better convey the work's sheer size). Exhaustively researched and cogently presented, Pinker makes a convincing argument for the decline of violence in the world over the past few centuries. As with his other books, The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined reveals Pinker to be one of the modern day's great thinkers and polymaths, as he demonstrates a greater-than-passing familiarity with disciplines as diverse as history, philosophy, neuroscience, psychology, and literature. Starting with a brief tour of the history of human cruelty, Pinker then dives first into the sociohistorical events that he views played the largest parts in pacifying (and continue to pacify) our species. He then follows up with a wonderfully thorough treatment of human psychology and neuroscience, illuminating clearly and point-by-point how our own wiring and heuristics can influence us towards the path of angel or demon, depending on the context. Pinker wraps up his work with a concise summary of how he views that his previously enumerated sociohistorical trends have been playing the right way to the right parts of our brains, helping to gear us away from the senseless brutality of our past.Pinker's recognition of the fact that the overall decline of violence in the world is likely due to multiple factors is refreshing, given that most who have tried to tackle the subject attempt to explain our historical pacifying trend as the result of only one or two causes. Pinker brings up many of these alternate views, describes their reasoning in detail, and then meticulously explains why he doesn't see them working (in particular, he does a wonderful job of deconstructing the idea that legalized abortions lowered violence in the U.S., which was first popularized by Levitt and Dubner in Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything). Pinker also doesn't shy away from saying he doesn't have all the answers to all the details of violence's decline, though in such cases he still puts forth numerous hypotheses. An excellent book for anyone to read.

I don't think any review I write will do justice to the book, so I'm not going to attempt it. The book covered a wide range of topics (really really really wide) to make a VERY eloquent case for why violence has declined. Because of the breadth of topics, I would encourage everyone to read this book even if you're not particularly interested in the decline of violence.

Let me save you a huge amount of condescension and repetition:Mr Pinker is a sort of neo-Hobbesian whose entire argument hinges on 2 concepts:1) Per-capita/percentage (he frequently alternates between percentage and percapita) death is markedly less under a 'leviathan' model where a centralized State controls the absolute authority to mete out punishments.2) Any exceptions to this rule are to be elaborately explained away, but essentially comes down to claiming individuals or groups involved are somehow 'stateless'.I happen to largely agree with point 1, yet still can't stand the methods and tap-dancing he uses to arrive at it.Onto the book itself:Steven Pinker wanders from point to point like a drunken squirrel. He believes that the plural of 'anecdote' is 'data', and that using wildly inaccurate statistical samples and methods is perfectly fine as long as they support his underlying world view. He cherry-picks quotes, data, and models, and fails to apply basic scientific methods to the data. Instead, he applies confirmation bias to it.The writing is condescending, dull, full of wandering and side-tracking and virtually guaranteed to offend as many people as possible - even people like me who actually *agree* with most of his point.Hiding casual ethnocentrism like his claim that England is the source of all modern civilization behind vague anecdotes and stories (then excusing away the Scottish, Irish, and Welsh, British Imperialism, and anything that might inconveniently disprove his assertion) all the while ignoring entirely the Scandinavians, all of Asia, and even the Middle East is just plain foolish.I find it amusing at best that he uses the *bible* as his source for 'ancient barbarism', somehow deciding that works of fiction are a reliable source for a society. By that same yardstick, Greeks and Romans would have engaged in massive amounts of incest (since their mythology has so much of it), and modern Westerners would be the most violent vigilante culture in history (since our videogames, books, and films revolve largely around one or two people killing scores in some form of 'against the system' narrative)Just avoid this pile of pulp. He may claim to be a 'Cognitive Scientist', but he seems to have long since fallen into the trap of soft science - "if you can't dazzle them with data, baffle them with bullshit".

Good:Pinker is an extremely engaging author. He has an amazing talent for finding interesting quotes and facts. Pinker's linguistic background surfaces in random explanations of origins of words such as rape, dandelion, etc. His language is casual and non-uptight, there is no pussyfooting around taboo subjects such as religion. In this book he has a lot of fun at the expense of: circumcision, old testament, "anthropologists of peace", chivalry, American south, small government proponents, German military, intellectual property, Ukrainians, Jeremy Rifkin, Russian peasants, American presidents, vegetarians.This may be the funniest serious book I've read, but if you feel strongly about superiority of your culture or religion, you may not like this book.The first part of the book is spent discussing various macro-level subjects: conflicts, casualty figures, influence/evolution of social norms and how it all points at the world becoming less violent. This is all very engaging and convincing. If the book ended 2/3rds of the way through, I would rate it 5/5.Bad:After building up my expectations with interesting historical figures, funny quotes, etc Pinker unexpectedly[1] dives into micro [individual] level violence. This part feels like pop-science. It consists of a lot of neuroscience, evolutionary biology, psychology and other soft "sciences". Nothing makes me sadder than suffering through someone drawing conclusions on human behavior based on the poorly understood structure of our brains. It gets worse, Pinker then embarks on business-book/self-help style advice on how we can control human vices. The last 3rd of the book essentially lived up to my worst expectations for this book. Pinker tries to balance out wishy-washy science by beating up on some of the worst examples of neuroscience-gone-wrong, but that still does not excuse the literary crime committed.Conclusion:The first part of the book is amazing and outweighs the kick in the balls that is the last 3rd of the book. Negatives aside, this is the most intellectually stimulating, yet approachable book I've read.[1] After writing this I learned that Pinker is a 'Cognitive Science' bigwig.

While I was reading in a park in Sarajevo a little kid tried to steal my Kindle. Being 6'3" I caught up to him in just a few steps, he quickly handed it back, and we went our separate ways. There was absolutely no violence in this little incident and the thought of perpetrating any didn't even cross my mind. In fact, I would have been appalled if anyone had suggested I should have. But why not? Anyone with a knowledge of history, or who has ever read a Dickens novel, will know that until recent times someone in my shoes would have almost certainly employed violence without a second thought. The natural question is, what changed?Coincidentally, when my kindle was snatched I had been reading a book that tries to explain exactly that. Steven Pinker offers four reasons why the violent option didn't even occur to me:1) I grew up in an effective government which punishes all but the most necessary violence, and furthermore, a good enough government that I respected and thus internalized its mantra of self control.2) I grew up without any rigid system of manly honor/dominance where minor slights are grounds for violent retribution.3) I grew up in a society committed to free communication of stories and ideas, which have taught me how to take another persons perspective and therefore taught me to sympathize with a kid trying to profit off an over-rich foreigner. 4) I grew up learning to practice calculated reason in all things, which not only tells me there is nothing to be gained in such violence but that everyone deserves the same rights to fairness and justice, and striking a child is neither fair nor just.(The fifth reason Steven Pinker gives for the reason violence has declined in the world, that commerce between states allows for peace to be more profitable than even successful war, didn't really apply to this situation.)I find these reasons, and the book entire, convincing. This is an indispensable book to better understand the age we live in now, and even people in general.

I've been listening to this book since February. It is painful-- partially because the torture section is graphic and mostly because pinker is tedious. My goal is to finish the first CD--it's like 8 hours long--and abandon it. Great title, interesting thesis--too damn long.

This is a very intelligent, well-documented new book which claims that we are living in the most peaceful, least violent time in our species' existence. It is truly the ultimate "glass half-full" book. I guarantee you will be challenged when you bring up this topic of conversation anywhere you go. But Pinker has all the documentation, charts, graphs, studies, and evidence you could need to prove that statistically speaking,this is truly the "best of times". And it is important to know this because every time violence erupts there are those nay-sayers who shake their heads and long for the "good old days" and pity the poor children growing up in this era. So it is good to have evidence to the contrary. My only problem with this book is that I couldn't read the whole thing because in making his case, the author reviews the violent history of the world and I got to a point where I just couldn't bear to hear one more crime against humanity. For example, we all know that ancient Romans in their glory days used to feed Christians to the lions for entertainment. But did you ever know that they used to act out myths and stories in the coliseum using slaves to act out the parts of the doomed? One such story involved chaining a live slave to a rock and having a trained bird fly out and eat the liver out of him like the story of Prometheus. I also learned the the word "genocide" was not even in use until around 1944 when it came into play to describe Hitler's plans. The reason it wasn't used was that warring nations frequently attempted to demolish whole societies or groups of people, and since that was the point of wars there was no crime. So, I fast-forwarded to the chapters on conclusions and was able to gather enough information to feel like I got the gist of the book. I realize that's not the ideal way to read any book, but I am glad to have read it at all.

I found this book to be very enlightening. It's the kind of book that tends to stay with you and gives you some insight into the history of "un-civilization".Our lives are very short and it leaves us feeling like today is the same as tomorrow which was the same as yesterday. When you read a book like this, you come away realizing that we are living in a bubble of current time and place. The point of the book is in a nutshell that over time, humanity has gotten better and less violent. And it does so very well primarily by engulfing the reader as to how bad things really used to be. Going back to biblical times reveals a people who view barbarism as par for the day and genocide as a good way of dealing with enemies. War with swords was a pretty horrible way to fight and just as deadly as mortars. Over time we graduated to having more technology and we used it to torture people and enslave them more efficiently.As a parent, you often hear that back in the day kids could run around town and be safe from predators. But statistically, children are very unlikely to be kidnapped by strangers. Of course it happens and when it does we have the technology to beam it all over the place. But it isn't as often as you think.The book makes a point that there are still horrifying acts committed by humans - no one can plausibly deny that. However, it makes the point that we see them as horrifying acts. The biggest difference I noticed in the book was that our empathy has increased and we know have a more honed conscience when it comes to acts of violence. We don't tolerate what we used to.It's not perfect but it's hard not to read a book like this and feel more optimistic about the future, not less. Over time, it does seem like humans can become better toward one another and it's nice to have a book like this to at least have a historical and data driven reason to believe so.PS - It's way too long. Needs an editor.

This is an amazing read. It goes through violence throughout history, how it has declined and it's likely causes. Despite what we're hearing through the news and what feels right, there is very strong evidence that violence is decreasing at a very significant rate and the world is becoming a safer place. The latter third of the book goes into some of the psychological explanations behind this and people's desires to do bad and good things.It is a big book and it took me a few months to get through, but it's understandable as the topic is a big one. His writing style is very conversational and, on the whole, easy to read. There were very few moments that dragged. For a non-fiction book, it was quite a page-turner.There is some criticism of Pinker's work. One issue is that it is largely western-focused, which it is, but this is what we have good evidence for so you can't blame him for reporting on it. The other criticisms seem to be regarding the potential inaccuracy of historical data. I don't think anyone doubts that the further back you go, the bigger the errors are, but this is acknowledged and the evidence still seems to support Pinker's conclusions. It seems like the main reason for criticism is that some people (for some unknown reason) just don't like the conclusion.It's really heartening to see that we, as a human race, are learning and constantly improving on the past. War, violence and suffering is becoming more abhorrent and we're more inclusive of people different to us and further away from us. Each data point is a tragedy on its own and we still have a long way to go, but it is good to know that trends are generally heading in the right direction. It is a reminder for anyone who is nostalgic about the past to really consider what they think it was like. There is no "golden age" to revert back to. It's also a reminder to question what "seems right" and to look at what the data say.

Over 36 hours of listening. Better listened to than read. When listening, if the discussion gets beyond me I can just keep on doing what I am doing until it comes back to my level. And it always did before long. So, ok, it went over my head at times, and the audio version does not come with the charts and tables, but these are minor and not even annoying. The fact is that it kept me coming back because I always knew there was more that I would find interesting, that would make me glad I stuck with it. There was always another moment when I'd say to myself, yes, this is worth coming back to.The narration is perfect. I could believe it was the author speaking to me. Without sounding like a Harvard professor, he sounded like someone I can like. It would be all scholarly-like for a while and then I’d hear a quote from Bruce Springsteen, Woody Allen or my personal Woodstock favorites, Country Joe and the Fish. There were also plenty of references to current pop culture but I just don’t remember them as much as those from my boomer culture.I don’t think I would have appreciated this book in my twenties but after many discussions and disagreements over the question of where our society is headed, are we getting better or worse, I love that steven Pinker has done the work for me. Because I have always believed it in my heart, I accept his research as the confirmation.  I am considering buying a print or ebook version to reread sections that were particularly enlightening. There is no table of contents in the audio version so I used an ebook preview to see how the book is organized and I find it is quite perfect, very descriptive so that I can find my way back easily enough. A very satisfying experience, it will not be my last from Steven Pinker.

This could well be the most important book of the last decade. The author explains clearly that violence has decreased in our day and age, contrary to popular opinion. He then goes on to eviscerate the arguments against this view and proposes a number of reasons why this might be so.He comes up with five:* the force of the Leviathan and how it disincentivizes violent behaviour for gain* gentle commerce, and its role in seeing others not as potential victims to be robbed, but trade partners instead, making the peaceful option have a better payoff* increasing feminization of a society, reducing the urge for honor and glory, and making the pursuit of this strategy have less payoff* an expanding circle of sympathy, beyond ones one tribe, family, country, letting others be viewed as humans, partners instead of dehumanized targets for aggression* the rise of reason and how reason favors a fair, humanist and non-violent approach to mattersThe author uses the concept of the Prisoner's Dilemma to construct a variant, called the Pacifist' Dilemma. In his variant, he shows how previously (without the afore-mentioned 5 factors) aggression would trump pacifism as a strategy. He then creates an adjusted matrix, with adjusted payoffs, accounting individually for each of the five factors. This is his coup de grace to demonstrate abstract concepts into tangible payoff considerations for a potential aggressor.Besides the excellent presentation of his evidence and the construction of his case, one cannot help but see that mr Pinker has his heart in the right place and deeply cares about the human condition. A heart-warming book that made me realize we are not doing so bad, despite the best efforts of our media to make us believe the opposite.

After finishing this book, I can share in the gratitude that Pinker expresses in the final chapter and even dare to indulge in some optimism that he, most wisely, explains that he tries to refrain from (per scientific correctness, not because I for one cannot feel that there are reasonable causes to be optimistic).And it is a gratitude for the people and their ideas and even chance that has so made it that we live in what, I am now convinced, is the best of times as far as violence is concerned. Pinker arguments following a scientifically honest course of trying to analyse the plausibility as well as the validity of primary hypotheses so that he can have a better chance of explaining situations in their appropriate statistical magnitude. He approaches the grail of causality in each case efficiently, carefully presenting data, and providing valid observations and references that present different points of view. The language is exquisitely refined, proof of his mastery, and makes for comfortable reading that helps one focus on complex ideas and arguments than trying to decipher what the writer says.This is a must for every person interested in crucial philosophical arguments as well everyone with the patience for a long book (Pinker himself tries to explain the reasons for the length and I thought he was right).The scope is vast and many pleasant surprises (unknown unknowns and unknown knowns) made this a purifying, pacifying, stimulating experience. And it was at the same a ton of fun! This is a fantastic book I enjoyed so deeply that I wish the experience upon others who have yet to read it. I 'm quite confident many who have read it would agree. Recommended with hands, feet, fingers, toes and all!

Steven Pinker is known for his wide-ranging advocacy of evolutionary psychology and, as the expression goes, “when you’re a hammer, everything looks like a nail.” The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined (TBAoON) purports to show just that. That over the ages of human history, violence has declined. Pinker is an acknowledged authority on such subjects as language and cognition. TBAoON is not a book on any of that.
