Pinker stretches his argument over 800 pages with research data, graphs and tabulations. Unfortunately, what he suggests is at best, open to interpretation. Statistics are like that. As is often done, the author uses a highly selective interpretation of data. He appears to select what supports his hypothesis and disregards the rest. Further, while there might be more evidence to support it, he does not present it and his extrapolations seem to be weak at best. Statistical sample sizes seem at times to be small and Pinker makes no apologies for this and fails to proffer its limitations. In fact, we are even sometimes asked to ignore some of the data. Ahhh, me thinks not.A tome this size perhaps warrants more of a review however, when the scientific method is totally mangled and evidence-based science is completely ignored, it’s probably time to stop reading let alone spend the time reviewing a book like this. I thoroughly enjoyed The Blank Slate. It was my introduction to Steven Pinker. I thought that I could not wait to read more by this author. I should have become suspicious about one who writes on subjects seemingly light years removed from his field of expertise. However, I took a chance and unfortunately, I was disappointed.

Pick up any newspaper and you will be deluged with editorials and news bemoaning the violence in our society. From regional skirmishes, wars and your neighbor sticking a knife in her husband’s eye, our world seems drenched in mayhem. However, your neighbor’s sudden loss of depth perception aside, Stephen Pinker contends we live in a historically pacific age.Taken from a historic perspective your chances of meeting a violent death is up to 30 times less than previously. In days of yore small city states would go to war and the best way of settlement an argument was by hitting your opponent with a rock. Even when taking into consideration cataclysmic events, like when Germans begin poking about for lebensraum, centralized governments that can keep peace within larger borders result in a safer and happier world.Consider when Mongols were rampaging and the various internal Chinese conflicts going back 800 years. As a percentage of world population these conflicts were much worse that World War II – and this was done with just people with pointy sticks making holes in people.On a much smaller level, individuals in civilized societies are more peaceable. My gosh, you can’t even spank children any more – even when the little bugger is really asking for it. We tend to treat others more civilly and law and order generally prevail.So keep an optimistic thought and be grateful that a Mongol is not bashing in your front door, putting an arrow in your forehead and looking with uncomfortable favor toward your significant other.Well researched and readable. Two doves up.

I listened to the first five hours of this monstrous book (nearly 37 hours long), waiting for it to grip my attention, but the hook never came, so I'm abandoning it.His main point, THAT violence has declined, was made comprehensively in the first chapter, backed up by lists of statistics. But the subtitle is WHY violence has declined, so the rest of the book is, presumably, a detailed account of all the myriad changes that various societies underwent over the course of history. For sure there are good points made, but they are embedded in a never-ending stream of statistics and references to scholarly articles, which makes this more of a reference text than anything.It could easily be condensed to about a third of the size for the casual reader; as it is it's not worth the time investment.

Pinker's message is compelling: the world is a safer, less violent place, and our attitudes as well as our actions have shifted. He is less than compelling when he rails against organized religion, occasionally twisting things just a bit to fit his bias, while seeming to have a blind spot when it comes to the identical behavior done by governments. This is, I believe, because he sees governments as an essential civilizing force, justifying the excesses they passed through. Since he fails to see such a vital role for religion -- and possibly holds some level of personal animosity for religiosity -- he forgives none of their excesses. I prefer the explanation that religion, like democratic forms of government, starts out with noble aims that are always at risk of corruption and the hands of those who hold power. The other main complaints I have with this book is it's exhaustive length -- 800+ pages. However, its length is also its strength – I’ve always believed in progress, and this book buttresses and fortifies that belief in this dimension so securely that it is hard to imagine changing it.As an aside, it is odd to read how many “progressives” are such skeptics of progress. It makes one wonder about the traditional labels “liberal” and “conservative” – aren’t conservatives supposed to be always looking backwards to an older and better era? It seems that if you look far enough back, to the cultures of indigenous peoples, than you cease being a conservative at all, I suppose since those values were preserved and thus can’t be conserved.

My one question going into the book was, “What makes people violent?” “Why do some people just want to fight?” Two questions I guess. I’ve been asking those questions since first seeing a bloody bar brawl. It seemed so stupid to me. I don’t think I’m above it in any way. I’m just a coward, I don’t like confrontation, even when drunk. So what makes some people want to fight, murder, rape, pillage, or carry out genocide? Pinker answers these questions thoroughly enough. My theory that American men in southern States are more violent because their balls are always sticking to their legs, was not confirmed.I learned some interesting things and failed to learn some uninteresting things. When Pinker talks brain hardware for instance, I’m lost. I’m just not smart enough to understand everything he’s writing about. Fortunately, much of the book covers history and the evolution of law, economy, science, humanity, and reason to make us a less violent species. Encouragingly, every section of the book manages to confirm that the human species is becoming less violent. Good news for wimps like me. I wouldn’t have seen my second birthday had I been born more than 100 years ago. This is a good book. It’s another confirmation that things are getting better. We’ve had a few hiccups like WW1 and 2, but overall the trend is towards a safer and more intelligent society. Even violent groups like ISIS tend to be their own worst enemies and I’m convinced they won’t last. The vast majority of the world is more reasonable than they are; reason will win. Good book.

Original review in 2015:This is one of the longest books I've read so far (800 pages, 36 hours as audiobook), but I will try to convince you it was worth it. For some people knowing that the author is Steven Pinker is enough, but for the rest of you, read on.The main thesis of the book is that violence has decreased in the World. In fact it has been decreasing for hundrends and thousands of years. Does this sound outrageous in light of the daily news reports on wars, terrorism and other forms of violence?Well, Pinker didn't just waste these 800 pages on nothing. He cites numerous statistics and studies on a vast variety of topics to demonstrate that violence has truly been declining for millennias. He then investigates what has caused this trend with similar deep resesrch based on studies and statistics. This book will probably convince you that we're very lucky to live in this relatively peaceful era which the author calls The New Peace.Pinker presents all of that in a wonderful, easy to understand style that will keep the reader turning one page after the other. Recommended.New comment on 30 August 2016:I think the findings are correct for the known recorded history, however it is speculative for much of human history which we only little of. I remember Chomsky once said that the book was inaccurate for 95% of human history (190 thousand out of 200 thousand years). Also some have criticized it for using percentages rather than raw numbers for deaths. Nevertheless, it is a great book.

I'm giving this book 5 stars because I learned a hell of a lot from it. I haven't cross referenced everything or checked all the facts or plunged into the bibliography and checked sources, but I found it quite persuasive and well argued. There were some spots that seemed a little shaky fact wise, but the overall picture of a less violent world made sense to me. I can see people who are far left/marxist/etc. not liking this book just because of what he is arguing. That being said, it isn't a right wing book at all either. I would recommend simply for the amount you can learn from it, the bibliography, and facing the argument that the world is less violent now than it was before and challenging your belief if you see it otherwise. I think if you are personally invested in the idea that the world is very unjust, which it is, you will hate the fact that he is arguing that it is less violent than it has ever been, because you have so much personal investment in that viewpoint and you feel that saying it is less violent minimizes that atrocities that do still take place, which isn't what the author is doing. Rather he is just painting of picture of what has caused violence to decrease and therefore use this knowledge to further decrease it in the future and continue down that path. He could be wrong, but I hope he isn't and hopefully we can continue this downward trend.

Few books truly qualify as "must-read", but the evidence Pinker marshals for the historical decline in violence is so massive that it simply must be seen by a serious student of history, society or psychology. Pinker begins with the obvious culprits of war, genocide and murder, but persuasively links these declines with equally striking declines in things like spanking, rape and animal cruelty. Perhaps most interestingly for Pinker's career, he is an "innatist", believing that the human being has many permanently imprinted bits of human nature that make us the way we are. So this book is a departure from books like his "Blank Slate", since he's arguing here that our human nature can be slowly steered towards historical -- and in this case, very benign -- change in how it manifests in the world. His evidence may be overwhelming, but Pinker's explanations of cause will cause controversy. He is basically a Hobbesian, saying that the growth in powerful states (for example) was one of the key factors in the decline in violence. Those who think that states and governments are the source of all bad things will naturally disagree. But Pinker is persuasive, and as always the writing is gentlemanly and elegant. One of the best books I've read in years. I should mention that Pinker and I are friendly acquaintances, but I'm not praising "Angels" because we're friendly. We've gotten to know each other because our interests overlap.

There are some serious points to make about the content of this book:1. The validity of the author's analyses is at best doubtful. As he mentions himself, there's not much reliable data on violence before we (read: Western countries) started to measure this phenomenon. This leads me to conclude that a serious portion of his data is a best guess, itself based on the best guesses of historians (for the years before the 20th century) and of social scientists (for the 20th century onwards).2. Long term trends - even based on fully accurate and reliable data - are very hard to detect and even more difficult to predict. This means that any model or conclusion based on these trends is a (serious) simplification of reality. This is a major issue in ecnonomics, but pops up in these sorts of studies as well. 3. Both aforementioned points lead to the conclusion that the message of this book has to be taken with a grain of salt.4. At times, the author doesn't shy away of letting the reader know his political convictions. It makes the reader wonder about the objectivity of the author, which is unnecessary in my opinion.But apart from these points, it is an exhaustive book, covering a huge amount of time and space and it brings a positive message, written in an attractive and easy-to-follow style. Nowadays it is easy to get carried away in the biased news broadcasts and social media moments, so this was definitely a refreshing read.

I have heard excellent reviews about this book.Not normally a fan of Pinkers, I have read some of his brain stuff and wasn't really impressed but I was prepared to read this cos I was curious to see what he has to say on violence.The big problem with this book is that its written like a PhD dissertation and as such it is repetitive. Constantly repeating assumption, evidence for the assumption, restating the theory & demonstrating how the theory works with the data or evidence. Hence it is excruciatingly long and somewhat tedious. Why he does this is because he believes we're gonna laugh at him for stating that us humans are becoming less violent. So he is demonstrates how our society is becoming less violent in various aspects, such as our penal code, our treatment of children, women, animals, war... in religion and the catalyst for the change. And I think he is right. But when I have discussed this with people, they refused to believe it was true so perhaps Pinker was right to bore nonbelievers into submission. I kind of think I know how he thinks we have achieved it but he is hinting at the method and I would like to know how he thinks it was achieved. Anyway why we have achieved it served as the big reveal but it got weighted down under so much material that the message got lost under the premise.

This book is a long challenging read, but definitely worth the effort.He traces violence throughout human history (and prehistory!) and demonstrates convincingly that the present day is less violent than it ever has been. Murder, genocide, war, torture, cruelty to animals: all are at the lowest level ever.Pinker is a rigorous scientist. Read this book and you'll be less satisfied with the fuzzy minded handwaving offered by other writers. He'll give an argument that seems reasonable, then points out that it's not conclusive, and offers more evidence, then points out any problems that remain.Readers of The Righteous Mind will be interested to know that he discusses Jonathan Haidt's moral classification scheme, along with related ones.Steven Pinker's writing is very clear, even playful. This is the second of his books I've read and I will certainly be reading more.I should probably try to summarize some of the major points, but wanted to get this out right now. If you want more, remind me to flesh this out.

The first half of the book, in which Pinker tries to prove THAT violence has declined, is very well put-together. That violence has declined is somewhat surprising and opposes the implicit world-view of almost all of the media, so it's important to document it thoroughly. Pinker does so.Then he gets into WHY it has declined. I found this part of the book much less satisfying; fewer statistics, and parts of it feel like he has a bunch of cool factoids he wants to jam in regardless of their relevance to his arguments. Many of them were indeed cool and were news to me, but some of the pieces that I know a little bit about (specifically, the game theory parts) were very cursory overviews that overstated the certainty that the results of these very simplified problems were applicable to the real world. This made me doubt that entire part of the book.One thing I can say in Pinker's favor about the "why" part: since this book came out, it's been in the news that the surge of violence in the 60s through the 80s was highly correlated with leaded gasoline use, 20-year-time-lagged (presumably because the resultant large amounts of environmental lead caused brain damage in children that led them to be more violent adults.) At the time of writing, this wasn't known, and Pinker both pointed out this surge and didn't claim to have a good explanation for it.

I think it's best to just let David Bentley Hart share some thoughts here:"In his latest book, The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined, he devotes over seven hundred pages to arguing the case that modernity, contrary to the common impression, has seen a steep decrease in every kind of violence—domestic, political, criminal, and martial—as a result of a variety of causes, but principally because of the triumph of “Enlightenment” ideas. It is a simple narrative, and at many points a painfully simplistic one, but it is clear and bracing and merits sympathetic consideration.Whether Pinker himself does the tale justice, however, is debatable. He is definitely not an adept historian; his view of the past—particularly of the Middle Ages, which he tends to treat as a single historical, geographical, and cultural moment—is often not merely crude, but almost cartoonish (of course, he is a professed admirer of Norbert Elias). He even adduces two edited images from Das Mittelalterliche Hausbuch as illustrations of “the everyday texture of life in medieval Europe,” without noting that they come from a set of astrological allegories about planetary influences, from which he has chosen those for Saturn and Mars rather than, say, Venus and Jupiter. (Think what a collection of Saturnine or Martial pictures he might have gathered from more recent history.)"

In this veritable tome, Pinker presents the argument that over the last millennium, multiple dimensions of the human experience have been trending toward a less violent state. To do this, he takes us on a rich journey through the historical record, demographic and cultural trends, punctuated by well-qualified statistics and inferences from a variety of sources. Pinker draws on theories and examples from fields as diverse as anthropology, evolutionary and social psychology, neuroanatomy, cognitive science, and behavioral and rational economics to build a case that there are knowable signals and milestones which indicate when a given society is disposed to lower or higher levels of violence, including violence towards other states, its own citizens, and marginalized classes. There are a few areas which were difficult to get through, such as Pinker's graphic depictions of medieval torture, cruelty to animals, and child abuse, and if there's any legitimate knock against this work, it's the sheer amount of theory, data, and argumentation brought to bear on this topic. But it's hard to imagine the conclusion making as much of a dent in the conventional wisdom without it all. All in all, "The Better Angels of Our Nature" is a worthy effort that strives to combat the doomsday pessimism that pervades modern sociopolitical discourse.

In this book Steven Pinker somehow surprisingly argues that the world is getting better and better - at least when it comes to the declining rate of violence in the world. At the beginning of the book I was rather skeptic, but after some pages I realized that this is a book based on evidence and real science. And yes, I am convinced. Generally the relative rate of violence in the world is declining. Actually I was convinced after just 3-400 pages. The book is more than 800 pages, and the last 400 pages was not needed for me to believe the authors claim. Nevertheless it was indeed interesting to read.Specially I found the parts describing the rights revolutions, and how the society has developed its views on what is regarded to be unfair and cruel to be interesting. It has been big changes just the last 50 years in most developed countries.The book is big, fact based and impressing. However, it is also a bit too long sometimes and tend to be a bit boring at the end. But this is just a detail in the big picture. Because the thing about this book is that it makes you believe in the good of humanity and that the world is going in the right direction. Reading it made me think positive about our shared future!I hope it will have this impact on you too.

The 24 hour news cycle serves a stream of blood and chaos that shapes our view of violence. It makes us resistant to the suggestion that past human history could have been far worse. What if you could find a well-documented source of information that shows a historical progression toward a less violent world. Could it really be that our increasingly populated, frantically busy modern world is an improvement over times past in the harm that humans do to other humans.Stephen Pinker’s book argues all of the above. The data he sites is vast and persuasive. It shows how rates of murder, slavery, animal cruelty, torture, and other behavior we now consider grossly perverse plummeted over a dozen decades under the influence of the Enlightenment, literacy, and republican governance. Better yet, he documents how in a few more recent decades the definition of human rights rapidly spread to include women, blacks, gays, and even animals. And his analysis of wars past and present is just and radical and interesting.While this is a bit of a tome with lots of graphs and theories, it will be highly informative for the patient reader who would like proof that the world is a bit better than he or she thinks it is.

Steven Pinker's The Better Angels of our Nature: Why Violence has declined is a really good example of why I try to read non-fiction on a regular basis. The thesis of the book is simply that as a species, humans are less violent now than we were in the past, regardless of what the news, politicians, or anyone else says.The book, although a little dry and hovering at just over 700 pages, works to prove that historically, we had a much higher tolerance for violence than we do now, and that if you take into account the percentage of an effected population rather than the simple number of people killed, people are killing each other a lot less now than they did in the past.This doesn't mean that no one is killing anyone else, or that all violence is going to disappear sometime soon, it simply means that on a societal level, we aren't being as violent as we used to be.The book is definitely one that opens up conversation, and the reviews all seem to either love it or hate it, but for me it was an interesting look at our history of violence towards each other, with an optimistic look to the future (Pinker does not suggest a perfect future, but a much more tolerant one).A Fascinating Read.

Popular opinion suggests that we live in dangerous times. People of all ideologies believe that the world is more dangerous than ever and media is constantly consumed with fears about terrorism, shootings, child danger and kidnapping, rape, abuse, murder, etc. Yet all categories of violence are on the decline and have been for a long time. That's not to say that we should ignore any current violence or downplay atrocities, but Pinker provides a great grain of salt to put the world in perspective.This book challenged me in many ways. It makes a counter-intuitive case that the world is the safest it has ever been and has been improving in just about every metric. It's also a very long and dense book, which takes a lot of commitment to finish. This is a book that I think is worth reading twice, though due to the commitment of 800 pages, i doubt I'll be re-reading it anytime soon. If the length is intimidating, I highly suggest that you at the very least skim the book to see the graphs and trends for various types of violence and perhaps read some of his articles online or watch his lectures on YouTube. There's much to be optimistic about in the world. There's plenty of atrocities in the world to focus on but overall we live in wonderful times.

In order to talk about the history and present of violence, this book had to cover a lot of other ground digging into the mysteries of humanity itself. Why do we do bad things? What is bad, and how do we decide what good and bad is? What are these forces inside us, why did they get there, and how are they being composed over time to make these (measured and measured and measured) effects?I found each of these building blocks to be as interesting as the thesis as a whole. Over the few weeks I read the book I kept saying to my wife "so I was reading the violence book, and did you know..."It is a large, large book. I felt like I'd been reading for quite a while (on a kindle app, which made it hard to appreciate the book's heft up front) and was a little shocked to see I was less than 5% through. But, it was worth it. I particularly appreciated the jokes and humor sprinkled throughout, which nicely leavened what could easily have been a dense loaf of facts and findings.Recommended for anyone curious how our world and cultures actually work, or anyone looking for some relief from the relentless "hell in a handbasket" messages we're fed by media/religious leaders/government.
